snippet: Owners of Apple PowerBook 5300 and 190 models can trade in their old computers for $700 discount on one of company's 400-megahertz G3 laptops, which sell for $2,499; offer is good until Aug 31 (S)
lead_paragraph: Owners of the Apple PowerBook 5300 and 190 models can trade in their old computers for a significant discount on one of the company's 400-megahertz G3 laptops if they act quickly. From now until Aug. 31, Apple is offering $700 off the price of a new G3 PowerBook (usually $2,499) for those who choose to send their old 5300 or 190 models back to the company. The 5300/190 series, which was released in 1995, gained a measure of infamy because of a host of design and technical problems, and its overheating -- and occasionally combusting -- battery. Those interested in taking advantage of the offer should call Apple at (800) 767-2775. Although not so dramatic as bursting into flames, the discount seems a much safer way for the 5300/190 series to go out in a blaze of glory.
abstract: Owners of Apple PowerBook 5300 and 190 models can trade in their old computers for $700 discount on one of company's 400-megahertz G3 laptops, which sell for $2,499; offer is good until Aug 31 (S)

lead_paragraph: Nearly a half-century ago, the farmers in these dun-colored valleys east of the Cascade Mountains set out to create the perfect apple. It would be lipstick red; broad-shouldered; uniform in size, color and crispness; a health food that would look as dazzling as an ornament on a Christmas tree.
abstract: Many apple farmers acknowledge their own role in collapse of one of last sectors of American agriculture still dominated by family farms; say that in trying to create perfect Red Delicious apple for major supermarket chains, they may have sacrificed taste to cosmetics; Pres Clinton recently signed biggest bailout in history of apple industry, after government reported that apple growers lost $760 million in last three years; growers say they established color, size and firmmess standards in response to major supermarket chains, who want consistent product that catches eye of harried shopper; say result is rosy red apple that lacks taste of old Red Delicious; most orchards continue to produce these perfect apples, at huge losses; other apple farmers have started growing new varieties like Fujis, Galas and Granny Smiths; farmers and apple trade associations say government bailout will not solve underlying problems of industry; three biggest apple-producing states are Washington, Michigan and New York; photos (L)

lead_paragraph: Apple Computer released a work-in-progress version of its new operating system -- Mac OS X -- which had Macintosh addicts and computer-industry analysts buzzing. The beta software, publicly available from Apple's Web site for $29.95, is the first look at a complete overhaul of the system that was first released in 1984 with the original Macintosh. Mac OS X combines an intuitive user interface on top of a robust infrastructure based on the Unix operating system. The final version is scheduled for release in 2001, when it may help restore Apple's shine as an industry innovator in a marketplace dominated by Microsoft Windows. J. D. Biersdorfer

snippet: Media Metrix survey shows Apple's Macintosh computers lost ground in American households last year; says 3.8 million households owned Macs in January, compared with 4.1 million a year earlier; finds that for first time, Gateway and Compaq Computer...
lead_paragraph: Despite the success of its iMac model, Apple's Macintosh computers lost ground in American households last year, according to a survey being released today by Media Metrix, the Web market-tracking company. The Media Metrix survey shows that 3.8 million households owned Macs in January, compared with 4.1 million a year earlier and 4.9 million in 1996. In a separate survey, Media Metrix found that for the first time, Gateway and Compaq Computer are the leading brands of Windows PC's in homes in the United States, each in about 5.4 million homes, followed by the previous leader, Packard-Bell, with 5.2 million. Laurie J. Flynn

Ronald Reagan was president, Steve Jobs was the chairman of Apple, and the consumer embrace of Windows was still several years away. (In those days many computers ran on the DOS platform, which involved a lot of typed commands instead of pointing and clicking.)
abstract: The last time Apple Computer introduced a fundamentally new operating system was in 1984, when System 1.0 shipped with the original Macintosh computer. Ronald Reagan was president, Steve Jobs was the chairman of Apple, and the consumer embrace of Windows was still several years away. (In those days many computers ran on the DOS platform, which involved a lot of typed commands instead of pointing and clicking.)

abstract: Honolulu is about 5,200 miles west of New York City. A sampling of attractions, along with travel information:    Where to Stay    HALEKULANI, 2199 Kalia Road, (808) 923-2311. This is the premier hotel in the islands and one of the half-dozen finest in the United States, an oasis of taste in tacky Waikiki, with 740 employees for 456 rooms. Order freshly squeezed pineapple juice for breakfast in your handsome beige-and-pale-blue bedroom, gaze out to sea and glow. Two of Hawaii's top restaurants are downstairs, plus chic shops and a pool with the famous orchid logo. Civic minded as well as elegant, the Halekulani offers guests free admission to leading museums and musical events. Current rates for a double-occupancy room range from $325 to $520 a night.

lead_paragraph: TO sit down in front of the stunning computing control screen that defines the new Apple Macintosh OS X operating system is to be struck not just by the shock of the new, but also by the startling return of the old.
abstract: TO sit down in front of the stunning computing control screen that defines the new Apple Macintosh OS X operating system is to be struck not just by the shock of the new, but also by the startling return of the old.    The software, expected to reach the market early next year, is still in the test phase. But any longtime personal computer user who has a chance to try it out will almost instantly recognize that beneath the new software, with its screens of lollipop colors, beats the heart of Steven Jobs's 11-year-old Nextstep operating system.

lead_paragraph: Whatever else it did tonight, the Supreme Court failed to speak with the kind of clarion political voice about the vexed 2000 presidential election that much of the nation had hoped for.
abstract: Whatever else it did tonight, the Supreme Court failed to speak with the kind of clarion political voice about the vexed 2000 presidential election that much of the nation had hoped for.    If, as seems sure, Gov. George W. Bush has won, he has won a narrow victory -- narrow in Florida, narrow in the Electoral College and narrow in the Supreme Court. He will have only a shaky platform from which to begin his presidency in January, and it will require immense skill to remove the questions about his legitimacy that were left hanging by tonight's decision.

This is the epicenter of the Strip, and hence of Las Vegas. The 3,000 rooms are beautifully furnished in subdued tones of beige (subdued! in Vegas!). The lobby ceiling is an explosion of Dale Chihuly glass. And nothing equals the eight-acre lake and its captivating water-cannon fountains, which shoot columns of spray into the air like rockets and dance as if Busby Berkeley were in charge. Double rooms: $159 to $750.

snippet: Stephen Mihm, whose apartment is 250 square feet, interviews other Manhattanites who live in small places and like it that way; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: A LOT of New Yorkers live in small spaces, some smaller than others. My own, for example, measures 250 square feet as the crow walks. Over time, I've become obsessed with making the most of it, getting up at odd hours to stack file cabinets and weed my belongings, even removing doors from hinges. Today, within easy reach, I also have a sofa, a desk, two chairs, three bureaus and an 18-pound cat named Gus, who takes up more than his fair share of the bed.

snippet: News analysis: Florida Supreme Court justices hearing arguments in suit over presidential balloting seem to be searching for way to reconcile competing imperatives of how to ensure that votes of every Floridian will be counted, to degree possible,...
lead_paragraph: The resolution of a momentous political question who will be the next president of the United States -- passed today, at least for now, into the hands of the justices of the Florida Supreme Court, seven men and women little known in their state, let alone the nation as a whole.
abstract: News analysis: Florida Supreme Court justices hearing arguments in suit over presidential balloting seem to be searching for way to reconcile competing imperatives of how to ensure that votes of every Floridian will be counted, to degree possible, without taking so long that final result will come too late to be reflected in Electoral College; seem to be groping toward timetable of their own devising that will allow manual recounting of votes to proceed but still permit legal underbrush to be cleared in time to allow state to participate fully in national political decision-making; decision may not be straight yes-or-no verdict on whether to count contested votes (M)

lead_paragraph: ''Now we learn,'' said the political scientist Thomas Mann, one of the leading authorities on Congress, ''who the grown-ups are around here.'' Like the rest of the nation, Mr. Mann, who is based at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group, awoke to a situation unprecedented in modern American history, shaped by a once-in-a-lifetime series of electoral events that holds the potential for stalemate and instability.
abstract: Analysis of once-in-a-lifetime series of electoral events that holds potential for stalemate and instability; Thomas Mann, political scientist, poses question: if Vice Pres Al Gore actually wins popular vote in Florida, but Gov George W Bush is credited with its electoral votes, would Gore and Bush engage in series of recriminations or even lawsuits, or would they decide, separately or together, to accept verdict, however flawed, and move forward; chart (M)

snippet: Upstart fashion and Internet companies use items other than classic engraved invitations to lure people ot shows and parties; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Eschewing classic engraved invitations, upstart fashion and Internet companies are getting overcreative to lure guests to opening shows and parties. This week, the Internet beauty company Eve.com sent gold-painted boxes containing two apples -- one red, one gilded (and no fresher for it) -- with party details tagged to the stem. Ozwald Boateng, the designer for Bespoke Couture, included a credit-card-shape CD rom with his invitation, showing his collections and an art movie he produced. The designer Rene Lezard pinned a breakfast invitation to a brick of beige felt (to pin thumb-size to-do lists?). ELLEN TIEN

lead_paragraph: Vancouver, British Columbia, is nearly 3,000 miles northwest of New York City. A sampling of attractions, along with travel information, with prices in United States dollars ($1 equals $1.49 Canadian):
abstract: Vancouver, British Columbia, is nearly 3,000 miles northwest of New York City. A sampling of attractions, along with travel information, with prices in United States dollars ($1 equals $1.49 Canadian):    Where to Stay    FOUR SEASONS, 791 West Georgia Street, (604) 689-9333. Canada is justly proud of this Toronto-based chain, and Vancouver has no more prestigious address. Guests can avail themselves of an indoor/outdoor pool and a 165-shop mall that leads off the swanky lobby (with Birger Christensen and Prada as bait for the unwary). From the upper floors sweeping vistas open across the harbor to the mountains. But guest rooms are a bit dowdy, and service is disjointed. Double rooms: $302.58 to $383.27.

lead_paragraph: The leaves have turned cranberry red and mustard yellow in the Fox River Valley, and people are obsessing as usual about the Packers, the community-owned football team up in Green Bay.
abstract: The leaves have turned cranberry red and mustard yellow in the Fox River Valley, and people are obsessing as usual about the Packers, the community-owned football team up in Green Bay.    But something new has been added to the usual seasonal mix: Appleton, a pleasant city of 85,000 at the northern end of Lake Winnebago, finds itself squarely in the cross-hairs of the 2000 presidential campaign. This is the swing region in one of the handful of swing states in the neck-and-neck battle between Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

lead_paragraph: Seattle is 2,895 miles northwest of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
abstract: Seattle is 2,895 miles northwest of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:    Where to Stay    ALEXIS, 1007 First Avenue, (206) 624-4844. A graceful, century-old 109-room classic, this is a member of the boutique chain assembled by the California hotelier Bill Kimpton. The public spaces are filled with the work of regional artists (including several vibrant Dale Chihuly glass sculptures), and the bright bedrooms are decorated with cheerful, traditional fabrics. No view, but you waken to the sound of sea gulls and foghorns. Terrific Aveda spa. Double rooms from $230.

lead_paragraph: A deputy no more, Vice President Al Gore made his debut as the Democratic presidential nominee tonight with a vow to work for all Americans, ''especially those who need a voice, those who need a champion, those who need to be lifted up so they are never left behind.''
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore makes his debut as Democratic presidential nominee with vow to work for all Americans; speaking to Democratic National Convention and the nation beyond, Gore distances himself from Pres Clinton, saying 'I stand here tonight as my own man'; lays groundwork for a fall campaign in which he will identify himself as friend of the little guy and Gov George Bush as candidate of the rich, powerful and influential; Gore lays out his position on range of issues in speech with few rhetorical flourishes or unexpected policy departures; promises to enact tax reforms targeting working families, preserve abortion rights, oppose school vouchers and support affirmative action; says comprehensive campaign spending reform bill will be his first order of business if elected; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: Ending more than two years of very public indecision, Apple Computer's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, said today he was dropping the ''interim'' from ''interim chief executive,'' the title under which he has led the company back into prosperity in the last two and a half years.
abstract: Ending more than two years of very public indecision, Apple Computer's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, said today he was dropping the ''interim'' from ''interim chief executive,'' the title under which he has led the company back into prosperity in the last two and a half years.    The announcement that he was staying on indefinitely at the computer company he co-founded almost 25 years ago was made in typical Jobsian style before an overflow crowd of more than 4,000 Macintosh users -- as a footnote to a lengthy keynote presentation at the company's biannual Macworld exhibition, which opened here today.

lead_paragraph: Philadelphia is 100 miles south of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:
abstract: Philadelphia is 100 miles south of New York City. Here is a sampling of attractions, along with travel information:    Where to Stay     FOUR SEASONS, 1 Logan Square, (215) 963-1500. The opulent, flower-filled lobby tells the story: no expense has been spared here. But as one of the hotel's executives says, ''The mahogany and marble are the easy parts.'' The hard part is building a skilled, attentive, kindly staff, and the Seasons succeeds superbly on that count, too. The Fountain dining room, where Jean-Marie Lacroix has presided since 1983, is the peer of any restaurant in town. Computer connections, a bit dated, are to be modernized soon. Double room: $240 to $320, weekends; $305 to $400, weekdays.     LOEWS, 1200 Market Street, (215) 627-1200. A tip of the Apple hat to the Tisch family, which has converted the landmark PSFS building into a hotel of ravishing Art Deco beauty. The old vault doors and silvery sans-serif signs have been used to great graphic effect in the lobby, amidst acres of rosewood and etched glass. The 583 bedrooms murmur ''Hollywood, 1930,'' with a chaise longue in every one; a club-floor library holds vintage books. Double room:  $175 to $365.     RITTENHOUSE, 210 West Rittenhouse Square, (215) 546-9000. The harsh zigzag facade does little for the harmony of the urban environment, though it gives the 128 guest rooms leafy views. Otherwise, the Rittenhouse is hard to fault, with a central location, an invitingly cool lobby and bedrooms swimming with space. Each has a desk tucked into an alcove, a fax and a video tape player, plus a dressing area and a marble bathroom with an oversize tub and separate stall shower. The low-key service is charmingly accommodating. Double rooms from $360; occasional weekend specials from $200.    Where to Eat     LE BEC-FIN, 1523 Walnut Street, (215) 567-1000. When Paul Bocuse visited Georges Perrier's formal little jewel box, with its raspberry-pink walls and tapestry-covered chairs, he pronounced it ''a real restaurant, more like Lyons than New York.'' The cooking is classical, lightened and brightened here and there with an Asian spice like Sichuan pepper. European fish (loup, turbot) are a specialty, as are desserts, dispensed from a calorie chariot five levels high. Great cheeses; great, very costly French wines.     FORK, 306 Market Street, (215) 625-9425. With bare floors, an open kitchen, and a fixation on freshness worthy of Alice Waters, this is the perfect place for lunch on a tour of the city's Colonial shrines. Try the satisfyingly rustic chicken-mushroom-barley soup, a fishy or meaty salad and the chocolate cake with banana gelato, plus a beer from the cosmopolitan list.     PASION!, 211 South 15th Street, (215) 875-9895. For my money, Guillermo Pernot's nuevo Latino cooking is the most exciting in Philadelphia at the moment. A superlative chili-laced ceviche of Chilean sea bass and seaweed, presented alongside a scallop shell, is served with big smiles in a tented room full of palms and bright fabrics. Likewise, an Argentine mixed grill, a Haitian empanada and the very best Chilean wines.     PAT'S KING OF STEAKS, Ninth and Wharton Streets, (215) 468-1546. This is the real deal: these are the folks who gave the world the Philly cheese steak -- thinly sliced, quickly grilled beef, slapped onto an Italian roll, slathered with Cheez-Whiz, topped with onions. Pat's stands on a triangular traffic island in the heart of Rocky country, South Philadelphia, across the street from an asphalt basketball court. You order your sandwich at a tiny window and eat it at a plastic table, right on the street. It's silly, sloppy and, in its own way, sublime.     STRIPED BASS, 1500 Walnut Street, (215) 732-4444. The lofty ceilings and the marble columns of this erstwhile banking hall, built in 1927, always put me in a mellow mood, as do the Fortuny lighting fixtures and the snazzy metal fish hanging overhead. Terence Feury, an alumnus of Le Bernardin in Manhattan, has refreshed a tired menu with distinctive, unpompous dishes like crisp-skinned striped bass (what else?) served on a tangle of bitter greens.     SUSANNA FOO, 1512 Walnut Street, (215) 545-2666. Born in Mongolia, Sue Foo, as the local Asian grocers like to call her, is equally at home with Asian and European culinary traditions. In a dining room full of orchids and Asian art, she serves a trio of dumplings (shrimp, duck, lobster), each in a deliciously different wrapper, and dares to pair fish in a tangy, winy sauce with sweet rice. Five-spice Pennsylvania venison is another hit.     TANGERINE, 232 Market Street, (215) 627-5116. This semi-nightclub is the town's hot spot, so you have to put up with noise, semi-pro service and dim, candle-lighted, souk-like passageways. But most of the Moroccan fantasy food is well worth it, notably gnocchi with dates and harissa and a honey-and-lamb tagine, cooked in a crockery dish with a top shaped like a coolie's hat. The fish and the duck are overdone. Comfortably low-backed leather chairs; dandy desserts (chocolate cake streaked with tangerine) from Laurie Shapiro.    Attractions     ACADEMY OF MUSIC, 1420 Locust Street, at Broad Street, (215) 893-1999. The next program is the Pennsylvania Ballet's production of ''Dracula,'' opening Wednesday and running through June 11. Tickets: $15 to $86. The Philadelphia Orchestra begins its fall season in Sept.; June 18-19, Harry Connick Jr.     BARNES FOUNDATION, 300 North Latch's Lane, Merion, Pa., (610) 667-0290 (press 5 for reservations) or fax date, time, number of visitors and credit card number to (610) 667-8315. Reservations are required. Hours: September through June open Fridays through Sundays, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; July and August, Wednesdays through Fridays, 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5.     INDEPENDENCE HALL, Chestnut Street, between Fifth and Sixth Streets, (215) 597-8974. Free tours begin in the East Wing every 15 minutes, beginning at 9:15 a.m. Printed brochures are also available in Chinese, French, German, Hebrew, Italian, Japanese, Spanish or Russian. Hours: Daily, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. (Hours are extended for some buildings on weekends and in July and August.)     PHILADELPHIA MUSEUM OF ART, Benjamin Franklin Parkway at 26th Street, (215) 763-8100. ''The Splendor of 18th-Century Rome,'' through Sunday. Ticketed show: $12.50 for adults; $9.50 for students, the elderly and children. The audio tour is $5. Call: (215) 235-7469. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Wednesdays to 8:45 p.m. Admission: $8; $5, children under 18, students and the elderly; free on Sundays until 1 p.m.     PENNSYLVANIA ACADEMY OF THE FINE ARTS, Broad and Cherry Streets, (215) 972-7600. Through Sunday, the annual student exhibition and graduate thesis exhibition, with more than 1,000 paintings, prints, sculptures and mixed-media works. Most works are for sale. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5 ; $4, students; $3, those 18 and under; free to members, children under 5 and everyone on Sundays after 3 p.m.     THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA MUSEUM OF ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY, 33rd and Spruce Streets, (215) 898-4000. In ''44 Celebrity Eyes in a Museum Storeroom,'' 22 celebrities pick their favorites from the the collection; through Dec. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; closed Sundays Memorial Day through Labor Day. Admission: $5; $2.50, the elderly and students; free for children under 6.     ROSENBACH MUSEUM AND LIBRARY, 2010 Delancey Place, (215) 732-1600. Rare books, manuscripts, furniture, silver and painting. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. (Research library open by appointment only.) Admission is by tour only: $5; $3 for the elderly and students.     WILMA THEATER, 265 South Broad Street, at Spruce Street, (215) 546-7824. ''Cherry Docs,'' a drama by David Gow. Today at 8 p.m. (tickets are $35); tomorrow at 2 p.m. ($25) and at 8 p.m. ($38); Sunday at 2 p.m. ($30).    Getting There     BY TRAIN: Amtrak trains leave Penn Station in Manhattan daily for the 90-minute trip to 30th Street Station in Philadelphia, about every 25 minutes from 5 a.m. until 11:40 p.m. One-way adult fares: $43 to $77. Information: (800) 872-7245.     BY BUS: Greyhound buses leave Port Authority Bus Station in Manhattan every 30 minutes daily, from 7 a.m. to 11:30 p.m. The two-hour trip ends at the Greyhound station at 1010 Filbert Street, Philadelphia. One-way adult fare: $20. Information: (800) 229-9424.   R. W. APPLE Jr.

lead_paragraph: FOR years, experts in digital imagery have been puzzled by a major technical challenge: Can technology be developed that enables people to search for images by visual characteristics alone? Will searchers someday be able to find photographs of, say, a basketball game by searching for an image of a basketball, instead of relying on keywords tagged to that photograph?

Not us Americans, most of the time. We are subjected to tomatoes bred for thick skins, picked when half-ripe, gassed, shipped hither and yon and chilled until they give up the ghost.

lead_paragraph: IT'S never easy living as a Mac user in a Windows world, but it is a lot easier than it used to be. Microsoft, maker of Windows, was once thought to be Apple's greatest enemy. I will admit to referring to Microsoft as ''the Borg'' (taken from the dominating alien race on ''Star Trek: The Next Generation'') in those dark days of '97 when Apple's future looked shaky. But then things got better.

snippet: Computer makers, including Apple, Sony and Dell, are trying to spice up the market by providing digital video editing capabilities that can turn a passive computer user into a movie director; in addition, there is the new Lego Studios Steven Spiel...
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM HILL was delighted when he first heard about the digital video editing capabilities of the new Apple iMac DV. Mr. Hill, a 40-something actor in New York, was having trouble finding film roles, thanks in part to the Screen Actors Guild strike. He needed to edit his reel, the film equivalent of a resume, but he figured that renting a digital editing suite and editor would cost him at least $150 an hour. In comparison, a new iMac DV would cost $999 to $1,499, about $100 more than a comparable iMac without video editing.

snippet: Scene just south of New York City's Governors Island described as Working Waterfront Assn and Swim the Apple stage Swim-In to prove that harbor is healthy and to promote building of swimming beach on island; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE SETTING -- A quiet corner of a busy harbor, just south of Governors Island. On Monday, 30 intrepid souls plunged into the murky waters there, not only to escape the heat but also to make an ecopolitical point. The Swim-In, organized by the Working Waterfront Association and Swim the Apple, two groups that advocate greater use of the city's waterways, was staged to prove that the harbor can be swum without fear of undue goo or exotic infections, and to promote the building of a swimming beach on Governors Island.

lead_paragraph: Randolph Walker, a 71-year-old actor, had the right of way on Monday afternoon when a large red New York Apple Tours bus ran him over at a corner crosswalk. The bus driver did not have a proper license. The bus was not supposed to be turning onto a side street. The tour company that owns the bus has been issued 1,800 summonses for traffic violations, many for reckless driving. The buses, imported from Britain, have had trouble meeting national safety and environmental standards.

snippet: We place the dough in the pan so that, initially, it is just a bit higher than the rim. That's because it will tend to settle into the pan during baking. What we want in the final result is a tart that exactly matches the pan.
lead_paragraph: The best rolling board is marble because it manages to stay cool the longest, although other surfaces will serve, too. Other tricks in this process: Start the baking at a high temperature to seal the dough quickly, then lower it (as we describe below); remove the ring from the sides of the tart halfway through baking, to allow complete browning; use a black-surfaced tart pan to aid browning by intensifying the heat.

snippet: Sparkling apple cider from France is crisp and has modest 5.5 percent alcohol content; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Restaurant affectations are normally the last thing you want on Thanksgiving, but here's one idea worth stealing: serve a glass of brut sparkling apple cider as an aperitif. Brasserie 8 1/2 pours a gorgeously crisp cider, made by Etienne Dupont in Normandy, into Champagne flutes. The light apple flavor, suggesting chardonnay, and delicate fizz feel seasonal and festive. You might consider bolstering its modest 5.5 percent alcohol content the way it's done in Normandy, by adding a splash of Calvados. A 750-milliliter bottle is $7.99 at Fairway, 2127 Broadway (74th Street) and 2328 12th Avenue (132nd Street).

Robert L. Johnson, the founder of BET, would become a major shareholder of Viacom and retain his titles of chairman and chief executive. [Page C2.]

snippet: Eric Asimov comment on chenin blancs of Savennieres, France; maps (S)
lead_paragraph: IN the middle of the Loire Valley, from the Anjou region east past Tours, the greatness and versatility of chenin blanc is revealed. This grape, which has a reputation for making dull, indifferent wines elsewhere in the world, produces wines in this region that are light and crisp, and others that are nearly dry but for their slightly honeyed finish. They can be sparkling and refreshing or they can be thick and luscious enough to have for dessert.

lead_paragraph: KUDESH-Stephen Bernard. Age 56. Of Edison. Died Thursday, December 14, 2000, at St. Peter's Medical Center, New Brunswick. Born January 19, 1944, in Queens, NY. Resided in Bayside, Queens, then Kew Gardens, before moving to Edison 25 years ago. Partner at the Cornell Computer Corporation, a computer consulting firm, in Edison for over 10 years, and was also president of its Telecomm Division. Received an M.B.A. in finance from St. John's University, NYC, and did his undergraduate studies at St. Lawrence University, Canton, NY. He is a member of Temple Neve Shalom in Edison, and a member of its choir. He also served as vice president of the J.C.C. of Middlesex County, and is also on the Board of Directors. He also sang in the Big Apple Chorus, NYC, which was invited to sing in Russia in the summer of 2001, and had also sung in Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center with the Big Apple Chorus. Surviving family members: wife Enid (Zucker) Kudesh, daughter Michelle Kudesh, son Jeremy Kudesh. Funeral services Sunday, December 17, 2000, at 9:30 AM, in Temple Neve Shalom, 250 Grove Ave., Edison, NJ, Rabbi Gerald Zelizer officiating. Burial will follow in Beth El Cemetery, Oradell, NJ. Shiva will be observed at the family residence. For information, contact Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave., Fords, NJ. Condolence messages may be sent to our web address at: www.flynnfuneral.com.

We loved you, now we will miss you. Roberta, Rick, Helen and Families

lead_paragraph: DYSON-Dr. Anne E. The Board of Directors, performers and staff of the Big Apple Circus mourn the passing of Dr. Anne E. Dyson, friend, colleague and inspiration. Over the last decade the Big Apple Circus and the Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit (CCU) Program have been the beneficiaries of her wisdom and commitment. As a member of the CCU Advisory Committee, Dr. Dyson's counsel guided the implementation of a strategic plan for national expansion of the CCU, enabling its clown doctors to bring joy, laughter and wonder to bedsides of ever greater numbers of hospitalized children. That plan continues and has resulted in the Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit making nearly 180,000 annual bedside visits in 14 leading pediatric facilities across the nation. Dr. Dyson was a visionary leader, a powerful force for the care of children, and a good friend. We were inspired by her life's work for children and in her memory rededicate ourselves to our shared commitment to children and their families. We extend our sincerest condolences to her family and her colleagues. Paul Binder, Founder Michael Christensen, Co-Founder Gary Dunning, Executive Director
abstract: DYSON-Dr. Anne E. The Board of Directors, performers and staff of the Big Apple Circus mourn the passing of Dr. Anne E. Dyson, friend, colleague and inspiration. Over the last decade the Big Apple Circus and the Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit (CCU) Program have been the beneficiaries of her wisdom and commitment. As a member of the CCU Advisory Committee, Dr. Dyson's counsel guided the implementation of a strategic plan for national expansion of the CCU, enabling its clown doctors to bring joy, laughter and wonder to bedsides of ever greater numbers of hospitalized children. That plan continues and has resulted in the Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit making nearly 180,000 annual bedside visits in 14 leading pediatric facilities across the nation. Dr. Dyson was a visionary leader, a powerful force for the care of children, and a good friend. We were inspired by her life's work for children and in her memory rededicate ourselves to our shared commitment to children and their families. We extend our sincerest condolences to her family and her colleagues. Paul Binder, Founder Michael Christensen, Co-Founder Gary Dunning, Executive Director    DYSON-Anne, M.D. The Department of Pediatrics at Weill Medical College of Cornell University is deeply saddened by the passing of Anne Dyson. We were privileged to know her as a resident, faculty member, philanthropist, wise and valued counselor, and as a friend. Her advocacy for children has left an indelible mark on American medicine. Our thoughts are with her husband Michael, her sons Roberto and Mac, and her family and friends. Maria I. New, M.D., Chairman

snippet: R W Apple Jr analysis says Gov George W Bush will have only a shaky platform from which to begin his presidency, given the narrowness of his victory in Florida, the Electoral College and US Supreme Court; says it will require immense skill to remo...
lead_paragraph: Critics of the Food and Drug Administration have argued that the agency has been allowing drugs to be rushed into use since a 1992 law enabled speedier reviews. A case in point is that of Odell Buggs, a 28-year-old counselor who suffered a stroke that her doctors attributed to an ingredient in her over-the-counter decongestant, Tavist-D. She sued the manufacturer, the pharmaceutical giant Novartis A.G., saying its cold pills had left her with brain damage. Novartis, based in Switzerland, had a strong defense: the ingredient, phenylpropanolamine, or PPA, was in dozens of cold remedies, as well as appetite suppressants, and had been taken in billions of doses with no ill effects. The Buggs case offers a glimpse into how companies marketing PPA worked aggressively to assuage concerns about the safety of a drug that for six decades was a staple in American medicine cabinets.
abstract: R W Apple Jr analysis says Gov George W Bush will have only a shaky platform from which to begin his presidency, given the narrowness of his victory in Florida, the Electoral College and US Supreme Court; says it will require immense skill to remove the questions about Bush's legitimacy that are left hanging by court's failure to speak with the kind of clarion political voice that much of the nation hoped for (M)

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
abstract: To the Editor:    I learned to use Apple's iMovie software when we got our new Mac G4. Making movies out of our ''kid activities'' video has been the most fun, creative and satisfying activity I have used the computer for. I learned to use the program in one evening and by the end of the week had created four short movies about our summer activities. For some bizarre reason, Apple did not write a manual, so I have relied on ''iMovie: The Missing Manual'' by David Pogue.    LORI ROSENBERG  Short Hills, N.J.

lead_paragraph: Calendula Choices
abstract: Calendula Choices    Q.  When I lived in New Hampshire, I grew calendulas in my herb garden that were to die for. Now, we have moved near Washington and they just aren't performing well. I'm baffled and need your help, please, as these are among my favorite easy-to-grow annuals.    A.  Welcome to summer heat. Calendula, also called pot marigold, takes little effort to grow other than remembering to put it in full sun. But while it loves cool climates, in warmer areas it quits blooming in midsummer. If the selection you have has grown long and rangy, this is a perfect time to cut them back by a third to a half. As cool weather returns, they'll rebloom. When they start again, continue your religious devotion to deadheading so they will keep flowering cheerfully right until hard frost finally takes them.

snippet: Peter Thevenot of River Road Farms, nursery in Decatur, Tenn, keeps alive art of espalier, ancient and all but forgotten art of training fruit and ornamental trees to grow flat against a wall or fence, sometimes forming extravagant architectural s...
lead_paragraph: PETER THEVENOT, nurseryman and arborphile, calls himself ''a gnarly-bark guy.'' On a Saturday morning last October, he steered his pickup truck toward a lichen-covered river birch near the bank of Big Sewee Creek, which joins the Tennessee River on the edge of his 340-acre farm here. The birch's peeling bark was reddish-brown, tan and white, with the texture of parchment. ''Isn't that cool?'' Mr. Thevenot asked.

lead_paragraph: Chevron to Acquire Texaco In a $36 Billion Stock Deal
abstract: Chevron to Acquire Texaco In a $36 Billion Stock Deal  Chevron, the nation's third-largest oil company, has agreed to buy Texaco for $36 billion in stock, creating the world's fourth-largest oil concern. The company's boards approved the deal, which is expected to be announced today.    The acquisition is likely to come under intense scrutiny by regulators, who could force the combined company to divest itself of certain assets, especially in states like California where the company would dominate the retail gas station business. [Page A1.]

abstract: Apple Warns on Earnings, And Stock Falls After Hours  Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall far below estimates because of weak September sales. Shares of Apple, which had closed at $53.50, up $4.56, dropped as low as $28.25 in after-hours trading. [Page C2.]

lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Captain Bernier, who has just returned from a voyage in the Arctic region, declared here to-day that the Esquimaux of Greenland are the most advanced of the North Polar inhabitants as they have organized a legislative body and publish a newspaper. He also said that, contrary to general belief, the ice regions are not destitute of life, there being fish in the rivers and varied vegetation on the land. He found apples growing, he said, as far north as latitude 75.

snippet: Getty Petroleum Marketing refuses third buyout offer from United Refining Co and urges shareholders to back a bid by Lukoil Holding, of Russia (S)
lead_paragraph: Getty Petroleum Marketing Inc. dismissed a third offer by the United Refining Company yesterday and urged shareholders to back a bid by Lukoil Holding of Russia. Getty also said it would fight a New York lawsuit filed by United to block Lukoil's purchase. Getty, which has 1,300 gasoline stations in 13 Northeast and mid-Atlantic states, agreed last month to be acquired by Lukoil for $5 a share, or about $71 million. United's latest offer was for $6 a share, plus absorption of the $5 million breakup fee Getty would owe Lukoil for backing out of their agreement. United owns 303 Kwik Fill and Red Apple filling stations, mostly in New York and Pennsylvania, and a refinery in Warren, Pa., where it is based. Getty is based in Jericho, N.Y.

snippet: Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey uses tent with its new circus in Bryant Park, Barnum's Kaleidoscape; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: From 1919 until 1956, the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus performed primarily in tents. Then the tents were deemed too expensive to maintain, raise and move, and the circus began performing only in arenas. In the 70's, the Big Apple Circus proved tents were viable, even in New York City, and along came other one-ring tent shows (Cirque du Soleil, Zingaro) to prove it. So it seemed time for Ringling Brothers, too, to get back under canvas. This year it has raised a new circus tent in Bryant Park. Todd Dalland, a founder of FTL Happold of Manhattan, the tent's designers, said his company ''eliminated the side poles, the guy ropes and the stakes.'' Instead, the tent, filled with red plush velvet seats, is supported by a metal scaffolding system. The show, ''Barnum's Kaleidoscape,'' runs through Dec. 31.

snippet: Dell Computer plans to invest in Eazel Inc, developer of Linux software (S)
lead_paragraph: Dell Computer plans to make an investment in a small Silicon Valley developer of Linux software. The company, Eazel Inc., which was founded by three of the original members of the Apple Macintosh design team, has developed a program called Nautilus that is intended to make the Linux operating system more accessible to nonspecialist computer users. Besides the Nautilus software, Eazel has developed several commercial services, including a software catalog and an online data storage system. The company said it intended to simplify greatly the task of installing Linux and other open source software. Dell will include Eazel software and services with computers that it ships with the Linux operating system. Terms of the investment were not disclosed, but Eazel executives said the computer maker had made ''a significant investment'' in the company, based in Mountain View, Calif. It now has 70 employees and had previously raised $14 million. John Markoff (NYT)
abstract: Dell Computer plans to invest in Eazel Inc, developer of Linux software (S)

abstract: A Sporting Chance    Q. I have a 20-year-old euonymus plant whose leaves are green with an off-white border. Recently, I found three branches with solid green leaves -- and no border. What is the explanation?    A. There is no particular cause; it's just a matter of odds. If you grow enough variegated plants long enough, you're bound to see it happen sooner or later.

snippet: William Hill was delighted when he first heard about the digital video editing capabilities of the new Apple iMac DV. Mr. Hill, a 40-something actor in New York, was having trouble finding film roles, thanks in part to the Screen Actors Guild stri...
lead_paragraph: William Hill was delighted when he first heard about the digital video editing capabilities of the new Apple iMac DV. Mr. Hill, a 40-something actor in New York, was having trouble finding film roles, thanks in part to the Screen Actors Guild strike. He needed to edit his reel, the film equivalent of a résumé, but he figured that renting a digital editing suite and editor would cost him at least $150 an hour. In comparison, a new iMac DV would cost $999 to $1,499, about $100 more than a comparable iMac without video editing.

lead_paragraph: WIRTH-Morris A. The Partners, Counsel, Associates and Staff of Baer Marks & Upham LLP mourn the loss of our partner and friend after a brief battle against the ravages of cancer. Morris had a distinguished fifty-year career in the practice of law and was most readily identified with over thirtyfive years of legal representation of the State of Israel. Morris was a marvelous person, a student of the law, a teacher of the law to young colleagues at our office and a trusted friend and confidant. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Jean, his sons, Bobby, Billy and John, his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, Vasilia Hughes, and the apple of his eye, his grandson, Alec. We will miss him dearly.
abstract: WIRTH-Morris A. The Partners, Counsel, Associates and Staff of Baer Marks & Upham LLP mourn the loss of our partner and friend after a brief battle against the ravages of cancer. Morris had a distinguished fifty-year career in the practice of law and was most readily identified with over thirtyfive years of legal representation of the State of Israel. Morris was a marvelous person, a student of the law, a teacher of the law to young colleagues at our office and a trusted friend and confidant. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Jean, his sons, Bobby, Billy and John, his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, Vasilia Hughes, and the apple of his eye, his grandson, Alec. We will miss him dearly.     WIRTH-Morris A. For almost forty years, we have shared most things together, the good and the not so good. I will miss our daily contacts and your wonderful, but sometimes too long, stories. Most of all, I will miss you, my good friend and long-time partner. Our hearts go out to Jean, Bobby, Billy and John, Kelly, Lisa and Vasilia, and the apple of your eye, Alec, and to all those who will miss you, as we do. Suzanne and Don Bezahler

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Le Zinc in TriBeCa; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Parisians are used to the idea of the baby bistro. A well-known restaurant achieves popularity, then spins off a smaller, more casual version of itself. Not a twin but a place with recognizable family features. It's taken awhile, but David and Karen Waltuck, the owners of Chanterelle, have brought forth Le Zinc, an unbuttoned, budget-price restaurant just a few blocks from the parent restaurant. It looks like a college hangout with whitewashed walls and a few unframed posters advertising avant-garde films or artists. There's a pounding sound track and, of course, a zinc bar. Le Zinc takes no reservations.

snippet: Alice Thomas Ellis Food article on Welsh cooking; recipes; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Jack Ty Coch, who looks after my roof, fences, water supply and so forth, still eats brwes menyn, long a favorite of Welsh farmers. It consists of diced bread, a lump of butter, pepper and salt and a little boiling water. The bread, of course, should be homemade. The food writer Countess Morphy remarked regretfully in the 30's that ''the Welsh seem to have been particularly indifferent to the art of cooking. 'Tea and bread and butter' seems to be the national institution, and the amount of both which is consumed is amazing.'' Most of the cooking -- of scones, cakes, crempogau (Welsh pancakes) etc. -- was done on the bakestone, while meat, when the Welsh could afford it, was boiled with vegetables in a caldron over the fire.
abstract: Alice Thomas Ellis Food article on Welsh cooking; recipes; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: Aetna Agrees to Sell Units To ING for $5 Billion in Cash
abstract: Aetna Agrees to Sell Units To ING for $5 Billion in Cash  Aetna agreed to sell its international and financial services units to the ING Group of the Netherlands for $5 billion in cash, people close to the deal said.    Under the deal, which was to be announced before the opening of the stock markets in Europe today, Aetna will create a new health care company that will keep the name Aetna. ING will also assume $2.7 billion of Aetna's long-term debt. [Page C2.]    Giveaway Music Pays Off for Some  As the recording industry and commercial artists try to stamp out the distribution of copyrighted music for free in the form of computer files, tens of thousands of aspiring rock stars are happily using the technology to give their music away -- and more than a few are beginning to see some payoff. [A1.]

abstract: NEW YORK    MANHATTAN: APPLE TOURS CRITICIZED  The city's Consumer Affairs Department has accused New York Apple Tours of lying to customers since the bus company was ordered off the road. The department said Friday that Apple Tours employees have told tourists that Apple Tours was the same company as New York Double Decker Buses. Double Decker is a separate company. It agreed to honor Apple Tours tickets sold before the May 31 suspension of Apple Tours' license. The president of Apple Tours, Hayim Grant, above, denied the charge.   (AP)

lead_paragraph: WIRTH-Morris A. Surrounded by his wife Jean, sons Bob, Billy, and John, passed away peacefully on the morning of Saturday, August 12, after a brave battle with cancer. He was 76. In addition he is survived by his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, as well as Vasilia Hughes, and his most cherished grandson Alec. A lifelong resident of Manhattan and a prominent lawyer who represented Israeli interests in the U.S. for more than 35 years, Morris lived to help others. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM, Tuesday, August 15, at the Park Avenue Christian Church/ Universal Synagogue, 1010 Park Ave. Friends are also welcome at the interment service Tuesday at 3 PM, at the Westhampton Cemetery. ''So many dear friends-well wishers whose prayers will help and whose support of Jean and the kids is my greatest comfort.''
abstract: WIRTH-Morris A. Surrounded by his wife Jean, sons Bob, Billy, and John, passed away peacefully on the morning of Saturday, August 12, after a brave battle with cancer. He was 76. In addition he is survived by his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, as well as Vasilia Hughes, and his most cherished grandson Alec. A lifelong resident of Manhattan and a prominent lawyer who represented Israeli interests in the U.S. for more than 35 years, Morris lived to help others. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM, Tuesday, August 15, at the Park Avenue Christian Church/ Universal Synagogue, 1010 Park Ave. Friends are also welcome at the interment service Tuesday at 3 PM, at the Westhampton Cemetery. ''So many dear friends-well wishers whose prayers will help and whose support of Jean and the kids is my greatest comfort.''    WIRTH-Morris A. The Partners, Counsel, Associates and Staff of Baer Marks & Upham LLP mourn the loss of our partner and friend after a brief battle against the ravages of cancer. Morris had a distinguished fifty-year career in the practice of law and was most readily identified with over thirtyfive years of legal representation of the State of Israel. Morris was a marvelous person, a student of the law, a teacher of the law to young colleagues at our office and a trusted friend and confidant. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Jean, his sons, Bobby, Billy and John, his daughters-in-law, Kelly and Lisa, Vasilia Hughes, and the apple of his eye, his grandson, Alec. We will miss him dearly.    WIRTH-Morris A. For almost forty years, we have shared most things together, the good and the not so good. I will miss our daily contacts and your wonderful, but sometimes too long, stories. Most of all, I will miss you, my good friend and long-time partner. Our hearts go out to Jean, Bobby, Billy and John, Kelly, Lisa and Vasilia, and the apple of your eye, Alec, and to all those who will miss you, as we do. Suzanne and Don Bezahler

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIRTH, MORRIS A.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Chinoiserie restaurant at Hotel Giraffe in Manhattan; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: With shocking abruptness, Marc Murphy has made a culinary U-turn, leaving the refined French cooking of La Fourchette behind and taking up a new style that might be called designer Chinese. If the concept sounds murky, it finds appropriate lighting at Chinoiserie, a gloom-wrapped, ear-splitting new restaurant in the basement of the Hotel Giraffe. Square red fold-out menus are provided. Then comes the problem. How to read them. The small white candles floating in a cut-out pool in the center of each table shed much-needed light, but it takes steady hands to illuminate the menu without setting it ablaze.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Fernicola Osteria, Italian restaurant in Williamsburg, Brooklyn; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: FERNICOLA OSTERIA clings to the upper edge of Williamsburg like a climber to a sheer sheet of granite. Two steps to the north, a long, lonely industrial strip extends deep into Greenpoint. Out the front window, across Kent Avenue, a stark wooden fence runs along a scrubby stretch of riverfront park that attracts the braver kind of jogger. The restaurant, a 100-year-old tavern, sheds a warm, hospitable light onto a cold-looking street. It seems a million miles away from the big city across the river, whose pinpoint lights glitter like an artificial galaxy.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK
abstract: NEW YORK    MANHATTAN: MEETING CLOSED TO SOME  The police kept two dozen Bronx residents from attending a meeting of the City Council's land use committee yesterday. The officers feared the residents were about to enter City Hall to begin a demonstration, said Sunny Mindel, a spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. The group wanted to attend an open meeting on 10 community gardens on city-owned Bronx lots that might be taken over to make way for housing. The residents had gathered in City Hall Park and unfurled a purple banner that read ''Save Our Gardens.'' A vote on the lots was delayed.    (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Mariza Caraveo Najera and Jonathan Goodman Cohen were married yesterday evening at the Windsor Court Hotel in New Orleans. Cantor Joel Colman perfromed the ceremony.
abstract: Mariza Caraveo Najera and Jonathan Goodman Cohen were married yesterday evening at the Windsor Court Hotel in New Orleans. Cantor Joel Colman perfromed the ceremony.    The bride, 33, is the managing director in Merida, Mexico, for Mayan Art, a Miami-based jewelry manufacturing company. She will continue to be known as Ms. Caraveo professionally. She is the daughter of Yolanda Najera de Caraveo and Ramon Caraveo of Juarez, Mexico. Her father owns La Laguna, a cattle ranch and apple farm near Cuauhtemoc, Mexico.

lead_paragraph: Q. I have impaired vision and find that the white background and black type used in Microsoft Word documents is hard on my eyes. Is there any way to change the background color of the documents for easier reading?
abstract: Q. I have impaired vision and find that the white background and black type used in Microsoft Word documents is hard on my eyes. Is there any way to change the background color of the documents for easier reading?    A. Yes, there is a setting within Microsoft Word that will let you create and use documents that have a dark blue background with white text on the screen. You may find that combination easier to read, and your files will still print normally.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Sixteen visiting German soccer players were pelted with apples and tomatoes by demonstrators as the athletes posed for pictures on the steps of City Hall. The demonstrators' spokesman said the German team was similar to the sports associations Adolf Hitler "used to build up his armies." As the Germans lined up, the demonstrators converged from two directions, and threw pamphlets into the air. Others carrying cartons of tomatoes and apples started throwing the overripe produce.

snippet: Paul Krugman column says Bill Gates, who is stepping down as Microsoft's chief executive officer, was able to push aside IBM and Apple Computer and dominate the new electronic economy because he realized importance of 'network externalities,' the ...
lead_paragraph: So Bill Gates is stepping down -- or up, or sideways, or something -- from his position as C.E.O. of Microsoft. Nobody seems to think that this will make much difference either to the way Microsoft is run or to the desire of the Justice Department to break up the world's most valuable company and humble its founder. But maybe the announcement provides a good occasion to reflect on the achievements of this elder statesman (44 years old!) of the New Economy.

snippet: Frank J Prial comments on granita, coarse-textured ice dessert made from fruit juice or espresso; recipe for apple granita with calvados photo (S)
lead_paragraph: IT all started with a Champagne sorbet I had at Lutece a few weeks ago. Compared with the complicated, swooping, architectural desserts so much in vogue in top restaurants, the sorbet was elegant and understated. It reminded me of a dessert I like to order in Paris: a granite des pommes, with Calvados. It, too, is simple and memorable: three scoops of apple granita flavored (''baptized,'' some French waiters say) with an ounce or two of apple brandy.

Young merry-makers have colonized the lounge of the W Union Square Hotel, but the clusters of sofas and settees are only the outer perimeter. Next the bar must be negotiated. snippet: William Grimes article, in series En Route, describes centuries-old tradition of vinegar making in Sologne region of France; photos of fermentation and aging procedures at Martin-Pouret factory in Orleans; map (M)
lead_paragraph: THE easy way to find the Martin-Pouret vinegar factory is to sniff. You might expect a billboard or a colorful sign advertising France's last remaining traditional vinegar-maker, but there isn't one. Instead, a sharp, unmistakable aroma, powerful enough to penetrate a rolled-up car window, broadcasts the Martin-Pouret address. It sits, as it has for more than two centuries, on Faubourg Bannier, a busy commercial street on the northern fringes of this ancient city on the Loire, although now it is surrounded by auto dealerships, warehouses and railroad tracks.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK
abstract: NEW YORK    MANHATTAN: LAZIO'S TAX RETURNS -- Calling reports of Representative Rick A. Lazio's stock profits ''deeply troubling,'' the chairwoman of the New York State Democratic Committee, Judith Hope, challenged the Republican Senate candidate yesterday to release his income tax returns. The New York Times reported on Friday that Mr. Lazio had made a 600 percent profit on stock he bought in 1997 in Quick & Reilly, a brokerage controlled by some of his campaign contributors. A spokesman said Mr. Lazio would release his returns ''as soon as possible.''   Eric Lipton (NYT)    MANHATTAN: GRAVANO ALLEGATION -- Salvatore Gravano, left, the Mafia turncoat who testified against John J. Gotti, plotted to kill Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer who represents the survivors of some of Mr. Gravano's murder victims, according to court papers. Mr. Gravano, whose ferocity earned him the nickname Sammy the Bull and who left New York under the cloak of the federal witness protection program to start a new life, was arrested in Arizona in February on charges that he was running a multimillion-dollar drug ring.   William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

snippet: Jacob E Goldman Op-Ed article rejects Microsoft Corp's assertion that government antitrust initiatives against it will stifle innovation; says company's dominance of personal computer software market is not due to its own innovation, but rather to...
lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, protesting the government's antitrust initiatives against Microsoft, has asserted from the first that limiting the scope of his company's activities or breaking it up would stifle the innovation that helped Microsoft catalyze the information revolution into existence. The incongruity of this response to the Justice Department's pleadings and Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's decision is inescapable: Microsoft soared to its powerful heights on the backs of innovations that were largely the work of others.

snippet: Lisa Anne Abend travel essay recalls her college junior year in Spain when she met young Spaniard and learned gestures but not attitude of flamenco dancing; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: I WAS drunk the first time I danced flamenco, which helped considerably. It was 15 years ago, and I had recently arrived in southern Spain, one of 30 or so American college girls well primed for the modest adventure of a junior year abroad. It was October, and the heat that turns the streets of Cordoba to molten tar had only recently subsided, so that we were just beginning to recognize the beauty of that city's winding alleyways and flowering balconies. We would walk the mile to school each day in small, chattering groups, past shopkeepers who did not yet know our names but who recognized us for what we were: that year's crop of americanas.

snippet: This warm, funny, inventive documentary is both a diary and a kind of extended essay on poverty, thrift and the curious place of scavenging in French history and culture. Agnes Varda, an intrepid woman in her early 70's and one of the bravest and ...
lead_paragraph: ''The Gleaners and I'' takes its title, and some of its inspiration, from an 1867 painting by Jean-Francois Millet that shows three women in a wheat field, stooping to pick up sheaves and kernels left behind after the harvest. The image is well known; it appears in the Larousse Dictionary of the French Language alongside the definition of the verb ''glaner'' (to glean). The painting itself, which hangs in the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, shows up early in Agnes Varda's wonderful new documentary, thronged by camera-wielding tourists.
abstract: This warm, funny, inventive documentary is both a diary and a kind of extended essay on poverty, thrift and the curious place of scavenging in French history and culture. Agnes Varda, an intrepid woman in her early 70's and one of the bravest and most idiosyncratic of French filmmakers, spent eight months traveling through France recording the lives of people who gather what others have thrown away or left behind. Varda's gleaners retain a resilient, generous humanity, which is clearly brought to the surface by her own tough, open spirit. The film is studded with found metaphors and serendipitous insights. — A. O. Scott

lead_paragraph: Articles on the mapping of the human genome discuss some of the benefits and possible dangers of this research, but no one really knows how this knowledge will affect humans and human evolution. Humanity's capacity to understand and potentially manipulate its genetic composition has as much potential for evil as for good. And, of course, how one measures the relative amounts of these depends entirely on one's definition of "evil" and "good." Who will make the decision?

lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:
abstract: DEAR DIARY:        My 10-year-old son wanted some help dressing one morning.     ''Mom,'' he began, ''what should I wear with my Nike pants?''    ''Why don't you wear the blue Adidas top, honey?'' I answered. ''They're the same color; they'd look nice together.''    ''No way,'' he told me in an exasperated tone. ''That would be cross-dressing.''    I made sure we had another birds-and-the-bees talk as we walked to the bus stop.   Pat Olsen

snippet: M H Reed reviews Spaccarelli's restaurant in Millwood, NY; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: PATRONS of the old Spaccarelli's, a shabby place in the A.&P. shopping strip here, have probably seen its brand new structure just around the corner. The restaurant has been reinvented as a contemporary spot, with gauzy curtains covering a sweep of glass on one wall and a honeycomb stacked with wine bottles on another. Subtle lighting and dusty rose walls make the room glow. Although still a neighborhood eatery, it's not the Spaccarelli's we remember, and hooray for that.

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Mamlouk, Middle Eastern restaurant in East Village; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: All over New York multiple sins have been committed in the name of baba gannouj. Hummus has been subjected to unspeakable acts. Right off the bat, Mamlouk deserves praise for restoring luster to these Middle Eastern staples. The hummus has no tricks up its sleeve other than fresh ingredients mixed in the proper proportions and a texture that's pure satin. The same goes for the wonderfully smoky baba gannouj, sprinkled with a few jewel-like pomegranate seeds. These two classics made up only two-fifths of the first course in Mamlouk's set menu the night I ate there. They were joined by a puree of red bell peppers thickened with ground walnuts, a salsalike avocado salad and a sweet, syrupy mound of grilled marinated bell peppers.

Waterman    GORDON-Edward S. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of one of its founders, Edward S. Gordon. The father of Robin Gordon Apple, a distinguished member of NJOP's Board of Directors. Mr. Gordon was a tower of strength and wisdom for NJOP, providing critcial financial support and wise counsel throughout NJOP's existence. NJOP's success in its mission to provide every North American Jew with a basic Jewish education can be attributed directly to his efforts on NJOP's behalf. Condolences to his wife Cheryl, mother Laura, daughter Robin (and Stephen) Apple and family, son Kenneth and brother Allan who have all joined Mr. Gordon in support of NJOP's vital work. Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.    GORDON-Edward S. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York are deeply saddened by loss of Ed. He was a man of strong principle, a leader in our industry, admired and respected by all. A dedicated Vice President of the Foundation, always supportive of our goals and beliefs. We send our sincerest condolencess to his family, colleagues and friends. Larry A. Silverstein, Chairman Jerry L. Cohen, President Officers and Directors    GORDON-Edward S. We respectfully offer our most sincere condolences to Ed's family, friends, and associates, with whom we have been both close friends and a frequent competitor for more that 30 years. Ed brought passion and intensity to everything he did, whether it was business, leisure or philanthropic. Ed's mark on this city, this profession and on everyone he touched, will endure for many decades. The Cohen, Carmel and Roos Families and GVA Williams    GORDON-Edward S. You will be missed and remembered. Our sincerest condolences to Cheryl, Ken, Robin & Steve, Alan and the grandchildren. You will live in our memories. Now, it's called Saracen, a restaurant that celebrates the food of Southern Italy and Sicily, those Mediterranean crossroads where so many groups, including the Saracens, left their mark.

lead_paragraph: VARIOUS ARTISTS: ''Heroes and Villains: Music Inspired by the Powerpuff Girls'' (Rhino/Cartoon Network). Those mutant X-Men are confronting all comers at the box office, but there are champions much tougher than that movie's confused adolescent, Rogue. The Powerpuff Girls, created by Craig McCracken for the Cartoon Network, give young viewers a taste of unequivocal female punch. Buttercup, Bubbles and Blossom talk like the Chipmunks, chew gum, think fast and defeat baddies like the monkey Mojo Jojo without mussing the bows in their hair.

lead_paragraph: I WENT to Colonial Williamsburg not long ago. snippet: Article on prefabricated metal sheds designed by Bryan Bell, founder of nonprofit Design Corp, which is dedicated to designing better housing for migrant workers; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: DOMINGO RODRIGUEZ, in after-shower boxers and a T-shirt, appeared fresh even after nine hours of apple picking. While a stereo played Spanish music, the lacy window curtains fluttered and the bistec sizzled under the broiler, Mr. Rodriguez, a migrant worker, gave a tour of the modest 810-square-foot house he shares with Alain Leon Burgos. He reveled in its comforts as if it were a fine hotel. Mr. Rodriguez and Mr. Burgos are part of a six-man crew that came up from Puerto Rico in June to help harvest 400 acres of apples and 200 acres of peaches at Bream Orchards, in the fruit-picking heartland of Pennsylvania near Gettysburg.

snippet: William Grimes reviews City Eatery, restaurant on Bowery; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE French have two very useful adjectives at hand when they like a restaurant: honest and correct. The words don't sound like much in English, but in French, honnete and correct have a certain resonance, implying sound technique, respect for ingredients and clearly expressed flavors. The English equivalent might be ''solid.'' A fanciful writer might describe a correct, honest restaurant as having the right stuff.

snippet: Chrysler Design Awards for 2000 go to Will Bruder, Ted Muehling, Gary Panter, David M Kelley, James Corner and Paula Scher; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: DESIGN being used as a marketing tool? Hardly shocking. In the 1980's, Chrysler, now DaimlerChrysler, got a leg up on the competition by making design history with its minivan; this year it was the company's bulbous retro PT Cruiser with the getaway-car fenders. Chrysler also came up with the Chrysler Design Awards in 1993, dedicated to sussing out innovators in the fields of architecture, environmental design, electronic media and graphic and industrial design. The winners, announced this week, each receive a trophy and $10,000.

lead_paragraph: IT was not exactly what I expected to see on entering Polanka, a Polish-American restaurant in Lower Manhattan. A D.J. with a rig the size of a Volkswagen was just inside the entrance, spinning soul tunes from the 60's and 70's. At the bar, women were grooving in their seats, singing the words to ''Lean on Me'' as if they were several drinks into their high school reunion. And as we sat down, a waitress greeted us as if the bouncing and singing were part of the furniture.

lead_paragraph: Reports by I.B.M. and Intel Lead to a Slide in Stocks
abstract: Reports by I.B.M. and Intel Lead to a Slide in Stocks  Disappointment with first-quarter reports from I.B.M. and Intel helped send stocks lower, ending the two-day surge after last week's sell-off. The dot-com stocks that have fallen so sharply recently were down again.    The Nasdaq composite index fell 87.16 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,706.41, while the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 92.46 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,674.96. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 14.1 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 1,427.47. [Page C12.]

snippet: Stonwin Farm, estate of late jeweler Harry Winston in Scarsdale, NY, is put on market for $27 million; broker Patricia Burnham, says she already has five potential buyers (S)
lead_paragraph: Stonwin Farm, the 15-acre Scarsdale estate of the late jewelry legend Harry Winston, went on the market Wednesday for $27 million, and the broker for the property, Patricia Burnham, said she already had five potential buyers. The estate has eight and a half bathrooms, a pool, tennis courts, stables and its own gas pump. It has been in the Winston family for 60 years and is being sold by Mr. Winston's son, Ronald, president of Harry Winston Inc. ''It is the cherry orchard with apple trees,'' he said, explaining how he agonized about the sale by recalling the Chekhov play about a family's angst in selling its cherry orchard. AL BAKER
abstract: Stonwin Farm, estate of late jeweler Harry Winston in Scarsdale, NY, is put on market for $27 million; broker Patricia Burnham, says she already has five potential buyers (S)

snippet: Eric Asimov comments on genuine Chablis; map; recommends several (S)
lead_paragraph: ANY time you think you've got a grape figured out, along comes a wine that knocks it out of its pigeonhole. The best chardonnays, for example, whether from California or Burgundy or even Australia, tend to be rich and creamy, full of exotic flavors buttressed by sensations of toasty vanilla and butter that are induced by aging in oak barrels. Then there's Chablis, one of my favorite wines and an exception to most other wines made from the chardonnay grape.

lead_paragraph: These are edgy days at the Union Square Greenmarket, where more than 100 farmers come in from the countryside, four days a week, to sell their produce, cheese and baked goods. Since a petition objecting to looming construction projects on the square was circulated on Dec. 9, worrisome rumors have been flying. lead_paragraph: IT was only a matter of time before someone put quote marks around the old-fashioned American steakhouse. Strip House is not so much a steakhouse as a catalog of hip references to the idea of a steakhouse, a kind of restaurant that really has no natural place in the heart of Greenwich Village. Without the quotes, Strip House would be naked.
abstract: IT was only a matter of time before someone put quote marks around the old-fashioned American steakhouse. Strip House is not so much a steakhouse as a catalog of hip references to the idea of a steakhouse, a kind of restaurant that really has no natural place in the heart of Greenwich Village. Without the quotes, Strip House would be naked.    As the name suggests, there's a burlesque theme hard at work here. The omnipresent David Rockwell has lined the walls with lust-red flocked wallpaper and upholstered the banquettes in quilted red leather. Vintage photographs of old-time strippers cover the walls, spicing up the mix of opera singers and 20-watt celebrities from a bygone era, left over from the days when the restaurant was Asti's. It all makes for a cheery, comfortable atmosphere, with none of the backslapping locker-room style of the old-line steakhouses, where big men take off their jackets, roll up their sleeves and get down to the business of eating big, unadorned slabs of beef. Strip House is a steakhouse for sissies, which means I can eat there without feeling like the second-string water boy.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK
abstract: NEW YORK    MANHATTAN: BUS WORKERS PROTEST  A small group of New York Apple Tours workers gathered at City Hall yesterday to protest the shutdown of their double-decker bus tour company on Wednesday. Meanwhile, hundreds of people with tickets for Apple tours gathered outside the company's Midtown office to demand refunds. Officials at Gray Line, another tour company, said they were accepting New York Apple tickets. The State Department of Motor Vehicles suspended the registrations of all 63 Apple Tours buses after a pedestrian was struck and killed by one of the vehicles last week.  Jayson Blair (NYT)

lead_paragraph: HERE is a grape with an identity crisis: In France it is known as pinot gris, except in Alsace, the French region where the grape reaches its zenith and is called tokay. In Italy, it is pinot grigio, a straight enough translation, but in Valais, a Swiss wine-growing region between France and Italy, it is known as malvoisie. Other aliases are auxerrois gris, rulander and szurkebarat.

snippet: Brief reviews of movies on television this week; photos (S)
lead_paragraph: BOY meets girl, girl turns out to be lesbian, and - this is the odd part - they fall in love anyhow. Ben Affleck, who was not such a huge star three and a half years ago, is the charming, boyish hero of CHASING AMY (1997), and Joey Lauren Adams is the sexy-voiced blonde of his dreams. The film is a smart, spare, quick-witted comedy that treats sexual orientation as just one more complication in the course of modern true love. Kevin Smith wrote and directed, so there are a number of conversational riffs that are thoroughly unrelated to the plot and highly entertaining - Friday at 10:05 p.m. on Starz.

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Wallse, new Austrian restaurant in West Village; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Among other things, Danube has taught New York that quark is a cheese as well as a subatomic particle. This is not useless information, certainly not at Wallse, Kurt Gutenbrunner's very appealing little Austrian restaurant in the far West Village, where a quark dumpling with red-currant-stuffed apricot halves leads the list of homey sweets. It's been a long wait for Mr. Gutenbrunner, an Austrian who once cooked at the renowned Tantris in Vienna and was David Bouley's original choice to run the kitchen at Danube. When that project seemed to be stalled, he decided to open his own place.

snippet: Editorial says aviation deal negotiated by Pres Clinton and Chinese Prime Min Zhu Ronghi in April 1999 is so restrictive that it forces Transportation Dept to pick between cargo and passenger carriers in awarding 10 new weekly flights to China; sa...
lead_paragraph: As the Senate takes up permanent normal trade relations with China, the Department of Transportation is on the verge of awarding an additional United States carrier the valuable right to fly to that nation. Lamentably, the aviation deal negotiated by President Clinton and Zhu Rongji, China's prime minister, in April 1999 does not reflect the spirit of the trade agreement. It is so restrictive that the Transportation Department, for the first time ever in such a bilateral route-awarding proceeding, is being forced to pick between cargo and passenger carriers. Chinese negotiators refused to differentiate between the two.
abstract: Editorial says aviation deal negotiated by Pres Clinton and Chinese Prime Min Zhu Ronghi in April 1999 is so restrictive that it forces Transportation Dept to pick between cargo and passenger carriers in awarding 10 new weekly flights to China; says that with advent of normalized trade relations, issue should be revisited and greater access to China should be demanded for both cargo and passengers

lead_paragraph: RETIREMENT was the chance to get away: After leaving Campbell Soup, David W. Johnson had been enjoying life by climbing Mount Kilimanjaro. Thomas L. Gossage, who had left Hercules Inc., was living in Atlanta and serving on a few corporate boards. And Henry B. Schacht had traded his responsibilities as chief executive of the gigantic Lucent Technologies for a post as chairman of a much smaller maker of office communications equipment spun off from Lucent.
abstract: RETIREMENT was the chance to get away: After leaving Campbell Soup, David W. Johnson had been enjoying life by climbing Mount Kilimanjaro. Thomas L. Gossage, who had left Hercules Inc., was living in Atlanta and serving on a few corporate boards. And Henry B. Schacht had traded his responsibilities as chief executive of the gigantic Lucent Technologies for a post as chairman of a much smaller maker of office communications equipment spun off from Lucent.    But recently, these men have all been summoned back to the companies they once headed. Other returnees include Paul A. Allaire at Xerox and John E. Pepper, who came back to Procter & Gamble as chairman. While they are expected to hold the top jobs only temporarily, they all face serious challenges: strategies gone badly wrong, bitter earnings disappointments and impatient and angry investors.
