byline.original: By Mitchell Martin, International Herald Tribune

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    LAST NIGHT A DJ SAVED MY LIFE: The History of the Disc Jockey, by Bill Brewster and Frank Broughton. (Grove, paper, $14.) A lively account of the unsung heroes of popular music, the club D.J.'s who in their enthusiasm and their technical competence developed the ears of nearly everyone else and led the music almost everywhere it has gone.    AN OBEDIENT FATHER, by Akhil Sharma. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) The main narrator in this novel by a New York investment banker is a low, corrupt functionary in the Delhi school system. It's easy to brand him despicable because he is, but his power to do ill is limited, his personality complex and his author compassionate.    A HOLE IN THE EARTH, by Robert Bausch. (Harcourt, $24.) Bausch's fourth novel concerns Henry Porter, 39, the sole flop in a family of successes, whose fixation in preternatural adolescence is mitigated by his own humiliations and the kindness of others.    JEW VS. JEW: The Struggle for the Soul of American Jewry, by Samuel G. Freedman. (Simon & Schuster, $26.) A journalism professor, once a reporter for The Times, explores the frictions that have risen in America, especially between the Orthodox and the less Orthodox, and envisions a possible future in which religion alone will be the determinant of who is Jewish and who not.    THE SECRET PARTS OF FORTUNE: Three Decades of Intense Investigations and Edgy Enthusiasms, by Ron Rosenbaum. (Random House, $29.95.) A generous collection of journalism by a writer who has exposed himself to many of the great obsessions of the 20th century without losing his curiosity, his skepticism or his willingness to listen.    I LOVED YOU ALL, by Paula Sharp. (Hyperion, $23.95.) An old-fashioned storytelling novel about the escalating defiance of hard-line anti-abortionists in the 1970's; the leading character (on the side that is clearly not the author's) has the depth and energy to become indispensable to people whose lives or children are out of control.    THE RULES OF ENGAGEMENT, by Catherine Bush. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A novel with the nerve to use war as a metaphor for the travails of love; its protagonist, a graduate in war studies, has fled Canada after two men fought a duel over her.    SISTER: The Life of the Legendary American Interior Decorator Mrs. Henry Parish II, by Apple Parish Bartlett and Susan Bartlett Crater. (St. Martin's, $35.) An oral history, compiled by the daughter and granddaughter of the aristocrat who went into the decorating business in 1933 and lived a life characterized by robust frivolity and hard work.    BLOOD OF THE LIBERALS, by George Packer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Liberalism, under one or another definition, is the force that shaped and eventually failed the author's grandfather (a Congressman from Alabama), his father (a legal scholar and student of procedure) and himself (once a Peace Corps volunteer, now a writer).

snippet: HARDWARE SONY CHOOSES TRANSMETA CHIP Sony said yesterday that it would use computer memory chips made by the Transmeta Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., in one of its popular models of laptop computers. Sony is a major customer of Intel, the dom...
lead_paragraph: HARDWARE SONY CHOOSES TRANSMETA CHIP Sony said yesterday that it would use computer memory chips made by the Transmeta Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., in one of its popular models of laptop computers. Sony is a major customer of Intel, the dominant maker of computer memory chips. But it said it would equip the CI model of its Vaio line of laptops with Transmeta's central processing units, which offer more effective power saving. Sony said the chip was a good fit for the Vaio CI, since it is designed as a go-anywhere computer with a built-in video camera. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

snippet: Garden Conservancy, dedicated to making privte gardens public, will open eight gardens in New Jersey on May 13 and 20 and June 10 and 23; drawing (By the Way column) (S)
lead_paragraph: It's perhaps more acceptable to peek through a neighbor's garden gate than through a window, but the furtiveness is often still there. The curious can stare all they like May 13 and 20 and June 10 at 23 private gardens in New Jersey as part of the Garden Conservancy's Open Days Program. The group, dedicated to making private gardens public, opens about 400 gardens nationwide each year, and the $4 admission fee often goes to the organization and other nonprofits or charities. On May 13, eight gardens will be display; among them will be a cottage garden in Oldwick, a riverside garden in Rumson with espaliered apple trees and a vegetable garden and a spot in Atlantic Highlands, with a view of Sandy Hook Bay and lower Manhattan. On May 20, gardens in Califon and Stanton will be on view and on June 10, 17 gardens will be open (some of them repeats). For information, call (888) 842-2442 or visit www.gardenconservancy.org.

lead_paragraph: LONG ago, before most of us spent far too much time sitting around airports, people actually went there for entertainment, for the thrill of watching planes take off and land when the jet age was still young. They might even have dinner at places like the Newarker, a white-tablecloth ''destination restaurant'' that opened at Newark Airport in 1953. Known for its large portions, its Absecon oysters and its propensity for serving food theatrically flambe, the Newarker became a cornerstone of the Restaurant Associates empire before it closed in 1973.

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    LEFT BACK: A Century of Failed School Reforms, by Diane Ravitch. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) An education expert who has often run with conservatives argues that 20th-century ''progressive'' theorists watered down education for non-elites in the name of ''life adjustment'' and other slogans, depriving those very groups of the knowledge to help them rise.    THE GENTLEMAN FROM NEW YORK. Daniel Patrick Moynihan: A Biography, by Godfrey Hodgson. (Houghton Mifflin, $38.) A life of the right's favorite liberal, or the left's favorite neocon, always intelligent, usually correct and at peace with his impending retirement; by a British journalist and friend.    KHOMEINI: Life of the Ayatollah, by Baqer Moin. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $27.95.) An Iranian (and former Muslim seminarian) gives a deft account of the background and rise to power of the gifted, shrewd cleric and politician who destroyed Iran's monarchy and forever changed the course of its history.    AN OBEDIENT FATHER, by Akhil Sharma. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) The main narrator in this novel by a New York investment banker is a low, corrupt functionary in the Delhi school system. It's easy to brand him despicable because he is, but his power to do ill is limited, his personality complex and his author compassionate.    BLOOD OF THE LIBERALS, by George Packer. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Liberalism, under one or another definition, is the force that shaped and eventually failed the author's grandfather (a Congressman from Alabama), his father (a legal scholar and student of procedure) and himself (once a Peace Corps volunteer, now a writer, and though bloodied not yet totally bowed).    A HOLE IN THE EARTH, by Robert Bausch. (Harcourt, $24.) Bausch's fourth novel concerns Henry Porter, 39, the sole flop in a family of successes, whose fixation in preternatural adolescence is mitigated by his own humiliations and the kindness of others.    THE SECRET PARTS OF FORTUNE: Three Decades of Intense Investigations and Edgy Enthusiasms, by Ron Rosenbaum. (Random House, $29.95.) A generous collection of journalism by a writer who has exposed himself to many of the great obsessions of the 20th century without losing his curiosity, his skepticism or his willingness to listen.    I LOVED YOU ALL, by Paula Sharp. (Hyperion, $23.95.) An old-fashioned storytelling novel about the escalating defiance of hard-line anti-abortionists in the 1970's; the leading character (on the side that is clearly not the author's) has the depth and energy to become indispensable to people whose lives or children are out of control.    SISTER: The Life of the Legendary American Interior Decorator Mrs. Henry Parish II, by Apple Parish Bartlett and Susan Bartlett Crater. (St. Martin's, $35.) An oral history, compiled by the daughter and granddaughter of the formidably descended aristocrat who went into the decorating business in 1933 and lived a life characterized by robust frivolity and hard work.

snippet: Thomas C Guy Jr, who has made documentaries on black history subjects, answers questions about video documentary he is making about Bordentown Manual and Training School, former residential school for black high school students now owned by state ...
lead_paragraph: The former campus of the Bordentown Manual and Training School, a residential school for black high school students in Burlington County, is now owned by the state. Some of the buildings, dating to 1886 when the school was founded, are used by the Department of Corrections to house juvenile offenders, but most are vacant and sinking into disrepair. The current condition of the school belies the impact it had on black education in New Jersey and beyond. Thomas C. Guy Jr., who has made a number of documentaries on black history topics, talked about a video documentary he is making about the Bordentown school. He is still searching for people with connections to it; he can be reached at tcgjr@aol.com

lead_paragraph: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
abstract: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    A PLACE IN THE COUNTRY, by Laura Shaine Cunningham. (Riverhead, $24.95.) Years of fruitless wishing for the great good place finally paid off for the author with a gracious old house upstate; her wisdom is shown by acknowledging that snakes and bad neighbors go with the territory just as flowers and moonbeams do.    SYDNEY: The Story of a City, by Geoffrey Moorhouse. (Harcourt, $25.) A virtuoso exposition of Sydney and the social history that has formed it, from the first Europeans and the British convicts through the gold rushes to the variety of today's Asian immigrants.    A RUM AFFAIR: A True Story of Botanical Fraud, by Karl Sabbagh. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.) A grave and witty account of a British amateur botanist who in the late 1940's caught a professor faking evidence to suit his theory about the last ice age and the Hebridean island of Rum, then sealed his report of the fraud in his college library (it leaked anyhow).    SISTER: The Life of the Legendary American Interior Decorator Mrs. Henry Parish II, by Apple Parish Bartlett and Susan Bartlett Crater. (St. Martin's, $35.) An oral history, compiled by the daughter and granddaughter of the formidably descended aristocrat who went into the decorating business in 1933 and lived a life characterized by robust frivolity and lots of hard work.    THE QUESTION OF BRUNO, by Aleksandar Hemon. (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $22.95.) Mostly fictional (but who can say for sure?) stories and a novella, invoking both the terrible facts of Bosnia and Yugoslavia and the years of the author's childhood, when there was yet hope for both.    THE GENTLEMAN FROM NEW YORK. Daniel Patrick Moynihan: A Biography, by Godfrey Hodgson. (Houghton Mifflin, $38.) A life of the right's favorite liberal, or the left's favorite neocon, always intelligent, usually correct and at peace with his impending retirement; by a British journalist and longtime friend.    DREAM STUFF: Stories, by David Malouf. (Pantheon, $22.) Australia, in the short fiction of this collection, is a place of surprises and changing potential where history itself is sometimes in question and characters protest against loss, though the author seems to assure us that nothing is lost forever.    THE LOST LEGENDS OF NEW JERSEY, by Frederick Reiken. (Harcourt, $24.) The drama of sheer ordinariness receives its celebration in this novel set in northern New Jersey about 1980; the Jewish and Italian families who inhabit it struggle (especially the teenagers) for both stability and poetry.    TOUCHING PEACE: From the Oslo Accord to a Final Agreement, by Yossi Beilin. (Weidenfeld/Trafalgar Square, $50.) Israel's chief negotiator at Oslo and Stockholm gives a personal account of the secret talks with the P.L.O. that outlined the probable shape of any future Middle East peace, regardless of the outcome of the recent Barak-Arafat-Clinton meetings at Camp David.

snippet: Unusual bar stools at Pierrot bistro noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)
lead_paragraph: The screwdrivers are strong and the gimlets agreeable at Pierrot, an East Village bistro, but visitors are less besotted by the cocktails than by the bar stools, which are made from John Deere tractor seats. ''They're a popular topic of conversation,'' Brian White, Pierrot's owner, said of the humped, 18-gauge steel seats. ''Although women like them a lot more than men.'' (It's that hump.) Bob Perry, who designed the seats, is fond of using farm and garden equipment in his work. He has constructed stools made from shovels for the Malaysian restaurant Penang in SoHo.

lead_paragraph: IT'S easy to forget what a skillful work Robert Zemeckis's FORREST GUMP (1994) is. Six years later, the special effects (from the hero, chatting with presidents to Gary Sinise's amputated legs) don't seem so amazing, but Tom Hanks's gut-level sincerity in the title role does. This is the story of a simple man's life, his love for one woman (Robin Wright, who is lovely as the emotionally bruised Jenny) and his encounters with Elivs, J.F.K., Bear Bryant, Dick Cavett, the Black Panthers, Vietnam, shrimp boats, Apple Computer stock and long-distance running. ''Forrest Gump'' won six Oscars, including best picture, best actor and best director, and it proved that an I.Q. of 75 and a good heart can get big cosmic free-for-all. You decide -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Channel 7.

lead_paragraph: IF flora were the focus of our critical purview, we would certainly cite the bouquets at Underhills Crossing as among the loveliest of any we have seen: coolly elegant pastels in silver julep cups on every table, brilliant sunbursts of color at the edge of the bar. Unfortunately, care for the diner's comfort is considerably less than the care lavished on nosegays.
abstract: IF flora were the focus of our critical purview, we would certainly cite the bouquets at Underhills Crossing as among the loveliest of any we have seen: coolly elegant pastels in silver julep cups on every table, brilliant sunbursts of color at the edge of the bar. Unfortunately, care for the diner's comfort is considerably less than the care lavished on nosegays.    Mirrors seem to augment the small space of this handsome, extremely narrow restaurant. But the effect vanishes at peak meal times, not only when one is seated at small, closely packed tables and surrounded by the din from equally closely packed diners but also, and especially, when the place fills with both tobacco smoke and patrons waiting for tables.

snippet: Charlie Saggese, social worker and program coordinator, answers questions about High Point Farm, working farm and retreat staffed by members of Fountain House, nonresidential center in New York City for adults with persistent mental illnesses; pho...
lead_paragraph: High Point Farm is a working farm in the extreme northwestern corner of the state next to High Point State Park. But unlike other farms, this 477-acre tract is a retreat that is staffed by members of Fountain House in New York City, a treatment center for adults with persistent mental illnesses. The farm will be open to the public to tour the grounds and view the fall foliage from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Oct. 21 and 22 and Oct. 28 and 29. Charlie Saggese, a social worker and program coordinator for High Point Farm, recently talked about Fountain House.

lead_paragraph: The ice cream mix-ins at the new Petrossian Cafe and Boutique, 911 Seventh Avenue, a few steps from the restaurant on the corner of 58th Street, are a far cry from the usual. Passion fruit seeds, caraway seeds, orange zest, praline jelly and pistachios are arrayed in small containers on the bakery counter, where ice cream ($6 to $8 a portion), fruit tarts ($6), filled beignets ($6 for six) and layered coupes of cream, cake, jelly and mousse ($7 to $8) are assembled a la minute -- in two to four minutes -- while you wait.
abstract: The ice cream mix-ins at the new Petrossian Cafe and Boutique, 911 Seventh Avenue, a few steps from the restaurant on the corner of 58th Street, are a far cry from the usual. Passion fruit seeds, caraway seeds, orange zest, praline jelly and pistachios are arrayed in small containers on the bakery counter, where ice cream ($6 to $8 a portion), fruit tarts ($6), filled beignets ($6 for six) and layered coupes of cream, cake, jelly and mousse ($7 to $8) are assembled a la minute -- in two to four minutes -- while you wait.     For the chef, Philippe Conticini, and the company's president, Armen Petrossian, freshness is paramount. The caramelized apple tart with riesling gelee is assembled and warmed just before serving, so that the crisp pastry shell does not become soggy. The vanilla ice cream is churned fresh, order by order. Classic French pastries like gat eau St.-Honore must be ordered in advance.

snippet: Eric Asimov reviews restaurants along Rhine and Mosel Rivers in southwest Germany: Landhaus St Urban in Liewen, Waldhotel Sonnora in Dreis, Weinstube St Urban in Deidesheim and Le Val d'Or in Stromberg; photos; map; list (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN agricultural lands were parceled out centuries ago along the Rhine and Mosel Rivers in what is now southwestern Germany, grapes for making wine were clearly not a priority. The choicest, easy-to-farm flatlands were planted with crops like cabbage and beets. Grapes were relegated to steep hillsides, some inclining as much as 70 degrees, land that would be insane to try to farm. Yet farmers, mostly monks, persevered, and one of the world's great winemaking regions was born.
abstract: Eric Asimov reviews restaurants along Rhine and Mosel Rivers in southwest Germany: Landhaus St Urban in Liewen, Waldhotel Sonnora in Dreis, Weinstube St Urban in Deidesheim and Le Val d'Or in Stromberg; photos; map; list (M)

snippet: A la Carte column on Long Island dining scene; reviews McGillicuddy's Irish Inn in Garden City Park (S)
lead_paragraph: EVERY day is St. Patrick's Day at McGillicuddy's Irish Inn. There's Irish soda bread on the tables, bangers and mash on the menu and songs from the auld sod in the air at this neat nook at 2232 Jericho Turnpike in Garden City Park (516-746-7590). Spiffy lasses attired in white shirts and emerald-green ties provide smooth service in a dining room of tasteful green sponge-painted walls, white table cloths and green napery. The decorative mirror in the bar proclaims Guinness, and the brew is put to good use in a dish or two as well as in many a glass. To the frequent accompaniment of bagpipes, drums and fifes playing gigs and reels (no, it isn't exactly dinner music, but it fits), neighborhood patrons, many of whom seem to know each other, eat not sublime, subtle gourmet morsels, but big blunt country fare.
abstract: A la Carte column on Long Island dining scene; reviews McGillicuddy's Irish Inn in Garden City Park (S)

lead_paragraph: William Boyd's stirring World War I drama ''The Trench'' joins a sizable list of films that evoke the futility of war and the tragic waste of young lives with a potent and simmering anger. Almost the entire movie, which opens today at Film Forum, is set in a British army trench during the 48 hours leading up to the Battle of the Somme in the summer of 1916. During that battle, Britain suffered 60,000 casualties in what is still considered its worst military disaster.
abstract: William Boyd's stirring World War I drama ''The Trench'' joins a sizable list of films that evoke the futility of war and the tragic waste of young lives with a potent and simmering anger. Almost the entire movie, which opens today at Film Forum, is set in a British army trench during the 48 hours leading up to the Battle of the Somme in the summer of 1916. During that battle, Britain suffered 60,000 casualties in what is still considered its worst military disaster.    A traditional ensemble piece that often has the feel of a stage drama, ''The Trench,'' like so many previous antiwar films, follows a surefire emotional strategy. It introduces us to a group of ingenuous young soldiers, many still teenagers, makes us care about several of them (of course, there is the usual bad apple or two), then lowers the inevitable boom.

lead_paragraph: BLOOR-James, 92, died May 31st at Hilton Head Island, SC. He was born September 16, 1907 to Walter and Isabelle Bloor. He attended Barnard School for Boys and Rockland Academy. He was employed by Thompson-Starrett Co. and in 1932 he went to work for Chase National Bank, (Chase Manhattan Bank). During World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy. After the War, he returned to Chase where he stayed until 1955 when he left to become Executive Vice President of Central Savings Bank, (Apple Bank for Savings). He was named President in 1961 and retired as Chairman of the Board in 1972. Following retirement, he was a consultant for the National Bank of North America until 1974 when he was chosen by the Bankruptcy Court to act as Trustee of Investors Funding Corp. In addition, he served on the Board of Directors of Nyack Hospital, Empire National Bank, Sandoz Inc., Alico Financial Corp., Mercantile National Bank, The James T. Lee Foundation, Savings Bank Trust Co., Institutional Investors Mutual Fund, New York State Employees Retirement System, National Association of Savings Banks and Guardian Life Insurance Company. Mr. Bloor resided in Grandview-on-Hudson in Rockland County, New York. He was a Trustee of the Village, Mayor and Police Justice. In 1992, he moved to Hilton Head Island, SC. Survived by his wife, Florence; 3 children, James W. Bloor of Santa Ana, CA, Joan Faccioli of Hilton Head and Ann Gray of Eastham, MA; 8 grandchildren and 6 great-grandchildren. Memorial contributions to the Kerry Fund c/o Camp Ronald McDonald for Good Times, 1954 Cotner Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90025. Services were held on Hilton Head Island.

lead_paragraph: Samira Makhmalbaf, at 20 the youngest director ever to be in competition at the Cannes film festival, is a woman who knows her own mind and gets her own way. It shows in "Blackboards," the Iranian's second film, and in her impatience with the interpreter who could not keep up with her impetuous flow. "I wanted to speak to the people myself in English," she explained after the press conference.

lead_paragraph: CLIMBING on a 1953 tractor by his roadside farmstand piled high with just-picked apples, Tom Wickham, 61, rolled slowly down a country lane through his peach orchard. At a mill beyond the blueberry bushes and his family's 1740's clapboard homestead, his nephews, Stephen Wickham Searl, 22, and Dan Heston, 32, were pressing Mutsus, Cortlands and Jonagolds into fresh cider. In the distance, past an inlet known for more than three centuries as Wickham Creek, was an old Indian camp where Mr. Wickham said he sometimes found arrowheads and potsherds.

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Porters New York in Chelsea; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The glamour index seems to be inching up in Chelsea, which has been strangely resistant to fine dining over the years. Neighborhood residents have preferred loose, casual spots and a sprinkling of scene restaurants, but Porters New York maintains the neighborhood feel while making a bid for stylishness in food and decor. At Porters, the owners of Il Valentino in the Sutton Hotel have come up with a look that might be called ocean liner Deco, with floor-to-ceiling wood paneling, narrow curtains and cylindrical light fixtures. The spell is broken by a loud soundtrack that includes rousers like ''The Wind Beneath My Wings.''

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Piccolo Mondo Ristorante Italiano in Inwood, Long Island (M)
lead_paragraph: THE tables are too close, the din too loud and at times the service is reminiscent of a comic opera at the new Piccolo Mondo Ristorante Italiano in Inwood. Yet, everybody seems quite happy to be there, no doubt because everything tastes so good and costs so little. Outstanding value and robust jump-off-the-plate flavors have overcome all annoyances for the obviously satisfied customers who t have been crowding into this new hot spot at 233 Doughty Boulevard (516-371-0200). Many of them have, over the years, eaten at Piccolo Mondo in Manhattan, where it has held forth for nearly three decades.

snippet: SmartDisk Corp acquires VST Technologies Inc for $81.6 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The SmartDisk Corporation, a computer disk maker, agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held VST Technologies Inc., a maker of computer disk drives, for $81.6 million in stock and cash. With the purchase, SmartDisk, based in Naples, Fla., is getting computer data storage products for Apple computers and more distributors for its own products. Besides disk drives, VST makes computer accessories like adapters, batteries and disks. The company, based in Acton, Mass., had $55 million in revenue in 1999. SmartDisk had $40.3 million in revenue in 1999. Its stock was down 75 cents at $42.

abstract: THE REPUBLICANS    CHENEY SURVEYS STORM DAMAGE -- Dick Cheney's voting record in Congress followed him to Ohio yesterday as he stopped to survey the damage from a storm on Wednesday in Xenia. Mr. Cheney stood beside Gov. Robert Taft of Ohio as he called on President Clinton to declare Xenia a federal disaster area.    The Gore campaign was quick to note that when Mr. Cheney served as Wyoming's lone congressman, he voted several times against financing for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, which provides relief to disaster sites like Xenia.

The new company, to be based in Seattle, aims its services at small and midsize companies that might not be able to afford market research firms. DeepCanyon has signed Lisa Wellman, a former Apple executive, as its chief executive.

lead_paragraph: Q. I have heard that a speedy connection like a cable modem or a digital subscriber line leaves your computer very vulnerable to invasion by hackers. Is that true, and how can it be prevented?
abstract: Q. I have heard that a speedy connection like a cable modem or a digital subscriber line leaves your computer very vulnerable to invasion by hackers. Is that true, and how can it be prevented?    A. Security and privacy issues are causing more and more concern among users as high-speed connections like cable and digital subscriber lines become more available to the home market. An individual cable or D.S.L. connection is part of a network and the connection is always on and therefore visible on the network to anyone poking around in the right places. So they are thought to have more vulnerability than a telephone modem connection, which is turned ''on'' only when it dials up the Internet provider.

Most tender geraniums (pelargoniums) are native to South Africa and bloom there in spring through summer. In winter here, think of them as indoor foliage plants. Children love nature's own scratch-and-sniff, rubbing geranium leaves to discover scents of apples (P. odoratissimum), oranges (P. snippet: Weekend Excursion article by Leslie Kaufman on late-summer visit to New York's Hudson Valley, with excursions from Rhinebeck to wineries and pick-your-own farms; photos; map (M)
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are certainly not farmers, not even the weekend-in-the-backyard variety. But there are moments, especially as the air starts to chill, when I survey the obscenely generous mounds of lettuce, eggplants and apples at the Union Square Greenmarket and feel a twinge of longing. I imagine us in rough clothes standing in an orchard laden with autumn fruit, plucking just-ripened pears from a tree and tossing them into straw baskets. Tilling the soil might not be for us, but harvesting -- we could handle that.

snippet: Maureen B Fant Choice Tables review of some of Munich's finer cuisine, beyond the beer hall; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: FOR northern Europeans, Catholic, Baroque, Bavarian Munich is practically Italy, with better beer. For non-Germans, the city embodies the kinder, gentler, gemutlich Germany. Munich takes contagious pleasure in eating and drinking. The most visible side of its gastronomy is represented by breweries and beer gardens, where sausages and sauerbraten are eaten with the world's best beer, sold fresh and unpasteurized. But there is a flourishing Munich of fine eating as well, with toprated elegant restaurants, of both conservative and creative persuasion, as well as a range of ethnic places, bistros and wine bars.

lead_paragraph: THE building looks as if it had stood here for at least a century, a stolid pile of brick with severe mansard roofs. In fact, it's hardly older than the Friendly's across the street. It was built around 1970 as a steakhouse, then became Le Chateau, a temple of what passed in those days for fine dining in Bergen County. By the late 90's, when Tenafly had grown weary of Le Chateau (or vice versa), it closed and stood empty, waiting for a tenant, or a wrecker.
abstract: THE building looks as if it had stood here for at least a century, a stolid pile of brick with severe mansard roofs. In fact, it's hardly older than the Friendly's across the street. It was built around 1970 as a steakhouse, then became Le Chateau, a temple of what passed in those days for fine dining in Bergen County. By the late 90's, when Tenafly had grown weary of Le Chateau (or vice versa), it closed and stood empty, waiting for a tenant, or a wrecker.    Instead, it got America, and Tenafly may never be the same. The restaurant opened last June, transformed from a thick-beamed copy of a fading French country inn into a gorgeous and inviting space festooned with fresh flowers, elegant woodwork and interior-design flourishes.

snippet: Bernard Holland article speculates on appeal to people who may have great taste in music of array of often humorous and largely tasteless music-related ties, lamps, toilet paper and other items offered in Music Treasures Company catalog; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: A FRIEND has a theory that our five senses get one blanket allotment of talent at birth and that the size of that allotment is pretty much the same for each of us. What separates one person from another, the thinking goes, is how we divide up what we have. The ''well-rounded'' person would actually be the well-balanced one: a finite amount of ability split equally among seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting and touching. If a little of everything seems to lead us to the ideal personality, it also, I fear, identifies someone who would bore us to death.
abstract: Bernard Holland article speculates on appeal to people who may have great taste in music of array of often humorous and largely tasteless music-related ties, lamps, toilet paper and other items offered in Music Treasures Company catalog; photo (M)

abstract: Ford Releases Data on Tires That Firestone Recalled  Ford Motor released documents showing that Bridgestone/Firestone had received for years an unusually large number of claims on the tires that were recalled last week.    The highest numbers of claims by a wide margin were for tires produced at Bridgestone's factory in Decatur, Ill., in 1994 and 1995, when the factory was operated by replacement workers. lead_paragraph: At the center of ''The Comedy of Innocence'' is a round-faced, apple-cheeked moppet named Camille (Nils Hugon) who lives in serene haut-bourgeois elegance in an old house in Paris. Shortly after his ninth birthday, Camille, whose closest companions are a possibly imaginary friend named Alexandre and a video camera, starts behaving strangely. He insists that his name is Paul and starts addressing his mother (Isabelle Huppert), with cold formality, by her first name, which is Ariane. Soon he has dragged her halfway across the city to the chic bohemian apartment of the woman he claims is his real mother, a flighty violin teacher named Isabella (Jeanne Balibar), whose son drowned two years earlier.
abstract: At the center of ''The Comedy of Innocence'' is a round-faced, apple-cheeked moppet named Camille (Nils Hugon) who lives in serene haut-bourgeois elegance in an old house in Paris. Shortly after his ninth birthday, Camille, whose closest companions are a possibly imaginary friend named Alexandre and a video camera, starts behaving strangely. He insists that his name is Paul and starts addressing his mother (Isabelle Huppert), with cold formality, by her first name, which is Ariane. Soon he has dragged her halfway across the city to the chic bohemian apartment of the woman he claims is his real mother, a flighty violin teacher named Isabella (Jeanne Balibar), whose son drowned two years earlier.    What is going on here? Some kind of strange supernatural event? Is this the latest movie to explore the possibility of parallel realities, to imagine a kind of lived hypertext? For its first hour, Raul Ruiz's film, adapted from a novel by the Italian writer Massimo Bontempelli called ''The Boy With Two Mothers,'' weaves an elegant spell of epistemological confusion. The quiet, elegant Parisian interiors take on a spooky, claustrophobic feel, which is intensified by the odd behavior of the people who inhabit them. Camille's uncle Serge (Charles Berling), a psychiatrist, is prone to odd mood swings; the au pair, Helene, sulks passive-aggressively around the house; and Isabella has a creepy neighbor whose most banal utterances sound mysterious, even threatening.

lead_paragraph: BRANDSTEIN-Gladys M. 91. Born in New York City, January 14, 1909. Died in NYC February 21, 2000. Devoted wife of Dr. Philip L. Brandstein, deceased in 1968. One of the first women to receive a law degree from NYU Law School. A progressive Attorney involved with civil rights and antipoverty programs. Managed a redevelopment housing projects in Crown Heights. Operated summer camps Wabigoon and Wahanda and was a positive influence in the lives of hundreds of children over two generations. In her elderly years, she served as a volunteer for a public library and as a mentor for newly arrived immigrants. She leaves her sons Lawrence Z. and David Z. Brandstein, grandchildren Kendra-the special apple in her eye, love/light in her life, Vicente, Asha, Owa & ''nephews'' and ''nieces'', Herman and Sunny Berkowitz and Ralph and Marilyn Berkowitz -sons of her life-long best friend Irma, deceased.

snippet: Elisabeth Ginsburg In the Garden column on growing ornamental gourds; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: GARDENERS who are fond of peering into the past already know that human history is littered with gourds. Ancient people used the hard shell Lagenaria (Calabash) varieties as utensils and containers. Early Egyptians sealed them in tombs along with other earthly necessities they thought that the deceased would need in the afterlife. Native Americans grew and used hard shell gourds and passed the habit along to the colonists.

lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:
abstract: To the Sports Editor:    Harvey Araton writes that Tony Perez's mother thanked the heavens that she had lived to see her son become the first Cuban-born player to make the Hall of Fame (''Apple Pie and Mom and a Dream,'' Jan. 13). The first Cuban-born Hall of Famer was Martin Dihigo, born in 1905 in Matanzas. Denied the opportunity to play in the major leagues, Dihigo starred in the Negro Leagues and in Cuba and Mexico as a pitcher, infielder and outfielder. He was elected posthumously to the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1977.    DANIEL EVAN SEABOLD  Hempstead, N.Y.

snippet: Marilyn Stasio reviews following books: Blood Money by Thomas Perry; Manifesto for the Dead by Domenic Stansberry; Void Moon by Michael Connelly; The Body in the Big Apple by Katherine Hall Page; and Coyote Revenge by Fred Harris; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Go. Run. Hide. Escape. The little voice that promises adventure and danger in Thomas Perry's hide-and-seek thrillers sends out another irresistible summons in BLOOD MONEY (Random House, $24.95). ''Everybody wants to go somewhere,'' says Jane Whitefield, a Seneca Indian guide who helps fugitives disappear into the wild blue yonder. But ''the only one who wants to go everywhere,'' she knows, ''is somebody who's been locked up for a long time. . . . Or a kid.''

snippet: I Started keeping a gardening notebook 20 years ago. I was living in the green heart of Savannah, Ga., at the time, on the third floor of a mustard-colored old row house with a walled garden full of 15- foot camellias, under the graceful canopy of...
lead_paragraph: I Started keeping a gardening notebook 20 years ago. I was living in the green heart of Savannah, Ga., at the time, on the third floor of a mustard-colored old row house with a walled garden full of 15- foot camellias, under the graceful canopy of a couple of tall pecan trees. My brand-new five-year garden calendar had enough blank pages to last an eternity, it seemed to me then, and I enthusiastically set about making horticultural notes: I sketched the cat, sleeping on the iron stairs down to the garden; remarked on the mockingbirds; and immortalized a few lunch menus.

lead_paragraph: The Nasdaq stock market, enduring its most persistent selling pressure in more than six years, has now returned to the lows of six months ago, when panic briefly gripped investors. This time the fall has been a bit less abrupt, but it has been even more relentless as one technology company after another has warned investors that growth is slowing.

snippet: RealNetworks Inc acquires Netzip Inc for about $268 million in stock (S)
lead_paragraph: RealNetworks Inc., a leading maker of software used to play online music and videos, said yesterday that it had bought closely held Netzip Inc., which produces software for downloading files from the Internet, for about $268 million in stock. Netzip, which is based in Atlanta, makes products that make it easier to download and view media files from the Web. RealNetworks, which is based in Seattle, is adding software and other features in a bid to hold off competition from the Microsoft Corporation and Apple Computer. It will distribute Netzip's software to customers who use its software for playing audio and video over the Internet. Shares of RealNetworks rose $11 each, to $157.875, in Nasdaq trading.

lead_paragraph: DESIGN is the art that is hidden in plain sight. In the United States, those design disciplines not prefaced by ''fashion'' have long been the neglected stepchildren of culture and commerce. But unlike fashion, which trades in distant desire, the work of product designers, graphic designers and architects is all around us: sneakers and staplers, trivets and towers, Web sites and Weber grills.

snippet: Design of the 20th Century, book by Charlotte and Peter Fiell, offers alphabetical entries on century's major design movements and designers; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Offering alphabetical entries on the century's major design movements (Art Nouveau, Bauhaus, de Stijl) and designers, including Eileen Gray, Le Corbusier, Serge Mouille and Marco Zanuso (his 1951 chairs are at left), ''Design of the 20th Century'' (Taschen, $29.99) is an important and accessible reference. The chunky 768-page paperback has beautiful photographs and an informed, if somewhat dry, text by Charlotte and Peter Fiell. More Eurocentric than some other surveys, this valuable overview thereby suffers from a few misspellings (the Apple Mackintosh and that old store, Benoit Teller).

snippet: Eliza Minot profiles decoupage designer John Derian; photos (special section, Home Design) (part 2 of 2-part section)
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Watertown, Mass., the youngest of six, John Derian was ''always collecting and arranging things to try to make my own little place,'' he explains. And he's still doing it: his store on East Second Street, the John Derian Company, is nothing if not his own little place -- a colorful haven filled with his handmade tableware, alongside antiques, flea-market finds and home furnishings gathered on his travels. The shiny plates he designs are arrayed brightly side by side, their lively faces as inviting as fresh flowers or candy. Pillows, straw bags, hat feathers, Chinese lanterns, vases and Derian's line of paper goods (note cards, postcards and wrapping paper) cover every surface. A wrought-iron bed is piled with richly colored Indian cotton spreads and reversible coverlets from France.
abstract: Eliza Minot profiles decoupage designer John Derian; photos (special section, Home Design) (part 2 of 2-part section)

snippet: The National Audubon Society, which is concerned about the finned as well as the feathered, has published the Seafood Lover's Almanac, a colorful guide ($19.95) to the habitats of various fish, crustaceans and mollusks and the methods used to catc...
lead_paragraph: The National Audubon Society, which is concerned about the finned as well as the feathered, has published the Seafood Lover's Almanac, a colorful guide ($19.95) to the habitats of various fish, crustaceans and mollusks and the methods used to catch them. There are also some cooking tips and recipes. Each species is rated, from green to yellow to red — with red being the worst — on the Audubon Fish Scale, a gauge of whether it is endangered and whether harvesting methods cause pollution or threaten other species. Among the imperiled are the Patagonian toothfish (a k a Chilean sea bass) and swordfish. (King mackerel, above, gets a green.) To order: (888) 397-6649.

lead_paragraph: Court Ruling Could Raise Costs for Phone Companies
abstract: Court Ruling Could Raise Costs for Phone Companies  In a legal victory for local telephone companies, a federal appeals court struck down pricing rules that federal regulators had hoped would foster competition in local communications markets.    If the ruling stands, it could lead to an increase in the fees that companies pay for connecting to the networks of local carriers, adding millions of dollars in costs for long-distance giants like AT&T and WorldCom as well as for new companies that are trying to break into the local telephone business. [Page C2.]

snippet: Neil Genzlinger reviews revival of Lily Tomlin's one-woman Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe at McCarter Theater, Princeton, NJ; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IN the 14 years since Lily Tomlin won the Tony Award for her performance in ''The Search for Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' we humans have done a lot of peering, both outward and inward. In 1989 we sent the Galileo spacecraft on its way to an orbit around Jupiter. In 1995, for the first time, we detected a planet circling a star other than our own sun. Just a few months ago we completed the mapping of our own genetic structure.

lead_paragraph: RARELY do audiences emerge from an exhibition smiling. Yet at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, where ''Calder in Connecticut'' is on view through Aug. 6, staff members witness the phenomenon every day. The works that Alexander Calder created during four decades spent mainly in the state reflect his zest for life and playful nature, and visitors seem to find his stance contagious.

snippet: Mark Kutsher, who runs Kutsher's Country Club in Catskills, comments on his plan to option the family business to a conglomerate that intends to build $1 billion casino and 2,000-room 'destination resort' on 50 spare acres of his property; photo (...
lead_paragraph: HERE we are, confronting the same old same old at Kutsher's Country Club: an elderly man is sound asleep in the lobby, while two women with no intention of spilling their age paddle across the indoor pool like a pair of spandex tugboats. Outside, the golfers ponder their divots. Helen Kutsher, who can spot a tarnished fork from 50 paces, is on hostess patrol, as she's been for the past half century, and her 52-year-old son, Mark, who runs the place, is solving the mystery of the missing tile in the men's health center.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Triomphe, French-American restaurant in Iroquois Hotel in midtown Manhattan; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: SIGN of the Dove no longer exists, but it continues to exert a quiet influence on the dining scene. The chefs who spent their formative years there have fanned out across the city to restaurants like Little Dove, Five Points and Cibo, bringing a restrained stylishness along with them. The latest in this crop is Steven Zobel, who spent four years at Sign of the Dove before taking over the stove at one of its sister restaurants, Contrapunto. Now he has his own showcase, Triomphe, in the remodeled Iroquois Hotel in Midtown.

lead_paragraph: THE decor has been muted since this restaurant's bright, white days as Baci. Massimo, the new occupant, however, has wisely kept the curved corner wall of sparkling glass brick and the charming sepia wallpaper. The softer, sandy tones of the color scheme enhance the room's intimate quality, and an interesting collection of prints and drawings lends sophistication.

snippet: Patricia Brooks reviews Brix restaurant in Cheshire, Conn (M)
lead_paragraph: BRIX in Cheshire inhabits the space (with the same ownership and chef) that once housed the Pavilion, but the proprietors Onella and Bernard Gayraud (he is also the chef) have changed the cuisine, menu and decor dramatically, evoking a more casual Mediterranean image, which seems to have taken hold very nicely. With good reason. The bright, stylishly mustard walls, parquet floor, Windsor-style chairs, banquettes and booths are a simple backdrop for some delicious, fresh-tasting food on a menu that also features a few pastas and pizzas.

snippet: Molly O'Neill Food column on choosing chef's knife; recipes; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The length of one's blade can be a measure of one's authority in the kitchen. Some virtuosos become human slice, dice and mince machines. Others, and I was one, take pity on a tomato bleeding under a light, short and dull blade and reach for ever heavier, longer, sharper knives. Either way, one learns the delicate balance between violence and nurture by mastering the use of something capable of both.

snippet: The Nobel laureate Guenter Grass once dissed Frankfurt as a "lump of concrete." The pain must be real for a 1960s leftist forced to watch economic policy wonks and speculative predators overrun the birthplace of the national poet, Johann Wolfgan
lead_paragraph: The Nobel laureate Guenter Grass once dissed Frankfurt as a "lump of concrete." The pain must be real for a 1960s leftist forced to watch economic policy wonks and speculative predators overrun the birthplace of the national poet, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. This medieval money-changing center hurried after World War II to rebuild itself; Frankfurt almost became West Germany's postwar capital. But fate was cruel. Bonn got the prize, while Frankfurt got all the lumpy pragmatic architecture.

lead_paragraph: Is there any relationship so intimate as that between a puppet and its master? Whether controlled by hand, strings or sticks, puppets are famous for providing bolder alter egos for those who manipulate them. ''My Puppet, Myself'' could easily be a subtitle for everything from the cheery television shows of Shari Lewis to those homicidal ventriloquist movies that show up every decade or so.

lead_paragraph: Q. Is there some way of transforming old home videotapes into the digital video format so they can be edited using the iMovie software on the new iMacs?
abstract: Q. Is there some way of transforming old home videotapes into the digital video format so they can be edited using the iMovie software on the new iMacs?    A. While the new iMacs are designed for easy video transfer between a digital camcorder and a computer with a FireWire cable, older analog video formats like VHS must be converted to the digital video format for use with iMovie, the iMac's video-editing program. A Web search can point you to companies that handle video transfers between formats, but there are other options if you would like to do it yourself.

lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16
abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-16    U.N. Agrees to Let Iraq Spend More Oil Revenue  A divided U.N. Security Council agreed to give Iraq new leeway in spending billions in oil proceeds that have been accumulating because of high oil prices. At the center of the package, a six-month renewal of the Iraqi ''oil for food'' program, is a provision pushed by France and other Iraq supporters to free about $525 million for repair and maintenance of Iraq's oil industry.   A16    Palestinian Economy Weakens  The United Nations said two months of renewed violence had devastated the economy of the West Bank and Gaza, costing Palestinians more than $500 million. Unemployment has tripled, leaving more than a million Palestinians with no regular household incomes.   A12

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Dodge City Steak House in Westhampton, NY (M)
lead_paragraph: LAST summer the unheralded Dodge City Steak House in Westhampton moseyed into the vast price gulch between Bryant & Cooper and Boulder Creek. Until then the steakhouse revival on Long Island had been largely confined to expense-account, high-roller venues and a few low-end emporiums that stressed quantity more than quality. There's a lot of room between the big beef palaces, with their $15 shrimp cocktails and $38 steaks, and the $12.95 economy steak spots. The commendable Dodge City Steak House, at 62 Montauk Highway (631-288-0500), has pulled its rig dead center between the two.

lead_paragraph: SING, goddess! Time to brush up our Homer. At the Salzburg Festival, which opens today and compresses a busy season's worth of music and drama into six weeks, four of the seven new opera productions take up the theme of the Trojan War, its antecedents and its aftermath. ''Les Troyens,'' by Berlioz, the grandest of them all, has its Salzburg premiere tomorrow in a production designed and directed by Herbert Wernicke, whose best work is second to none in contemporary music theater.

lead_paragraph: Because Wilson Daniels has brought wine lovers pleasure mostly indirectly since 1978, it is not a household name. A Napa Valley company, it represents producers like Schramsberg, the top-tier Napa sparkling-wine house; Domaine de la Roman'ee-Conti, Burgundy's crown jewel; Salon, the ne plus ultra Champagne; and the brilliant Marc Kreydenweiss of Alsace.
abstract: Because Wilson Daniels has brought wine lovers pleasure mostly indirectly since 1978, it is not a household name. A Napa Valley company, it represents producers like Schramsberg, the top-tier Napa sparkling-wine house; Domaine de la Roman'ee-Conti, Burgundy's crown jewel; Salon, the ne plus ultra Champagne; and the brilliant Marc Kreydenweiss of Alsace.     Win Wilson and Jack Daniels couldn't resist the temptation to create their own chardonnay. The spiffy '97 version is the lucky consumer's multipurpose dream: sleek, light-bodied and refreshing enough to be an aperitif; crisp and creamy enough to accompany seafood and poultry dishes.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Tocqueville, Manhattan restaurant; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ONE way to gauge the vibrancy of a city's restaurant culture is to count the number of three-star or four-star establishments. Like the Dow, however, this approach may yield a false result. It would put Las Vegas in the same league as San Francisco or Chicago. A more reliable measure -- call it the French scale -- is the number of restaurants that deliver good, well-executed food in a civilized atmosphere. They do not want to be hot. They will never develop a scene. In the republic of dining, they constitute the solid, tax-paying, law-abiding bourgeoisie.
abstract: William Grimes reviews Tocqueville, Manhattan restaurant; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: Caring for Fuchsia
abstract: Caring for Fuchsia    Q. I just purchased my first fuchsia, an expensive, beautiful all red one. How do I care for it? Should the ends be cut back after the blooms at the bottom fall off? Can cuttings be taken in the fall for the following year?    A. Congratulations! Only 7,999 more and you'll have almost all the varieties. Meanwhile, keep the plant in a warm, semishaded place, out of the wind. While it's blooming, feed it every other week with a half-strength solution of balanced fertilizer. Water just enough so that the soil stays evenly moist.

snippet: William Grimes reviews ONEc.p.s., brasserie in Plaza Hotel; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IF you wanted to hide a contemporary restaurant in Manhattan, the Plaza Hotel would be an excellent place to put it. In a city famous for tearing headlong into the future, the Plaza sits immobile, a squat dowager at the corner of Central Park who has has seen it all come and go. The Oak Room remains a dark, heavily timbered relic, haunted by ghosts. The Palm Court looks as though it is waiting for Martin Scorsese to drop by to shoot one more scene for ''The Age of Innocence.'' In decor and atmosphere, the hotel makes a perfect match for the horse-drawn carriages that ply the street, and is therefore an astounding location for Alan Stillman, the chairman of the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, to create a snappy, up-to-the-minute American restaurant.
abstract: William Grimes reviews ONEc.p.s., brasserie in Plaza Hotel; photo (M)

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Metro Fish restaurant on East 36th Street; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The calendar says the year 2000 is here. Inside Metro Fish, the date is 1955. Or it could be 1935. Metro Fish is the kind of restaurant that invites diners to ask about ''the fisherman's catch'' and boasts that its clams and oysters are ''shucked to order.'' There's nothing self-consciously retro about any of this. The consciousness is pre-retro. Metro Fish offers, with a straight face, dishes like clams Casino, coconut fried shrimp and a broiled seafood platter. All entrees include baked potato, french fries or mashed potato. The night I visited, the children at surrounding tables seemed to be in seventh heaven. At last a fine-dining menu they could understand.
abstract: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Metro Fish restaurant on East 36th Street; photo (S)

snippet: Hewlett-Packard's introduces new series of smaller and simpler desktop PC's, called e-Vectra; new computer is aimed at business market but is also designed to appeal to home users; price of low-end model starts at about $549; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The Help Desk just got a little help: a new series of desktop PC's that are smaller and simpler. Announced earlier this week, Hewlett-Packard's new e-Vectra computer is about the size of a hard-cover dictionary, about 75 percent smaller than the average desktop PC. The computer, aimed at the business market but also designed to appeal to home users, is expected to arrive in stores by this summer, with street prices for the low-end models estimated to start at about $549. The e-Vectra weighs about eight pounds. When unhooked from its monitor and keyboard, it can fit inside a laptop computer case for easy transport.

snippet: Herbert Muschamp assesses changes in design field, fueled by new economy, that have sparked public imagination like no other since late 1960's and early 1970's; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IT is scary to be living at a time when a particular creative field grips the public imagination as powerfully as design has in recent years. I can't recall anything like it since the late 60's and early 70's, when movies and pop music exercised a magnetic hold on the minds of baby boomers. Today, the vigor pulses through fashion, furniture, art direction, graphics and product and image design with a similarly captivating verve. Design has taken on its own life, and this raises a problem often encountered in consumer culture. The energy is pure delight. But can we turn it off?

snippet: Edward Rothstein column praises new Hayden Planetarium in Rose Center for Earth and Space at American Museum of Natural History; says that while old planetarium projected the human imagination outward, the new one attempts to project the cosmos in...
lead_paragraph: There was a time, not long ago, when the Hayden Planetarium quaintly combined exoticism with worn comfort. Inlaid in the floor, in colored terrazzo, was a representation of an Aztec calendar stone. The massive Willamette Meteorite squatted by the museum entrance, a pitted sculpture created according to some unreadable design. In the lobby a mural depicted the cosmology of the Blackfeet Indians. In the domed hall itself, in the days before prepackaged programming became the rule, a man would stand pointing out the stars and constellations with an arrow-shaped beam of light. And the great Zeiss projection machinery would seem, silhouetted against the heavens, to be a creature out of ''War of the Worlds.'' As the show began, twilight would gradually fall, a mock skyline of houses ringing the dome beneath the blackening sky.
abstract: Edward Rothstein column praises new Hayden Planetarium in Rose Center for Earth and Space at American Museum of Natural History; says that while old planetarium projected the human imagination outward, the new one attempts to project the cosmos inward, imprinting it on the human imagination; drawing (M)

snippet: Jeff MacGregor article on rising tide of air rage that is sweeping American airline industry; blames not only record delays, flight cancellations and overcrowding but passengers' inability to have any control over their own fate; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: It wasn't supposed to be this way. We were told to expect medium-rare chateaubriand and exotic fondues and white linen antimacassars gentling our dreamy heads and fancy French wine all around and the bell ring of sterling flatware. These I was promised. Knifing through the jet stream at 50,000 feet, I would put up my stockinged feet, take my good wife's gloved hand, beam at our Cleaver-perfect children across the wide aisle and doze as we rocketed safely into our future at 600 miles per hour. This is what we were sold. Promises were made, the ancient newsreel promises of commercial jet travel, circa 1960. The new magic carpet for the new American leisure class.
abstract: Jeff MacGregor article on rising tide of air rage that is sweeping American airline industry; blames not only record delays, flight cancellations and overcrowding but passengers' inability to have any control over their own fate; photo (M)

snippet: Kay S Hymowitz Op-Ed article says problem with contemporary child-rearing is not simply that some parents do not spend enough time with their children or are not close to them, but that many adults fail to use that time to define moral universe fo...
lead_paragraph: Last week's White House conference on teenagers kept coming back to one conclusion above all: that parental involvement is the best tonic for what ails troubled teenagers. President Clinton, calling attention to a report from the Council of Economic Advisers, announced that ''teenagers that had dinner with their parents five times a week are far more likely to avoid smoking, drinking, violence, suicide and drugs.'' He and the first lady trumpeted a campaign to encourage family togetherness, and he promised to make it easier for federal workers to spend time with their teenagers.

lead_paragraph: Best Bet
abstract: Best Bet    On Friday at 8 p.m., Musica Sacra, which Opera News calls ''the Cadillac of the New York choral scene'' returns to Tilles Center on the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville with its highly polished, unabridged version of Handel's ''Messiah,'' complete with professional soloists (516) 299-3100.    Different Drummers    The holiday lineup this week brings some lesser-performed music, too. Today, the Choral Society of the Hamptons sings ''A German Baroque Christmas,'' a program of Bach cantatas and sacred pieces by Praetorius and Schutz, at 5 and 7:30 p.m. at the Bridgehampton Presbyterian Church on Main Street (631) 324-1891. On Friday, the Stony Brook Camerata and Women's Chorus concentrate on English composers with Britten's ''Ceremony of Carols'' and works by Vaughan Williams and Tavener at 8 p.m. at Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University (631) 632-2787, while the Moscow Boys Choir visits the Westhampton Beach Performing Arts Center on Main Street at 8 p.m. with ''Christmas Around the World'' featuring a potpourri of international holiday tunes (631) 288-1500. The Long Island Symphonic Choral Association has Saturday to itself for Monteverdi's ''Vespers of 1610,'' a work for double chorus, soloists, orchestra, harpsichord and organ, at 8 p.m. at the St. James Catholic Church on Route 25A in Setauket (631) 751-2743.    Pops Approach    The Long Island Philharmonic offers such pops classics as ''Winter Wonderland,'' ''Let It Snow,'' ''White Christmas'' and ''Oh Hannukah'' today at 4 p.m. with ''Bravo! Holidays,'' a family concert at Tilles Center in Brookville. Performed by the cast of ''Bravo! Broadway,'' the concert, under Randall Craig Fleischer's baton, will also feature Sean-Avram Carpenter and Lauren-Sarah Carpenter, brother and sister violinists, who won the Long Island Philharmonic's 1997 and 2000 Young Artist Competition, respectively, in a duet of ''Winter'' from Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons.'' The concert will help raise money to send the East Meadow High School Marching Band to the Orange Bowl (516) 299-3100.    On Their Toes    While ''The Nutcracker'' is as much a part of this holiday season as Handel's ''Messiah'' -- there are seven different productions on the Island this week -- naturally not every ballet company conforms. So Ballet New York, the new troupe based in Glen Cove, will open its annual performance today at 2 p.m. at the Maguire Theater on the Old Westbury campus of the State University with the premiere of a new work. It is ''Wanderers in the Light,'' a one-act ballet set to music by Rachmaninoff that was inspired by ''Street,'' which Konstantin Uralsky, the company's artistic director, created by commission for a Unicef gala at the Kremlin in Moscow in 1999. The ballet, the choreographer said, is ''a look at the human experience on the brink of the new millennium.'' ''Sounds of the Holiday,'' with, yes, excerpts from ''The Nutcracker,'' completes the program. (516) 656-3232.    Ballet Long Island, the company based in Bohemia, also defies convention this year. Well, almost. In addition to its traditional ''Nutcracker'' which on Saturday begins its run through Dec. 23 at Town Hall West on Main Street in Islip, the troupe will also expand its repertory with ''The Fantastic Toyshop,'' on Saturday and Dec. 19; ''Snow White,'' next Sunday and Dec. 21; and ''A Christmas Carol,'' Dec. 20 and 23 (631) 567-4403.    Wildlife Watch    Sandwiched between the Atlantic Ocean and Shinnecock Bay, Dune Road, which runs from Quogue Village to the Shinnecock Inlet, is a great place to view wildlife on the East End, no matter what the season. Today, from noon to 2 p.m., naturalists from the Group for the South Fork take nature lovers on a walk along this thoroughfare on which the group eventually hopes to establish a self-guided wildlife viewing trail. Hikers will be on the lookout for the shorebirds, waterfowl and harbor seals that inhabit the salt marshes, mudflats and open waters bordering the road (631) 537-1400.    'Sound and Fury'    When it comes to family drama, reality can make fiction pale. That's the case with ''Sound and Fury,'' a documentary that begins a seven-day run at the Cinema Arts Center in Huntington on Friday. The film takes an up-close and personal look at the Artinians, a deaf family from Glen Cove split by the desire of its 6-year-old daughter, Heather, for a cochlear implant. The medical treatment would make her part of the hearing world, alienating her from her parents and two brothers and their deaf identity. The subjects of the film and Josh Aronson, its director, and Roger Weisberg, its producer, will appear at the screening at 7 p.m. on Saturday. The center is on Park Avenue (631) 423-7610.    Youth Reigns    Young musicians and song-and-dance performers are all the rage this week on the Island. Today, the Metropolitan Youth Orchestra of New York, 250-members strong, showcases the talents of the youngsters ages 8 to 18 and from 73 different communities in Nassau, Suffolk, Queens and Manhattan who make up the eight-year-old organization's three performing units, the Principal, Concert and String Orchestras. Starting at 4 p.m. at Berner Middle School on Carman's Mill Road in Massapequa, the youngsters will play works by Chabrier, Dvorak, Handel and Sibelius and Joseph Schwantner's ''New Morning for the World,'' a piece about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. which they will perform in January in Albany at New York State's celebration of Martin Luther King Jr. Day (516) 365-2599.    Talent of another kind will be showcased on Saturday when ''The Broadway Kids'' make their Long Island debut at the Landmark on Main Street in Port Washington. These youngsters, all of whom have performed on Broadway, will recreate the children-friendly tunes featured in the popular ''Broadway Kids'' CD series: from ensemble numbers to solos from such shows as ''Annie,'' ''Oliver,'' ''Les Miserables,'' ''Pippin'' and ''The Sound of Music.'' The revue will be offered at 3 and 7 p.m. (516) 767-6444.    Free Choices    TODAY  With time out for their leader, Luis Cordero, to discuss the ''whys and hows'' of his emigration to the United States, Los Amigos de la Amargue perform traditional meringue music from the Dominican Republic at 2 p.m. at the Parrish Art Museum on Job's Lane in Southampton (631) 283-2118.    Martin Goldsmith, the National Public Radio commentator, discusses ''The Inextinguishable Symphony,'' his book about his parents' involvement in an orchestra founded by the Nazis for Jews, at 1:30 p.m. at the Holocaust Memorial and Educational Center of Nassau County on Crescent Beach Road in Glen Cove (516) 571-8040.    The Gilbert and Sullivan Light Opera Company of Long Island offers ''A Gilbert and Sullivan Christmas Carol,'' combining lines from the Dickens work like ''Bah, humbug'' with tunes like ''Titwillow, titwillow,'' at 2:30 p.m. at the Merrick Library on Merrick Avenue (516) 379-3476.    WEDNESDAY  The Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery and Aquarium on Route 25A holds a ''Holiday Open House'' from 1 to 5 p.m., inviting folks in to tour the place, ask questions about the fish, amphibians and reptiles on the premises, and, just incidentally, visit the gift shop (516) 692-6768.    SATURDAY  On Saturday, Handel's ''Messiah'' gets a more modest treatment in Massapequa via community singers when the Long Island Concert Chorale and St. Rose of Lima Choir present parts one and two at 8 p.m. in a free concert at St. Rose of Lima Church on Merrick Road (516) 946-7207.    The Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary on Cove Road in Oyster Bay holds an open house, its ''Traditional Sanctuary Winter Celebration'' from 2 to 4 p.m., with tree decorating and apple cider and hot-chocolate treats (516) 922-3200.    Cecelia Brauer plays the glass armonica, the instrument made of glass bowls that Benjamin Franklin invented and that the likes of Beethoven and Mozart composed music for. The performance is at 2 p.m. at the Bayport-Blue Point Library on Blue Point Avenue in Blue Point (631) 363-6133.   Compiled by Barbara Delatiner

lead_paragraph: Q. Is there any way I can use U.S.B. devices if my computer has no U.S.B. ports?
abstract: Q. Is there any way I can use U.S.B. devices if my computer has no U.S.B. ports?    A. Computers made before 1997 do not generally support the Universal Serial Bus standard, but it might be possible to upgrade your machine, depending on the type of computer and operating system you are using. But there are a few hardware and software factors to consider.

snippet: Interview with Bride Whelan, executive director of Society of Publication Designers who recently acquired one-bedroom condo rental on Park Avenue near 39th Street; photos (Habitats column) (M)
lead_paragraph: SHE might not like the description, but some people consider Bride Whelan something of a seer whose medium is color. Tell her whether red, blue or green speaks most forcefully to you, and she'll describe your personality, your style, your values. She will insist, however, that there's nothing psychic about her abilities, that ample evidence from science, history and psychology explains the link between personality and color.

snippet: Timothy Jack Ward article describes demise of Posh&Sticks, home-furnishings Internet business financed by group that included Ronald and Leonard Lauder; analyzes reasons for its failure; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: OUR multimillion-dollar dot-com folded, and all I got was this lousy T-shirt. Everyone at Posh&Sticks got one, the day our enigmatic -- let's face it, odd -- name was announced last January. Now, it is a bittersweet souvenir from the rush for the elusive e-commerce mother lode. Don't get me wrong: I loved the name and was proud to wear it on my chest. We gave this our best shot, but we are toast.

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Grace, new restaurant in TriBeCa; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: It's hard to know whether Grace is a restaurant with a bar or a bar with a restaurant. Visually the bar comes first, and it's impossible to miss. Weighty, glossy and a mile long, it dominates the front room, and there's more to it than polished mahogany. Fred McKibbin, one of the owners, did pioneering cocktail work at Nosmo King, now defunct, and he has transferred his obsessions to Grace, where the bar list includes an apple martini made with vodka and Berentzen Apfelkorn, a tangerine margarita and a superior winter warmer made with hot spiced cider, Maker's Mark bourbon, fresh lemon juice and a stick of cinnamon.
abstract: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of Grace, new restaurant in TriBeCa; photo (S)

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Heart of Portugal restaurant in Mineola, Long Island (A La Carte column) (M)
lead_paragraph: IT'S possible to whiz along Mineola Boulevard and not notice that the large stucco building with the wrought-iron gates, brick-trimmed entrance and circular windows that was Little Portugal is now Heart of Portugal. The Mineola spot has experienced an admirable resurgence under its new owners. Although it's not unpleasant cliched Portuguese decor (stone and rough-hewn walls, fireplace, lanterns, antique guns, boat models, Old Lisbon mural) remains largely in place, the nine-month-old Heart of Portugal, at 241 Mineola Boulevard (516-742-9797), has a revitalized menu, warmth and spirit that makes it one of the most outstanding restaurants in this ethnic enclave.
abstract: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Heart of Portugal restaurant in Mineola, Long Island (A La Carte column) (M)

lead_paragraph: GORDON-Edward. To our beloved Dad and Papa: we will always love you. You gave us so many special memories that will last in our hearts forever. Robin, Steve, Jennifer, Jeremy, Emily and Brianna Apple
abstract: GORDON-Edward. To our beloved Dad and Papa: we will always love you. You gave us so many special memories that will last in our hearts forever. Robin, Steve, Jennifer, Jeremy, Emily and Brianna Apple     GORDON-Edward S. The Officers and Staff of State of Israel Bonds mourn with profound sorrow the passing of an outstanding leader of its Real Estate and Construction Division and a devoted friend and supporter of the State of Israel. Widely esteemed throughout the real estate industry, he served with great distinction as a Vice Chairman of the Division and was a Campaign Chairman and guest of honor at its Tribute Luncheon. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Cheryl, his children Robin and Kenneth, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Gideon Patt, President and CEO Burton P. Resnick Chairman of the Board Irwin Hochberg, National Campaign Chairman Howard Hirsch, Chairman Metropolitan New York Region Peter S. Kalikow, Chairman Corporate & Professional Division Daniel R. Tishman Chairman, Real Estate & Construction Division     GORDON-Edward S. On behalf of our entire organization, we wish to express our profound sorrow at the passing of Edward S. Gordon, and to extend our deepest condolences to his family. He left an indelible mark on our industry. He will be sorely and forever missed, although his legacy will live on. The Principals of Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. Aaron Gural Jeffrey Gural Barry M. Gosin James Kuhn Arthur H. Lerner Ronald E. Goldberger William G. Cohen Arthur Rosenbloom Marlene Post David A. Falk Neil A. Goldmacher Scott M. Panzer Brian S. Waterman     GORDON-Edward S. With great sorrow we mourn the loss of our great leader, beloved mentor, and dear friend. Those who really knew him will and can never forget him. He changed the face of this great city with a style and flair distinctly his. I thank him for giving us the platform to do what we do; we could not have done it without him. My deepest sympathy to Cheryl, Robin, Kenny, Allan and their families. I share and am devastated by this tragic loss. I will miss him. He will always live in the hearts of those he touched. To know him was to love him. C. Bradley Mendelson Insignia/ESG     GORDON-Edward S. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of NY deeply regret the passing of Edward S. Gordon, a friend of our community who touched the lives of thousands of individuals through his generous support. We extend our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife, Cheryl; his children, Kenneth and Robin; his mother, Laura; and the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO     GORDON-Edward S. The Partners, Associates and Staff of Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield mourn the passing of Edward Gordon, our most cherished friend and client of so many years. Ed always demanded the best of us and we are gratified to have met his expectations. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. We extend our deepest condolences to Ed's beloved family and legion of friends. Podell, Schwartz, Schechter & Banfield     GORDON-Edward S. My deepest sorrow at the passing of my unforgettable mentor and friend Edward S. Gordon. For the last 28 years Eddie, you have influenced every chapter of my life. My heartful condolences to Cheryl, Laura, Ken, Robin, Steve, Allan and Joan. James B. Emden     GORDON-Edward S. We respectfully offer our most sincere condolences to Ed's family, friends, and associates, with whom we have been both close friends and a frequent competitor for more that 30 years. Ed brought passion and intensity to everything he did, whether it was business, leisure or philanthropic. Ed's mark on this city, this profession and on everyone he touched, will endure for many decades. The Cohen, Carmel and Roos Families and GVA Williams     GORDON-Edward S. Ed, if you are reading this, and we bet you are, we will miss you for the rest of our days. You were one of a kind to say the least, but most of all you were a friend. Amelia, Richard, Bradley, Jennifer     GORDON-Edward S. Donald J. Trump mourns the loss of his dear friend and colleague, Edward S. Gordon. Ed was a brilliant businessman and strategist who became enormously successful, yet also was a man of great principle and honor--a true gentleman! He will be greatly missed! My deepest condolences to his devoted wife Cheryl and the entire Gordon family on this very sad occasion.     GORDON-Edward S. To the entire Gordon family I wish to express my sorrow at the untimely loss of my friend and mentor Ed Gordon. My heartfelt sympathy goes out to Cheryl, Joan, Robin, Steve, Kenny and Allan. He gave me my start in the real estate business and I will always value his example. He will be sorely missed. Robert B. Emden     GORDON-Edward S. We will always remember the wonderful times that we shared with Ed and Cheryl, and we will forever cherish our friendship. Lynne and Mickey Tarnopol     GORDON-Edward. snippet: William Grimes reviews Orsay, on Upper East Side; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE Mortimer's era is officially over. And Orsay has put the period on the sentence. Glenn Bernbaum, Mortimer's notoriously highhanded and cranky owner, made sure the restaurant would not survive him. He arranged to have the name retired at his death, two years ago, and barred his former employees from operating a restaurant on the premises. Undeterred, they moved two blocks south and created Swifty's, where the spirit of Mortimer's has migrated with surprising ease, along with the Mortimer's ''in'' crowd. In the meantime, the partners who run La Goulue bought Mr. Bernbaum's building, transformed it into a French brasserie and, in a final dismantling of the Mortimer's legacy, are serving very good food. Mr. Bernbaum must be wincing at the very thought of it.
abstract: William Grimes reviews Orsay, on Upper East Side; photo (M)
