lead_paragraph: Blind Eye:
abstract: Blind Eye:  The Terrifying Story of a Doctor Who Got Away With Murder  By James B. Stewart.  Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $14.    A journalist tells the story of a doctor suspected of killing at least 35 hospital patients, and indicts the medical authorities who failed to protect the public. Last year our reviewer, Lance Morrow, called this a ''chillingly thorough and superbly matter-of-fact . . . reconstruction that has the fascination of an acutely observed and troubling novel.''    Elementals: Stories of Fire and Ice  By A. S. Byatt. Vintage International, $12.    A British writer whose work explores the intersection of aesthetics and morality spins tales in which stolid, blinkered Europeans from the North become either imprisoned or re-energized by the earthier South and the warmer-blooded people (mostly artists) who live there. In Byatt's eyes, it is an unforgivable crime not to be curious about a world ''full of light and life.'' ''Byatt's prose is capacious yet exquisite,'' Fernanda Eberstadt wrote in the Book Review in 1999, and this collection is infused with ''the throwaway gleams of a writer at the height of her powers.''    The Distance to the Moon:  A Road Trip Into the American Dream  By James Morgan. Riverhead, $12.95.    The author explores America's obsessive love affair with cars and car culture as he drives from Miami to Portland, Ore., in a shiny new Porsche. ''The human case for the automobile has never been more persuasively presented,'' Bruce McCall wrote here last year. I'm a Stranger Here Myself: Notes on Returning to America After Twenty Years Away, by Bill Bryson (Broadway, $14), is a collection of humorous dispatches written for a British newspaper about the author's bumpy re-entry into his native culture with his English wife and four children. ''The best columns are those in which the author discards his hapless persona and allows his natural impatience and intelligence out of their cages,'' Elizabeth Gleick said here in 1999.    True at First Light  By Ernest Hemingway.  Edited by Patrick Hemingway. Scribner, $13.    This fictional chronicle of an African safari, which was abandoned by Hemingway and edited by one of his sons, is a pale imitation of the writer's best work, James Wood said here last year. Nonetheless, ''there is a kind of mottled glamour, made up of bullying integrity and nonsense, of truth and falsity, which always makes the least of Hemingway's books compelling.''    1185 Park Avenue: A Memoir  By Anne Roiphe. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $13.    Avoiding sentimentality and self-pity in favor of an emotionally mature distance, the author tells of growing up Jewish in the 1940's and 50's with everything she could want but her parents' affection. ''Roiphe gives her memoir the dramatic vividness of a novel,'' Karen Lehrman wrote in these pages in 1999.    Apples From the Desert: Selected Stories  By Savyon Liebrecht. Feminist Press, $13.95.    This collection of 12 stories originally published in Israel focuses on the fault lines between secular and Orthodox Jews, bereft parents and their torn children. ''At her best, Liebrecht is the equal of far better-known Israeli authors like Amos Oz,'' Suzanne Ruta said here in 1998.    Mother of Pearl  By Melinda Haynes.  Washington Square/Pocket Books, $13.95.    This first novel revolves around a large cast of characters in sleepy Petal, Miss., in the 1950's, including Even Grade, a black orphan named for a road, and Valuable Korner, a fatherless white girl named after a real estate sign. Last year our reviewer, Roy Hoffman, admired the book's ''profuse and vigorous'' language.    George III: A Personal History  By Christopher Hibbert. Basic Books, $18.    As portrayed here, George III (1738-1820) was a churchgoing, monogamous, mostly competent ruler before going famously mad. His oldest son, however, George IV (1762-1830), the subject of Prince of Pleasure: The Prince of Wales and the Making of the Regency, by Saul David (Grove, $15), led the field in scandalous behavior at a time when London was the world's capital for debauchery. '' 'George III' and 'Prince of Pleasure' make a simply unputdownable theater of the personal and political absurd,'' Valentine Cunningham wrote here last year.    The Houdini Girl  By Martyn Bedford. Vintage Crime, $13.    After his Irish girlfriend dies in a mysterious train accident, a British magician discovers she led a double life and sets out to unravel her carefully hidden past. Last year our reviewer, Carey Harrison, called this ''a masterfully choreographed'' erotic thriller.    Poachers: Stories  By Tom Franklin. HarperPerennial, $12.    Set in lower Alabama, these mordant tales feature sympathetic good old boys stuck in bad situations, frayed marriages and dead-end jobs. ''With this satisfying collection'' Franklin ''establishes himself as one of the region's more interesting emerging voices,'' Bruce Barcott said here last year.   Scott Veale

snippet: Jessicï
lead_paragraph: 'This is big -- really big,'' said Bill Sarpalius, a former Texas congressman, taking in the scene at Boot Camp for Start-Ups, a seminar recently held in Manhattan and currently making its way around the country. While the Nasdaq was imitating sine waves on computer screens around the world, Sarpalius, like everyone else in sight, was networking wildly and conferencing on his cell phone. He was on the line with his board working out a merger with a rival while his employees were back at Lobbyforme.com, a Web site that, come May, will allow citizens to pool their resources and hire former congressmen as lobbyists. Getting voted out of office, he decided, was ''the best thing that ever happened. Now I'm part of a new frontier. There was the gold rush, the land rush and the oil boom. Now it's the Internet. I'm staking my claim.''

lead_paragraph: BOSTON food folk are bent on shaking off the lingering stigma of ''cold roast Boston'' and baked beans. And the crusade has spread to the suburbs. Over the last few years new-style bistros as distinctive as the towns they serve have been laying to rest those canards. All are run by owners determined to produce food that would do New York or West Coast restaurants proud without compromising the neighborliness and informality of the ''local.'' They've succeeded so well that these three bistros are now destinations in their own right. And then, of course, there is my favorite clam shack.

snippet: William Grimes Diner's Journal review of new lunch menu served in lounge of restaurant Daniel; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: No one goes to Daniel for home cooking, but there's a homey instinct behind a new lunch menu being served in the restaurant's lounge. It has its roots in Lyon, Daniel Boulud's hometown, where the cherished sub-bistros known as bouchons have pleased diners for generations by offering down-to-earth fare and a couple of house wines for a price that wouldn't buy an appetizer in Paris. Sometimes there's a menu, but more often the owner stops by the table and runs through a list of three or four entrees. The meal might start with a salad mixed at the table, followed by a plate of charcuterie and a pate that travels from table to table in the course of the evening.

lead_paragraph: Several times in each of the last few decades, Silicon Valley has been home to a truly big gamble. In 1984, the Apple Macintosh transformed the computer industry, but other high-stakes wagers like the Amiga or the Go Corporation have fizzled.
abstract: Several times in each of the last few decades, Silicon Valley has been home to a truly big gamble. In 1984, the Apple Macintosh transformed the computer industry, but other high-stakes wagers like the Amiga or the Go Corporation have fizzled.    In fact, most of the valley's big gambles have failed for setting goals that proved far too ambitious. In the early 1980's there was Trilogy, a premature effort to build an ultrafast mainframe computer. In the early 1990's, Microunity caught the valley's imagination with a microprocessor intended to be the standard for interactive cable systems, which failed to emerge.

snippet: Julia Szabo compares home of Pertab and Soolagmy Singh of Elmhurst, Queens, with the White House; photos (special section, Style & Entertaining) (part 2 of 2-part section) (L)
lead_paragraph: One cause of voter apathy in recent years must be a vague feeling on the part of many Americans that the White House has about as much in common with their house as, well, Bauhaus. To be sure, it is a rare species of residence: a house designed to withstand any calamity that could befall its occupants, and to stand ready to hold affairs of state with adequate calm. But the Executive Mansion is still a house: home to a family, site of festive meals, with a high-traffic kitchen, a spare room for guests and a well-kept lawn. As such, it's not radically different from an average middle-class American home, like the one owned by the Singh family of Elmhurst, Queens.
abstract: Julia Szabo compares home of Pertab and Soolagmy Singh of Elmhurst, Queens, with the White House; photos (special section, Style & Entertaining) (part 2 of 2-part section) (L)

snippet: Eric Asimov reviews Mombar, restaurant in Astoria, Queens (M)
lead_paragraph: STEINWAY STREET between 25th and 28th Avenues in Astoria, Queens, does not look, or smell, like a New York street. On warm evenings the air is flavored with sweet tobacco, as men, young and old, gather outside Middle Eastern cafes to smoke hookahs and drink tiny cups of thick coffee. Long robes and kaffiyehs are as common as Western dress. But perhaps the most unusual sight is the entrance to Mombar, a small Egyptian restaurant that opened about a month ago.

snippet: Patricia Brooks reviews restaurant at Bernard's Inn at Ridgefield in Ridgefield, Conn (M)
lead_paragraph: THE long-running Inn at Ridgefield is now Bernard's Inn at Ridgefield, with new ownership, new chef, staff and decor. This means a lighter, fresher look and a staff that is alert and attentive. Even more important are the beguiling menu and food befitting the 21st century. We appreciated extra touches like the fresh cut flowers on each table, the lagniappe served before dinner and delicious petit fours as a finale. One pleasant reminder of times past is the live piano music on Friday and Saturday evenings and at Sunday brunch.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Brasserie 8 1/2, Manhattan restaurant; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: MY vote for the hardest-working banana split in town goes to Brasserie 8 1/2. It's a strenuously conceptual dessert, a plateful of allusions, feints and inside jokes, the main one being the almost total absence of banana. From right to left, one encounters a small dome of caramelized banana on a quarter-size sable pastry disk, a medium-size puck of strawberry ice cream topped with strawberry slices and a large stack that begins with caramelized pineapple and ascends, in many chapters, through vanilla ice cream, almond sable, chocolate ice cream and chocolate syrup, with fascinating asides. If a split could sweat, this would be a three-towel production.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Wallse; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IT took a few twists and turns before Kurt Gutenbrunner found his way back to Austria. He intended to take the direct route, moving from Bouley, where he served as sous chef for five years, to the post of executive chef at Danube, David Bouley's ambitious, bejeweled shrine to the cooking of Austria-Hungary. When the project stalled, however, Mr. Gutenbrunner became restless and left. He took over the kitchen at Monkey Bar, putting a Viennese spin on the menu that never felt quite right, given the restaurant's roots in the New York of the 1930's and 40's. Now he has found a new setting in Wallse, a corner restaurant in the far West Village that he has turned into a modest showcase for the Austrian cooking he grew up with.

abstract: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.    Opera    ''LA BOHEME.'' Amato Opera. This company, in its 53rd season, stages its productions on modest but generally attractive sets, and uses reduced orchestrations and singers who can often be described as enthusiastic amateurs. But the company's work shows an evident devotion to opera and its composers, and the intimacy of its theater affords an experience of this music quite unlike that offered by the Met in the quasicinematic version of ''La Boheme'' on its stage. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, New Year's Eve at 7 p.m. Tickets: tonight and tomorrow, $25, $20 for the elderly and children under 12; New Year's Eve, $100 (Allan Kozinn).

snippet: Sarah Raper Laurenaudie interviews Versace fashion house ad director Andrea Tremolada, who describes his solo crossing of Atlantic ocean in homemade plane; photos (special section, Men's Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section)
lead_paragraph: Five hours into crossing the Atlantic in his wooden, single-engine plane, Andrea Tremolada began to have serious doubts whether he'd live to see the coast of Brazil. The steady drizzle that had followed his red Falco F.8L from Sal Island, off the coast of Senegal, suddenly turned into a convulsive thunderstorm. In seconds, his 22-foot plane shot from 8,000 feet to 15,000 feet and slammed back down. ''Those accelerations were breaking the plane,'' he said. ''And the cockpit was full of water. I looked at my watch, and it was 11:23, and I said, 'This is the time I am going down.'''
abstract: Sarah Raper Laurenaudie interviews Versace fashion house ad director Andrea Tremolada, who describes his solo crossing of Atlantic ocean in homemade plane; photos (special section, Men's Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section)

lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
abstract: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.    Opera    ''LA BOHEME.'' Amato Opera. This company, in its 53rd season, stages its productions on modest but generally attractive sets, and uses reduced orchestrations and singers who can often be described as enthusiastic amateurs. But the company's work shows an evident devotion to opera and its composers, and the intimacy of its theater affords an experience of this music quite unlike that offered by the Met in the quasi-cinematic version of ''La Boheme'' currently on its stage. Tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2:30 p.m., Amato Opera Theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village; (212) 228-8200. Tickets: $25; $20 for children under 12 and the elderly (Allan Kozinn).

snippet: William Grimes reviews Village, restaurant in Greenwich Village; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: SOME restaurants arrive with expectations. Village is one of them. The expectations swirl around Stephen Lyle, Village's owner and chef, who made his mark at Quatorze and the Odeon, restaurants that pulled off the difficult feat of serving top-quality food in a hip environment. Quatorze, which opened in 1984 and closed a decade later, was the bistro that showed how a bistro should be done, years ahead of the current bistro boom. The Odeon, like Dick Clark, is perpetually ageless and definitively downtown. I never had a bad meal at either place and therefore stepped into Village with soaring hopes.

snippet: Fred B Adelson reviews retrospective by contemporary figurative sculptor George Segal on view at Locks Gallery in Philadelphia; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: GEORGE SEGAL, a master of 20th-century figurative sculpture, has been living and working on what was once a poultry farm in South Brunswick for more than 50 years. His tableaux of contemporary American life made in his studio, a former chicken coop, bring together elements of both sculpture and painting, high art and consumer culture. No history of the Pop Art movement could be complete without a discussion of his assemblages. In the early 1960's, the innovative white plaster casts of ordinary people doing ordinary things in a realistic environment had earned Mr. Segal an international reputation. At their best, these sculptures are more than representations of anecdotal situations; they evoke feelings of ennui and alienation, reflecting a deep concern for the human condition.
abstract: Fred B Adelson reviews retrospective by contemporary figurative sculptor George Segal on view at Locks Gallery in Philadelphia; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: DESIGN has abandoned Socrates for Nietzsche. This is the take-away idea at the first edition of the National Design Triennial at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. No more pure geometric shapes. No more strict correspondences between form and function. No more efforts to refine materials and production methods to their pure Platonic essence. Instead, we behold room after room of dancing stars. Fluid shapes. Appetizing colors. Laughter in the dark. Flesh.

lead_paragraph: BY the time I got to the Halkin Hotel, a three-minute walk from Hyde Park Corner, it was midafternoon and I was wilting after a flurry of work earlier in the day. Tucked away on a quiet, pretty street feeding off a noisy, unpretty street, the 41-room hotel is unassuming and discreet. Look down to answer your cell phone, and you might miss it. But as the taxi pulled up, a smooth young man in a chic black suit suddenly materialized from inside the automatic glass doors to whisk my suitcase away and usher me inside.

Of course, I also was raised to believe that if you wear pajamas with elastic cuffs, your skin won't be able to breathe. But I have slept in sweat pants for years without clogging my pores.

lead_paragraph: Best Bet
abstract: Best Bet      The Nassau County Museum of Art sees beyond the brush and canvas to define art, long enough at least for ''Gardens as Art: An Autumn Landscape and Garden Spectacular.'' The nine-day show, through Oct. 22, gets under way on Saturday, transforming the Great Lawn of what was once the Frick estate off Northern Boulevard in Roslyn Harbor into a series of innovative gardens created by some of the leading landscape designers on the Island. In addition to the gardens, the show features a marketplace of garden ornaments, furniture and decorative objects; daily lectures, including, on Oct. 19,  ''Tea and Conversation With Martha Frick Symington Sanger,'' who will reminisce about her childhood at the family estate; music by the Venus Flute Ensemble, a quartet from the Juilliard School of Music, during the first weekend; and on Oct. 21 and 22, a Family Festival with the Big Apple Circus to Go. Visitors will also be able to explore the newly restored Marian Cruger Coffin Formal Garden (516) 625-9397.

lead_paragraph: I HANKER for pie. Specifically, a pie bursting with cherry filling, topped with a golden, sugary lattice, cooling behind the counter glass. There's bread pudding too, usually served with vanilla sauce, and there's a five-berry pie and good old American apple pie.
abstract: I  HANKER for pie. Specifically, a pie bursting with cherry filling, topped with a golden, sugary lattice, cooling behind the counter glass. There's bread pudding too, usually served with vanilla sauce, and there's a five-berry pie and good old American apple pie.    Or is it Dutch apple? This is, after all, De Nacht Wacht, or The Night Watch, a family-owned restaurant tucked inside the remains of an old general store in Sussex County. Barbara Schutz, born in the Netherlands, opened this place a year ago to bring her love of food and antiques together in one place. The interior of The Night Watch (the name is from the Rembrandt painting) is filled with chairs and tables, as it should be, and more besides: old farm and kitchen tools, knickknacks and vintage country furniture, enameled tin pitchers and cloudy bottles, framed pictures and quaint signs rescued from time. And all of it, barring the working furniture, is for sale.

lead_paragraph: From the most raked-over historical fields to the latest technology, scholars and researchers continually manage to ask new questions, rethink old verities and produce fresh insights. Arts & Ideas takes an occasional look at what some of today's thinkers -- the established as well as those who yearn to be -- are working on. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs and others may turn out to be dead ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

Flowers are a source of romantic inspiration, aesthetic meditation, perfumed essences and food. snippet: James Q Wilson Op-Ed article disputes findings of study of capital punishment cases by Columbia University Law School Prof James Liebman, which concluded that for approximately last two decades courts have found serious reversible error in large f...
lead_paragraph: For those who support capital punishment, as I do, the possibility that innocent people could be executed is profoundly disturbing. No human arrangement can guarantee perfection, but if perfection is not possible, then the number of errors ought to kept as low as possible. For that reason, it is worth studying ''Broken System: Error Rates in Capital Cases,'' the recent report by Professor James Liebman and others at the Columbia University Law School, especially since that document has stimulated an outpouring of media coverage.
abstract: James Q Wilson Op-Ed article disputes findings of study of capital punishment cases by Columbia University Law School Prof James Liebman, which concluded that for approximately last two decades courts have found serious reversible error in large fraction of cases they reviewed often involving weak defense attorneys and withholding of important evidence from juries; says what study really shows is how well courts shield accused (M)

Now it seems as if each huge new resort deliberately mimics some other place, wrapping itself in the veneer of an older, more elegant culture: Egypt of the pharaohs, Venice of the doges, Paris, even New York. I wanted to see if Las Vegas had lost its sense of itself.

lead_paragraph: YASMINA REZA rises early on Tuesdays because Monday is her only night off from appearing onstage in her new play, ''Trois Versions de la Vie,'' at the Theatre Antoine in Paris. A mother of two, with a movie director for a companion, she has a tight schedule. She speeds off to make tea, visibly humming with nervous energy. An English-French dictionary lies open on a table in her Left Bank apartment. She has been skimming British reviews of her new play, which has also just opened at the National Theater in London as ''Life x 3.''

snippet: Alternately hilarious, poignant and gory, this modern fairy tale that follows an aspiring nurse (Renee Zellweger), suffering from traumatic amnesia, to Los Angeles to win the love of her favorite soap-opera character is a contemporary ''Wizard of ...
lead_paragraph: ''Nurse Betty'' takes the most hackneyed dramatic ploy of soap opera, a case of amnesia, and spins it into an irresistibly heady mixture of sadness and hilarity. At its giddiest peaks the movie, directed by Neil LaBute, produces that shivery feeling when your heart melts but at the same moment you want to burst out laughing. This whimsical rose-colored fairy tale with tragic undercurrents suggests a contemporary ''Wizard of Oz'' for grown-ups. It is easily the finest American comedy since David O. Russell's ''Flirting With Disaster,'' another road movie that never ran out of poignantly funny surprises.
abstract: Alternately hilarious, poignant and gory, this modern fairy tale that follows an aspiring nurse (Renee Zellweger), suffering from traumatic amnesia, to Los Angeles to win the love of her favorite soap-opera character is a contemporary ''Wizard of Oz.'' Hollywood is the Emerald City. Greg Kinnear is the self-centered actor who plays her heart's desire on television. Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock are a sadly introspective hit man and his hot-headed protege who follow her across the country with intention to do harm. This may be the deepest and funniest American comedy since David O. Russell's ''Flirting With Disaster.'' — Stephen Holden

lead_paragraph: The pop charts last year were a game of rock, scissors, paper. Three very different forces were at work, each one briefly supplanting the other. There was the rock of rap-metal bands like Limp Bizkit and Kid Rock; the sharp, angular minimalist hip-hop that emerged from the South with J T Money and Juvenile; and the paper was the lightweight pop of the Backstreet Boys, 'N Sync, Britney Spears and Ricky Martin. Rock smashed scissors, paper smothered rock, scissors cut paper.
abstract: The pop charts last year were a game of rock, scissors, paper. Three very different forces were at work, each one briefly supplanting the other. There was the rock of rap-metal bands like Limp Bizkit and Kid Rock; the sharp, angular minimalist hip-hop that emerged from the South with J T Money and Juvenile; and the paper was the lightweight pop of the Backstreet Boys, 'N Sync, Britney Spears and Ricky Martin. Rock smashed scissors, paper smothered rock, scissors cut paper.     Bubbling beneath the surface of a pop world in which singles flourished and albums were undernourished were at least a dozen genres. Thanks to the success of ''Buena Vista Social Club,'' it was a banner year for Cuban music with releases from  Ibrahim Ferrer, Los Zafiros and Eliades Ochoa. Benefiting from the success of Lauryn Hill, a crop of soul divas sprouted, including Macy Gray, Angie Stone and Blandinna (Melky) Jean of Melky Sedeck. Bluegrass boomed, with musicians like Steve Earle turning to a genre flourishing thanks to the popularity of Alison Krauss and Bela Fleck, and alternative hip-hop emerged with enough bands to fill compilations like ''The Funky Precedent'' and ''Quannum Spectrum'' with quality nongangsta tracks.

abstract: NEW YORK    MANHATTAN: BUS PLAN  A Manhattan judge proposed yesterday that state lawyers hammer out a temporary compromise with a suspended bus company, New York Apple Tours, and allow drivers without violations to return to the road until a final determination about the company's license is made. The city suspended the company's license after one of its buses struck and killed a man in Manhattan on May 22. At the hearing yesterday, Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob asked both sides to meet on Friday to try to reach a compromise.   Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

snippet: Mark Bittman travel article on poor quality and quantity of food served on airline flights; notes many travelers are buying meals at fast-food restaurants in airport food courts to eat on plane or soon after disembarking; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: TRAVELING makes me hungry. I want comfort food when I'm bored and lonely, and exhaustion and enforced waiting combine to make me ravenous; only huge quantities of protein will do the trick. Anxiety brings a craving for calming carbohydrates. So the one good thing about sitting in a plane, where I'm almost always bored, lonely, exhausted and anxious, is that the fierce demands of my stomach keep me from worrying whether the mechanics remembered to check the flaps.

snippet: Arts Abroad column on retrospective at Jewish Museum in Vienna honoring life and work of illustrators Paul Peter Porges and wife Lucie; both were persecuted there during Nazi era; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: What really gets you is the red sweater with three white P's across the breast, the same hand-knit sweater a 12-year-old boy named Paul Peter Porges wore as he boarded a Kindertransport from Vienna to France on a wet, nasty night in March 1939, one step ahead of the Nazis. That this particular sweater has survived and is part of a retrospective honoring his life and work, along with that of his wife, Lucie, who also barely got out of Vienna alive, perhaps symbolizes what makes this exhibition compelling: the everyday details of life.
abstract: Arts Abroad column on retrospective at Jewish Museum in Vienna honoring life and work of illustrators Paul Peter Porges and wife Lucie; both were persecuted there during Nazi era; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: Israeli Leader Wins Fight Over Banking Nomination
abstract: Israeli Leader Wins Fight Over Banking Nomination  The Israeli cabinet, over the public objections of the finance minister, narrowly approved Prime Minister Ehud Barak's choice of a conservative central bank economist as the bank's next governor.    David Klein, who now heads the Bank of Israel's monetary affairs division, was endorsed in a 10-to-7 vote after a long afternoon of contentious debate that exposed stark economic policy divisions within Mr. Barak's center-left coalition.   [Page C2.]    A Friendlier Anti-Snoring Machine  A chronic snorer has been granted a patent for a device he contends will provide relief to serious snorers like himself. His invention, an attachment to the previously used ''continuous positive air pressure machine,'' makes that device more comfortable to wear during sleep. The inventor said half of those who are prescribed the machine stop using it because of discomfort.   [C2.]

lead_paragraph: The unexpected success of ''American Pie'' last summer, in which a fresh crop of young actors obsessed about losing their virginity, and an apple pie was rudely disturbed in the process, has accelerated the trend toward vulgar, borderline-tasteless comedy and has some shaking their heads. How low will Hollywood go to lure young people into theaters? The most recent flurry of tsk-tsking occurred with the release of ''Me, Myself and Irene,'' a Jim Carrey comedy that pokes fun at mental illness and the disabled and does brazen things to a cow and a chicken.

snippet: Devin Friedman article on development of suntan pill; University of Arizona Prof Mac Hadley and others in field explain (M)
lead_paragraph: People are willing to put up with almost anything to make themselves a different color. In order to get a bit darker, we're happy to lounge in claustrophobic boxes irradiating ourselves with carcinogenic light or liberally apply self-tanners that oxidize our epidermis like the flesh of a peeled apple. We strip off layers of skin with chemicals to make ourselves lighter, shoot lasers at our dark patches and spread thick ''blending'' makeup over our white spots. Dr. James Nordlund, an expert on the human pigmentary system, offers this explanation: ''People are weird.'' And he thinks we haven't yet begun to plumb the depths of our strange desires. Wait 10 or 15 years, he says, when we might walk into the drugstore, buy a cream that's able to flip our pigmenting mechanism on or off and get as dark or light as we want.
abstract: Devin Friedman article on development of suntan pill; University of Arizona Prof Mac Hadley and others in field explain (M)

abstract: Fourth of July      It would be hard to find an Independence Day celebration more Main Street, U.S.A. than the one staged every year at Mystic Seaport. The staff gets decked out in 19th-century Sunday best, Uncle Sam leads a parade through the grounds in his red, white and blue tails and top hat, and a roster of orators sound off on the significance of the day. The ceremonials are capped with the singing of ''America,'' the national anthem of the 1800's.

lead_paragraph: Best Bet
abstract: Best Bet      Balloons shaped like shopping bags, polar bears, bunnies and apples take flight in Waldbaum's Balloon and Music Festival in Shirley. While the 75 hot-air balloons that go up at 6:30 p.m. Friday and 6:30 a.m. and 6.30 p.m. Saturday and next Sunday give the event its special appeal, basically it's a family affair, with daytime activities like performances by the National Marionette Theater, a Paul Bunyan Lumberjack Show and a Fire Jump High Dive. The evenings feature concerts at 8 o'clock by Chubby Checker and Mary Wilson and the Supremes on Friday and the Beach Boys on Saturday, and the Summer X Jam Concert with BBMak, Bosson and Take 5 on Sunday. The festival is from 1 p.m. to 10 p.m. Friday and 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. Saturday and Sunday at Brookhaven-Calabro Airport on William Floyd Parkway (888) 994-6824.

snippet: David Lehman Bookend column on results of survey in which a dozen poets were asked to name their top 15 American poems of 20th century; the poems appear in book Best American Poetry 2000; criteria and selections discussed; list; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: OF the making of lists there is no end. Now that it is possible to speak of the 20th century as a whole, it seems irresistible to compile and swap lists of our favorite poems (or novels or plays or movies) of the last 100 years. Which works are indispensable? Which stand the best chance of enduring? Which do we simply like the best? Which have come to mean the most to us? To assemble a list of great 20th-century poems would, if it did nothing else, direct attention to important works. It might also stimulate discussion, even controversy. And as I conceived it, the project would record the taste of some of our leading poets surveying the monuments of what Henry Luce called the American Century.
abstract: David Lehman Bookend column on results of survey in which a dozen poets were asked to name their top 15 American poems of 20th century; the poems appear in book Best American Poetry 2000; criteria and selections discussed; list; drawing (M)

lead_paragraph: FRETTING over what to wear to her daughter's wedding, Ilene Beckerman experienced an instant of panic. ''Everybody remembers Princess Diana's wedding dress, but who remembers what her mother wore?'' she told herself soothingly. ''Nobody pays attention to the mother of the bride.''
abstract: FRETTING over what to wear to her daughter's wedding, Ilene Beckerman experienced an instant of panic. ''Everybody remembers Princess Diana's wedding dress, but who remembers what her mother wore?'' she told herself soothingly. ''Nobody pays attention to the mother of the bride.''    Ms. Beckerman knows better, of course. Taut as a snare drum, smooth and polished as an apple, the mother of the bride these days is apt to be as raptly scrutinized and cooed over as the bride herself. With that in mind, Ms. Beckerman, who chronicles her experiences in a new book, ''Mother of the Bride'' (Algonqin, $17.95), which she wrote and illustrated, resolved not to fade into the marquetry at her own daughter's wedding. Bypassing the discreet beige that more conventional women trot out for such occasions, she chose a decollete number that riveted all eyes to her chest.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Bridges restaurant in Bridgehampton, Long Island; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: MUCH like a mirage, the too-good-to-be-true Bridges in Bridgehampton is in the process of revving up for its first summer. It is an airy, spacious place of majestic arches, massive beams, graceful chandeliers, a wall of French doors, tiny candles and glorious music. It serves healthy portions of both robust and refined dishes at very unHamptons prices. With a three-course $19.95 fixed price dinner, the Island's only Sunday gospel brunch (a drink, entree and dessert affair) for $24.95, soups and desserts for $5 and entrees as low as $16, Bridges is nearly every diner's dream: it looks expensive, but isn't. There are few local restaurants this sophisticated and attractive, especially in the Hamptons, that offer comparable value.
abstract: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Bridges restaurant in Bridgehampton, Long Island; photo (M)

lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
abstract: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.     * FIONA APPLE, Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, Manhattan, (212) 496-7070. Fiona Apple's last New York appearance, at Roseland, ended ignominiously when the singer and songwriter, unable to hear herself in the monitors, threw a fit of agony so long and difficult to watch it made ''Saving Private Ryan'' seem like a laugh fest. Maybe her behavior wasn't professional, but she did it for the sake of her music, which is too complicated to be sacrificed to a poor sound system. Now she will attempt her gorgeously, gracefully tangled songs in a different setting. Here's hoping that the sound system cooperates and, if not, that she rides the wave. Tonight at 8; admission is $27.50 (Ann Powers).

Now, thanks to new farming techniques, fresh sea beans are becoming more abundant and available.

lead_paragraph: YEARS ago, before I moved to Santa Fe, I remember asking a resident what winters were like there. She said they were wonderful and added with a smile, ''We like to keep that a secret.'' Alas, for locals who might want to keep a good thing to themselves, the secret has long been out, and for at least the last century and a half, trappers and traders, sightseers and skiers have known that Santa Fe winters are pretty special.

abstract: WEST FARMS  A Diversity of Media From Black Artists      ''In the Black'' refers to the race of the 10 artists in the show of that name, at the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery, and perhaps to their desired balance sheet. But these artists, all of them from New York City or living here now, work in a variety of colors and media. The variety ranges from photomontage to traditional oil paint, from found object assemblage installations to spray paint. Among the pieces is ''Mourning Memory I'' (below), a 1998 mixed-media work by Terry Boddie.

lead_paragraph: Cabbage reigns where fear presides; at least that has been its history. In times of scarcity -- as the ''rose'' of various famines, or simply as one of the few green vegetables that could endure long, cold winters -- cabbage has always been king.
abstract: Cabbage reigns where fear presides; at least that has been its history. In times of scarcity -- as the ''rose'' of various famines, or simply as one of the few green vegetables that could endure long, cold winters -- cabbage has always been king.    Even its mythical origins attest to pain and suffering. Ancient Greek legend holds that King Lycurgus of the Edones was driven mad by his enemy Dionysus, the god of wine, and accidentally murdered his own son. On the ground where Lycurgus's tears had fallen, the first cabbages grew.

snippet: A la Carte column on Long Island dining scene reviews Sweetwaters Bar and Bistro in Hauppauge (S)
lead_paragraph: FIRST impressions deceive at the new Sweetwaters Bar and Bistro in Hauppauge. Knowledgeable diners will notice that the restaurant, at 470 Wheeler Road (631-348-0808), has a small dark dining room and a big handsome bar room, holds daily happy hours from 4 to 7 p.m. and promotes disc jockey entertainment every Thursday, Friday and Saturday. A look into the woody dining room -- with its pressed tin ceiling, overhead fans, bare shiny floors, dome lighting and photos of bygone American roadhouse eateries (my favorite is Posey's Topless Oysters) -- reveals burgers in baskets, butter patties in foil wrappers and ketchup in bottles. All this leads one to conclude that Sweetwaters is much more about drinking than eating, that it is a burger and Bud, big television, loud music hangout.

snippet: Roberta Smith reviews work of Alice Neel in traveling exhibit now at Whitney Museum; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Alice Neel could be witheringly blunt. ''Art is not as stupid as human conversation,'' she was once quoted as saying. I wrote it down and pinned it up at my desk, struck by its weirdness. In its unequivocal dismissal of daily discourse, Neel's remark gives one a glimpse of a certain darkness: the misanthropy and self-protective brutality that, along with more positive instincts, may be part of the commitment to being an artist.

lead_paragraph: By 1871 and the brief and bloody Parisian uprising called the Commune, photography had become part of life and, as Mathew Brady's pictures of the American Civil War had shown, a deeply affecting means of showing destruction and death. The Musee d'Orsay has had the good idea of hanging a show of photographs taken in Paris during the Commune flanked by a small exhibition, "Courbet et la Commune," Gustave Courbet having been the one great painter deeply involved politically and artistically. Prison, ruin and exile were his rewards.

snippet: Andy Grundberg reviews selection of photography books; drawings (M)
lead_paragraph: If economists ever need a new measure to judge the health of the economy, I would propose a revamped G.N.P. -- the new abbreviation standing for Gross Number of Photography books published per year. By this yardstick the economy must be in fine fettle, because publishers here and abroad have put into print a vast array of books of photographs this season. Quality has not always kept pace with quantity (some new volumes seem to have no discernible audience except the author's immediate family), but the market suggests that photographs are an inexhaustible source of curiosity and pleasure in today's opticentric world.

This year from next Friday to Sunday guests will see six new films that are scheduled to open in theaters in the late spring and early summer.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Crazy Dog restaurant in Westhampton Beach, Long Island (M)
lead_paragraph: QUESTION: when is a diner not a diner? Answer: when it's the Crazy Dog in Westhampton Beach. No wonder its owners don't want their restaurant to be called a diner any more. Yes, that's what it looks like from outside. In fact, come to think of it, the inside of this gleaming l950's Art Deco spot seems like the Mercedes of diners. But how many diners have a heralded Johnson and Wales-trained chef in the kitchen, a Wine Spectator award on the wall and a rose on every table? How many diners have etched-glass partitions separating their booths, white linen-covered tables and their own pastry chef (the chef and co-owner Eric Rifkin's wife, Nicole)? And how many diners charge $20 or more for all but 4 of their 18 a la carte evening entrees?
abstract: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Crazy Dog restaurant in Westhampton Beach, Long Island (M)

headline.main: Looks Like a Diner, but Don't Call It One

lead_paragraph: IF ''grill and bar'' conjures up dank, sticky corners and lardy burgers, perhaps Trinity has chosen its name unwisely. Or perhaps with its classically elegant decor and a few interesting variations on familiar themes -- pizzas, pasta, salads, burgers and main dishes -- Trinity seeks to reconstruct the concept of the neighborhood bar. For this restaurant is certainly something more: it is a welcoming place that draws family groups, which no doubt appreciate the menu's range, providing pizza or hamburgers for the young set and something a bit more sophisticated for adults.
abstract: IF ''grill and bar'' conjures up dank, sticky corners and lardy burgers, perhaps Trinity has chosen its name unwisely. Or perhaps with its classically elegant decor and a few interesting variations on familiar themes -- pizzas, pasta, salads, burgers and main dishes -- Trinity seeks to reconstruct the concept of the neighborhood bar. For this restaurant is certainly something more: it is a welcoming place that draws family groups, which no doubt appreciate the menu's range, providing pizza or hamburgers for the young set and something a bit more sophisticated for adults.     A longtime winner and the best appetizer we sampled, Sizzle Shrimps proved true to their name. Arriving in a hot ovenproof dish, five jumbos shimmered in a sauce of butter, white wine, lemon and lots of garlic, with toasted pignolis and small pieces of smoky pancetta providing crunch to this fragrant dish. A spicy red dipping sauce sparked a huge pile of tender rings of calamari merely dusted with corn meal, a pleasing change from the heavy batter armor that usually encases shrimps.

lead_paragraph: INTERMEZZO has gone big time. The Fort Salonga storefront trattoria has opened a stylish second restaurant at one of the Island's busiest intersections, hired Roland Iadanza, a highly regarded chef who worked at Bruzell's in Great Neck for the past 11 years, and is serving more sophisticated, upscale dishes.
abstract: INTERMEZZO has gone big time. The Fort Salonga storefront trattoria has opened a stylish second restaurant at one of the Island's busiest intersections, hired Roland Iadanza, a highly regarded chef who worked at Bruzell's in Great Neck for the past 11 years, and is serving more sophisticated, upscale dishes.     Gone are the calzones, many of the pastas, the Neapolitan and Sicilian pizzas, half the brick-oven pizzette and most of the Marsala, francaise and Sorrentino dishes. They have been replaced by creative selections like garlic-crusted shrimp dipped in tempura batter and fresh crumbs, and hand-rolled shrimp and sea scallop cannelloni broccolini and tomato confit in a porcini champagne sauce.

snippet: Barry Singer profiles orchestrator Luther Henderson, 81, whose latest project is evening of Duke Ellington music re-orchestrated for Orchestra of St Luke's, conducted by Simon Rattle, at Carnegie Hall; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ORCHESTRATORS rarely receive marquee billing. Luther Henderson knows this as well as anyone. More than 25 Broadway musicals, a good many more television shows and untold numbers of club acts and recording sessions have used his distinctive talents for more than 50 years. Few ever acknowledged his name prominently. But that is the lot of the orchestrator-arranger who labors behind the scenes to construct instrumental settings that animate the music of others.

snippet: Joanne Starkey reviews Maguro, Japanese restaurant in Roslyn, LI; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IS Maguro the most expensive restaurant on the Island?'' asked the woman on the phone. ''We spent more there than at Panama Hatties,'' she said. That is easy to do when sushi assortments cost $30 to $70, the majority of hot entrees are $35 or more and appetizers (most in the teens) go as high as $25. The only way that reader escaped with next week's grocery money was by ordering a few hand rolls. (There are pitfalls here, too. The dragon roll is $20. It goes for $7 to $7.50 at nearby Japanese restaurants.)

lead_paragraph: IS it too much to expect the National Design Museum to show a little design now and then? Finally Cooper-Hewitt has taken the plunge. With the first edition of its National Design Triennial the museum brings us real, living design. Not the history of design; not the sociology, anthropology, psychology, theory, politics or economics of design. Not Good Design, Green Design or Universal Design. Just Design, the whole field of American Design and nothing but Design.

lead_paragraph: IN a world where nearly everything seems to be getting miniaturized, the new I.B.M. Thinkpad T20 portable computer is traveling in the other direction. If it were any larger, I.B.M. could have equipped this impressively redesigned laptop with folding legs and offered it as a card table.
abstract: IN a world where nearly everything seems to be getting miniaturized, the new I.B.M. Thinkpad T20 portable computer is traveling in the other direction. If it were any larger, I.B.M. could have equipped this impressively redesigned laptop with folding legs and offered it as a card table.    It would be an expensive card table, to be sure, given that the fastest model starts at about $4,000, not counting the broad array of options that I.B.M. is offering for it. But hey, thanks to the games built into the Windows operating system, this would be a card table that came with its own game of solitaire.

snippet: Betsy Rubiner article on Garst Farm Resort, working farm and resort in Iowa; photos; map; Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev visited farm in 1959, at height of cold war, to witness wonders of modern American agriculture (M)
lead_paragraph: GARST FARM RESORTS looks like a classic Iowa homestead, but it occupies a unique place in history: Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union visited in 1959 in an effort to improve his country's agriculture. A hybrid, as its name suggests, the farm resort is a true agricultural operation that takes overnight guests and offers activities like riding, fishing and hiking. It's a form of agritainment, or agritourism -- a growing sideline for struggling family farmers and small rural towns.

lead_paragraph: LILAC inhabits a dollhouse of a room, just 42 seats packed into a former cigar store not many steps from downtown Millburn's best-known landmark, the Paper Mill Playhouse. Open since October, it already seems to have replaced the late 40 Main Street (now known as Cafe Main, and by some accounts less ambitious) as the destination of choice for theatergoers in search of serious food. lead_paragraph: IT'S new. It's French. And Mitchell Hauser, the chef and owner of Barney's in Locust Valley, is in the kitchen. These are a few of the reasons crowds have been packing Aix-en-Provence since it opened last month. But it is the food that brings them back.
abstract: IT'S new. It's French. And Mitchell Hauser, the chef and owner of Barney's in Locust Valley, is in the kitchen. These are a few of the reasons crowds have been packing Aix-en-Provence since it opened last month. But it is the food that brings them back.    The newcomer is in the attractive, pale mint-green and white building near Huntington harbor that formerly housed Mediterraneo. The interior does not have the cozy, romantic charm of Barney's and is in fact a bit stark. The light mushroom-colored walls are interrupted only by a few leaf-shaped white plates, a large framed mirror and a corner cupboard of curios. Country prints on shades and curtains add the only touch of color.

lead_paragraph: First we hated her for marrying Paul. She wasn't beautiful enough; she wasn't famous; she was American, for heaven's sake. Later we hated her for breaking up the Beatles (with Yoko's help), then joining her husband's new band when it was clear she couldn't sing, and wasn't she just a little too self-righteous about those vegetarian cookbooks and her work in animal rights? Then, two years ago last month, she died of breast cancer at the age of 56 and we made her a saint.

lead_paragraph: IN the daytime, Cafe Antico spills over with natural light. At night, however, the rooms are rendered in chiaroscuro, which indeed suggests the antique cafes across the Tiber. snippet: Ben Brantley reviews Richard II and Coriolanus, two plays, in repertory, by William Shakespeare, presented by Brooklyn Academy of Music; Jonathan Kent directs; Ralph Fiennes takes title role in both plays; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: If anyone could elevate petulance to the status of tragic flaw, Ralph Fiennes would seem to be the man. Throughout his fertile career in movies as the bluestocking's heartthrob, he has consistently found the combustibility in being sullen, taciturn and socially ill at ease. Think of those unhappy adulterers he played in ''The English Patient'' and ''The End of the Affair,'' in which he struck erotic sparks just by peevishly knitting his brow.

snippet: Karen Schoemer interviews pop singer Joan Osborne, who comments on new album, her first in five years; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE woman who greets you in front of a Manhattan soul food joint is not someone you would recognize. She is tall and imposing, beautiful but remote. She wears slender black stretch capris and a chic blue three-quarter-sleeve gingham shirt with matching decorative eyeshades. Her posture is so perfect she could balance books on her head; her cheeks have a spa-fresh glow. Demure honey ringlets frame her face. She tells you that this home-cooking place is a bit crowded and noisy for her liking; she would prefer the upscale French boite across the street. She glides into a booth, tucks her Bebe shopping bag under the table, orders a cappuccino -- no food today; she is staying slim for some forthcoming television appearances -- and fixes you with a humorless, rather unhelpful stare. You feel perplexed, a little thrown off. You look over her shoulder, half expecting a wild-haired, grinning, explosive, bluejeans-clad hippie babe to leap out from behind a pillar and rescue you. You're not sure what to say to this creature. How about: Nice to meet you -- now where's Joan Osborne?
abstract: Karen Schoemer interviews pop singer Joan Osborne, who comments on new album, her first in five years; photo (M)

snippet: Finnish soprano Karita Mattila discusses her career and new role in Fidelio at Metropolitan Opera; interview; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: After a recent midday rehearsal for the new Metropolitan Opera production of Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' which opens tonight, the glamorous soprano Karita Mattila, dressed in casual slacks and sneakers, came bounding into the company's press room for an interview, beaming with the hearty, dimpled bloom of the Finnish farm girl she once was. In her shoulder bag she carried the opera's score along with apples, raw carrots and a bottle of spring water to keep her going on a busy day. Even in her soprano-at-work mode Ms. Mattila, who recently turned 40, looked stunning.

snippet: Nora Ephron article on what she has learned about entertaining and preparing delicious, yet simple, dinner-party dishes from Lee Bailey; photos; recipes (special section, Style & Entertaining) (part 2 of 2-part section) (L)
lead_paragraph: I think I learned almost everything I know about having people to dinner from Lee Bailey. This was long before he began writing cookbooks and, through them, influencing thousands of readers and a generation of cookbook writers. When I first met him, in the late 60's, he was a designer, and he lived in the East 40's in a duplex that was one of those places you walked into and wanted to live in; everyone felt this way. Every single object in it was simple and beautiful. The glasses were beautiful. The wooden-handled knives and forks were beautiful. The seersucker napkins were beautiful, and what's more, they didn't have to be ironed. Everything was white, or beige, or sometimes gray, and fantastically easy on the eyes. In fact, right around the time I met Lee, Geraldine Stutz walked into Lee's apartment and wanted to live in it so badly that she hired him to open a small shop at Henri Bendel, the department store she was running at the time; as a result, I was able to buy the very glasses and knives and forks and seersucker napkins I had seen at Lee's, and before long almost everything I too owned was white, or beige, or sometimes gray.
abstract: Nora Ephron article on what she has learned about entertaining and preparing delicious, yet simple, dinner-party dishes from Lee Bailey; photos; recipes (special section, Style & Entertaining) (part 2 of 2-part section) (L)

snippet: Jacqueline Friedrich Choice Tables review of 'bouchons,' traditional restaurants in Lyon, city long considered capital of French gastronomy; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: LONG considered France's capital of gastronomy, Lyon is blessed with culinary history as rich as its extraordinary produce. Not only does it have a galaxy of starred restaurants but it also has styles of eating unique to it: from the cooking of its ''mothers'' (the city has always been known for its restaurants run by women, and often named for them, as in La Mere Brazier) to the ''machons'' (now translated as an informal meal) that fed its silk workers, to its ''bouchons,'' perhaps its most venerable -- and arguably its most lovable -- gastronomic institution.

abstract: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.     CLAUDIA ACUNA, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 242-1785. Ms. Acuna, from Chile, is a new jazz singer with a debut record on Verve; she came up through the group of musicians who work at Smalls and has that gang's air of bohemian living-for-art that can produce, over time, great jazz performers. She is still developing, but her voice has a strong, unglossy musicality; the young New York jazz scene will be here cheering her on. Sets through Sunday are at 9 and 11 p.m., with a 12:30 set tonight and tomorrow night; cover charge is $20 tonight and tomorrow night, $10 on Sunday; $10 minimum all nights (Ben Ratliff).

snippet: Ben Ratliff comment on need for thriving independent-label record business to bring forth fresh musical ideas; photos (S)
lead_paragraph: MOST big-picture conversations about jazz these days come down to the same question: how can it become important again? The answer has to be more than once-every-five-years phenomena like Cassandra Wilson or Diana Krall. Jazz needs what rock has had since the 80's, an organized proliferation of termitelike hipster activity wherever there are young people playing and listening. There needs to be better music education. There need to be more clubs booking jazz where people under 25 feel welcome. And there needs to be a thriving independent-label record business, one that plots the daily graph of where jazz musicians are heading.

lead_paragraph: I have three business trips looming in the next five weeks. In addition to the usual arrangements -- plane reservations, hotel reservations, car rental, driving directions -- I find myself worrying about one thing more: Will there be access to a fax machine at about 5 o'clock Eastern Standard Time, so my third grader can fax me his homework?
abstract: I have three business trips looming in the next five weeks. In addition to the usual arrangements -- plane reservations, hotel reservations, car rental, driving directions -- I find myself worrying about one thing more: Will there be access to a fax machine at about 5 o'clock Eastern Standard Time, so my third grader can fax me his homework?    There's a trend at our house when it comes to business travel. When my husband does it, someone back home always gets sick. Bruce was in Vienna when our older son was ordered to spend an immobile weekend on the couch because of an inflammation of his hip, and he was in San Jose, Calif., when that same son spent another weekend on the same couch because of a broken leg, so there was a lot of consulting and consoling done long distance.

snippet: David Brooks article desribes Bethesda, Md, one of may ritzy areas filling up with urbanites who swore they would never live in suburbia; says that to make them feel at home, retailers are rapidly turning suburbia into SoHo; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: If drug dealers drove minivans, this is the kind they'd drive. I'm in a black-on-black, top-of-the-line Dodge Grand Caravan ES, with phat spoilers, muscle grillwork, road-hugging fog lights and 10 Infinity speakers blasting out alternative rock. I'm in my element weaving through the suburban streetscape of Bethesda, Md. I'm hunting for a parking spot, passing by the Ancient Rhythms furniture gallery, the Outrage Cafe and Terra Cognita, a Material Culture-type store that sells tribal rugs, folk art and kilims. Parking is supposed to be easy in the suburbs, but it's always tough in a retail hub like Bethesda. My eyes narrow with that sharp, hungry look I used to get when I lived in Manhattan, hunting for an apartment or on rainy evenings desperate for a cab. Finally, I spot an empty space up the street in front of Three Dog Bakery, which makes fat-free apple-oatmeal biscuits, cheese and herb treats and gourmet carob chips -- for dogs.

snippet: Kristin Hohenadel article recalls creative uses of food, feasts or dinner table settings to convey passion, love, lust or other emotions in films; focuses on Roland Joffe's new film Vatel, Chocolat by Lasse Hallstrom and Fina Torres's Woman on Top...
lead_paragraph: IN the scentless, flavorless language of film, the dinner table is often used as an excuse to assemble the cast: it becomes the stage for spilling secrets, for acting out ancient dramas and measuring loyalties by shifts in appetite. Take the ritual Sunday dinners in Ang Lee's ''Eat Drink Man Woman'' (1994), or the freighted family gatherings in the films of Woody Allen. ''What's Cooking?,'' one of four food-centered movies coming this fall, tells its story of multicultural Los Angeles through four intersecting Thanksgiving feasts, their changing turkey recipes a metaphor for families struggling not to break apart.

AISLERS SET, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3055. The pop-savvy homecrafters swelling the ranks of indie rock auteurism are mostly male, with women sometimes providing support and winsome vocals. But Amy Linton, a singer and a producer, fits right in with the men in bands like Apples in Stereo and the Pastels. Her rough-hewn but smooth-minded arrangements make her songs, which expand on the fantasy of a well-educated young woman, more than just another round of confession. A slew of similarly charming indie-pop bands joins Aislers Set tonight, including Girlfrendo, Sportique, Comet Gain, Steward, and Toulouse. Tomorrow at 8 p.m.; tickets are $8 in advance, $10 day of show (Ann Powers).

Olga Borodina in the title role gives a searing account of the last act, with passion in every flicker of vocal color or phrasing; she is joined by Neil Shicoff as Don Jose. Rene Pape is all proud, suave maleness as Escamillo, and Norah Amsellem provides a touching account of Micaela's prayer. Franco Zeffirelli's production fills the stage with animals and extras. Bertrand de Billy conducts. Tomorrow at 1: 30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, (212) 362-6000. Standing room tickets only at $12 and $16 (Paul Griffiths).

snippet: Ben Ratliff article on popular success of jazz singer Diana Krall; notes Krall, who relies on standard songs from 50's, has shed dated mannerisms of jazz's past while still milking its aura; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Each era's important jazz singers amplify the state of the music: how far it has come, how much it is appreciated. In the 40's, the trace of an uncouth honk in Billie Holiday's voice reminded her audience of jazz's demimonde roots. In the 50's, the virtuosity of Sarah Vaughan implied that jazz had become one of the fine arts. The strident rip in an Abbey Lincoln performance embodied jazz in the 60's -- politically ambitious, its structure undergoing major tremors. Diana Krall's dusky, deadpan contralto with its hairline cracks and her studious and tasteful swing might be jazz in 2000. It's gentle but firm, ready to negotiate with popular culture to be accepted through any possible doorway -- as jazz, pop, cabaret, whatever. And its thick layer of emotional neutrality serves to protect it from rejection.
abstract: Ben Ratliff article on popular success of jazz singer Diana Krall; notes Krall, who relies on standard songs from 50's, has shed dated mannerisms of jazz's past while still milking its aura; photo (M)

snippet: Terry Teachout reviews recently released CDs that reveal pianist Erroll Garner and trumpeter Harry James as hard-swinging jazzmen; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IN jazz as in the other arts, worldly success can be a decidedly mixed blessing. As the critic Max Harrison has pointed out, ''People do not object to artists deserving success -- only to their getting it.'' The bigger the triumph, the snarkier the reaction, at least among those who mistakenly believe there is an inverse relationship between accessibility and quality. From Louis Armstrong to Diana Krall, talented musicians lucky enough to crack the code of popular taste without compromising their art in the process have invariably found themselves fending off flying brickbats. Some are flung by prissy colleagues who think jazz should be packaged in plain brown wrappers, others by critics who review reputations instead of music.

lead_paragraph: For anyone venturing north of New York City with contemporary art in mind, two destinations are not to be missed this summer. Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y., just south of Newburgh, is presenting recent works by the English sculptor Andy Goldsworthy, and the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., has mounted a three-decade retrospective of the works of the Russian conceptualist Ilya Kabakov, including paintings, drawings and installations. You could take in both shows in a day if you set out early, but give yourself more time. One requires a lot of walking, the other a lot of reading; both are worth the effort.

lead_paragraph: IT was Shakespeare who pointed out that newborns ''are made and molded of things past,'' and three concerts this week prove that so-called early music can still speak to us with modern eloquence. It is, indeed, Music of Shakespeare's World that the Ensemble Galilei is taking to Sarah Lawrence College today at 4 p.m.
abstract: IT was Shakespeare who pointed out that newborns ''are made and molded of things past,'' and three concerts this week prove that so-called early music can still speak to us with modern eloquence. It is, indeed, Music of Shakespeare's World that the Ensemble Galilei is taking to Sarah Lawrence College today at 4 p.m.    ''Composers from Mendelssohn to Brubeck have written music associated with Shakespeare's plays,'' said Carolyn Anderson Surrick, one of the six women in the group, who plays the viola da gamba, ''but we were looking for the popular music of the day and played through hundreds of tunes searching for jigs, lute songs, reels and country dances that might have accompanied the dramas. We found an Irish lament, for instance, that speaks perfectly to Hamlet's Ophelia when played on Scottish small pipes, and 'Apples in Winter,' a traditional jig that fits perfectly with 'The Winter's Tale.' With these and some original pieces, too, we honor the Bard and his words. From the plays and the poetry, from the tragedy and the laughter, we draw lines from Shakespeare's world to our own, and listening carefully, one can hear how each of the original compositions reveals where our worlds meet.''

headline.main: Ensemble's Concerts Honor Shakespeare

lead_paragraph: IT'S perhaps an understatement to say that the films of Peter Greenaway are not fashionable at the moment. The 1980's were the director's moment in the art-film spotlight -- specifically, the period bounded by ''The Draughtsman's Contract'' (1982), whose Restoration-era cruelty was interpreted as a sneak attack on Thatcherite England, and ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' (1989), which summed up the whole glittery decade as a Jacobean revenge melodrama set in a swank restaurant.

lead_paragraph: AFTER a few visits to the Freelance Cafe and Wine Bar, you begin to realize that what seems simply casual is in fact meticulously orchestrated. The Freelance Cafe, which started in 1989, is part of Xaviar's restaurant group, a no-reservations, no-dress-code contrast to two fine-dining establishments named Xaviar's (one next door and the other in a country club in Garrison, N.Y., offering weekend wine dinners) plus an enormous chophouse called Restaurant X in Congers, N.Y.
abstract: AFTER a few visits to the Freelance Cafe and Wine Bar, you begin to realize that what seems simply casual is in fact meticulously orchestrated. The Freelance Cafe, which started in 1989, is part of Xaviar's restaurant group, a no-reservations, no-dress-code contrast to two fine-dining establishments named Xaviar's (one next door and the other in a country club in Garrison, N.Y., offering weekend wine dinners) plus an enormous chophouse called Restaurant X in Congers, N.Y.     Such a place as this could easily get away with filling its assigned role without necessarily taking on a life of its own. In fact, New Jersey and New York are littered with small places that combine the foods and attitudes of American cafes, French bistros and Italian trattorias. But how many of them feature local artwork that changes every couple of months, offer small and large plates instead of appetizers and entrees, or make a point of serving dinner at the bar?

But for far too many older Americans, the so-called Golden Years are tarnished by diseases that seriously undermine the quality of those extra decades -- diseases that with tools now at hand are usually preventable, postponable or detectable at a curable stage.

This is the realm of snacks like tartines and rillettes, salads and savory tarts, and one of most delicious of all: the croque-monsieur.

snippet: Ben Brantley reviews House Arrest, Anna Deavere Smith's new one-woman show, whose subtitle is A Search for the American Character in and Around the White House, Past and President; it is presented by Joseph Papp's Public Theater; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: The choice of ringmaster, in any case, couldn't be better. Studs Terkel, the grand old man of oral history, shows up with a shuffling, lopsided walk, an Olympian laugh and a flair for the dramatic gesture, to usher in ''House Arrest,'' Anna Deavere Smith's wide-ranging and unwieldy consideration of the circus that is the American presidency. Actually that's Mr. Terkel as channeled by Ms. Smith, who is famous for her one-woman shows in which she portrays an assortment of real people whom she has interviewed to create mosaic portraits of the state of a nation. Ms. Smith's theater pieces have often been compared to Mr. Terkel's books, and the melding of the writer and the performance artist here seems a fitting act of homage.
abstract: Ben Brantley reviews House Arrest, Anna Deavere Smith's new one-woman show, whose subtitle is A Search for the American Character in and Around the White House, Past and President; it is presented by Joseph Papp's Public Theater; photo (M)

snippet: Kristin Hohenadel article on films that reveal summer's dark side; photos (M)g
lead_paragraph: IN the Prague summer of 1994, during a heat wave unrivaled in 200 years, nude sunbathers posed in their front yards and old ladies in transparent nighties cruised the streets. I was stuck in a city that had not yet embraced deodorant or air-conditioning, and whose hardware stores had run out of fans. One Saturday afternoon in the midst of this evil swelter, I got stuck in the elevator. Visible through the open cage, I hoped a neighbor would soon wander out in his underwear to check the mail or take the dog for a walk.
abstract: Kristin Hohenadel article on films that reveal summer's dark side; photos (M)g

lead_paragraph: THE Polish conductor serves his passengers coffee a half-hour before the night train from Berlin pulls into Krakow's main station. lead_paragraph: FROM time to time I'm asked to give tastings for groups of people who don't necessarily know much about wine. Normally, I like to use 12 wines -- 6 reds and 6 whites -- all from different parts of the world. Each red wine will be made from a different grape: syrah, cabernet sauvignon, pinot noir and others. But the white wines will all be chardonnays: one from the United States, one from France, possibly one from Italy, and the rest, perhaps, from South Africa, Israel and Australia.
abstract: FROM time to time I'm asked to give tastings for groups of people who don't necessarily know much about wine. Normally, I like to use 12 wines -- 6 reds and 6 whites -- all from different parts of the world. Each red wine will be made from a different grape: syrah, cabernet sauvignon, pinot noir and others. But the white wines will all be chardonnays: one from the United States, one from France, possibly one from Italy, and the rest, perhaps, from South Africa, Israel and Australia.    With the chardonnays, I try to show how important soil, weather, viticulture and winemaking skills are in determining what a wine is really like.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Cafe Randazzo, pizza and pasta restaurant in Glen Cove, Long Island (M)
lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a time, Cafe Randazzo in Glen Cove was one of the hundreds of look-alike, taste-alike pizza and pasta restaurants that dot Long Island. No more. On a recent visit, pizza, which more than any single dish built Cafe Randazzo, was a no-show. What was a very basic, red sauce, predictable Italian hangout behind a McDonald's, off Glen Street, has become a sophisticated, upscale venue. It is now the scene of $75-a-person wine dinners and special-occasion celebrations. A recent six-course wine feast featured dishes like roast loin of elk, pan-seared Artic char and spice-seared Peking duck breast.

lead_paragraph: A growing portion of corporate America appears to be concluding that dividends are no longer needed to attract investors and are therefore an unnecessary cost of doing business. Fewer companies are raising dividends, and more and more major companies do not bother to pay them at all.
abstract: A growing portion of corporate America appears to be concluding that dividends are no longer needed to attract investors and are therefore an unnecessary cost of doing business. Fewer companies are raising dividends, and more and more major companies do not bother to pay them at all.    Dividends used to be a virtual requirement to convince investors that a company was successful and worthy of investment. Some institutional investors were barred from buying stocks that did not pay dividends.

lead_paragraph: RESTAURANTS are not people, but they have personalities. The best ones can be a little difficult, even forbidding. Intellectually, you have to meet them halfway. There's no small talk. Others are like the not-too-bright, affable fellow who always greets you with a smile, a friendly wave and five dependable minutes of conversation about sports and the weather. La Nonna, a trattoria in Greenwich Village that opened in September, is definitely the sports-and-weather guy.

lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
abstract: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.    RON AFFIF TRIO, Makor, 35 West 67th Street, Manhattan, (212) 601-1000. Steeped in Wes Montgomery and George Benson, Ron Affif is an intensely rhythmic player, as you can see for yourself every Monday night at the Zinc Bar. With his well-practiced trio, he's playing this new club's jazz brunch on Sunday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., and there's no cover (Ben Ratliff).    * BAMBOLEO, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940. Bamboleo is one of the top bands on Havana's dance circuit, playing timba, a hard-driving fusion of salsa, funk, Latin pop, jazz and anything else that keeps a club audience in motion. With three singers who all take solo turns and share backup harmony, it's a one-band revue. And even songs that start out like ballads end up, sooner or later, as a danceable crossfire of horns, keyboards and percussion. Tonight at 11 p.m. and 1 a.m.; admission is $20 (Jon Pareles).

snippet: Special report Beaten Track, on Interstate highway 95, what traffic experts say is busiest, most overburdened and, in most parts, least attractive highway in nation; between Maine and Virginia alone, I-95 cuts through commercial corridor containin...
lead_paragraph: Every weekday before sunrise, Dick Chartier buckles himself into a mud-brown United Parcel Service truck outside Providence, R.I. He dangles a balsam-fir air freshener from the dashboard. He secures his provisions: turkey sandwich, apple, bottle of juice. He drapes his coat on the seat, settles behind the wheel and steels himself to stay there for a long, long time. He always does.
abstract: Special report Beaten Track, on Interstate highway 95, what traffic experts say is busiest, most overburdened and, in most parts, least attractive highway in nation; between Maine and Virginia alone, I-95 cuts through commercial corridor containing almost quarter of American population; it is major highway feeding 13 major airports, 11 major seaports, and more than two dozen railroad stations; it is surrounded by 30,000 miles of other busy roads that all flow, one way or another, into I-95; highway is overflowing with traffic; photos; map-chart shows traffic volume in different segments of highway (L)

The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has opened, with the same hours as the museum. Tomorrow from noon to 5 p.m., Kwaanza celebrations, including performances, visual and performing arts workshops and a film festival. The Hall of Ocean Life will be transformed to an African village with a marketplace. The annual origami tree is on display during the holidays. Museum admission: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children 2 to 12; under 2, free. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' Tickets:  $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children under 12. In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200. Visitors can buy a First Night New York City 2001 Button, $10 for adults, $5 for children (2 to 12), for free admission into the museum Sunday. Ticketmaster: (212) 307-7171. Information: (212) 676-2000 or www.nycmillennium.org.

snippet: Christopher Benfey reviews selection of art books; drawings (M)
lead_paragraph: If you are looking at the pictures, the best art books are likely to be the newest. The quality of color reproduction just keeps getting better. But if you're also reading the words, all bets are off. The best art criticism, in every age, tells us something about the art under consideration and something about the critic. Rilke on Rodin, Baudelaire on Delacroix, Meyer Schapiro on Cezanne -- once you have read these writers, the works of art are never quite the same again. And yet, art keeps asking something new from us, what Robert Frost called ''counterlove, original response.'' Word and picture, image and text -- the terms kept shifting in my mind, like yin wrestling with yang, as I meandered among the harvest of this year's art books.
abstract: Christopher Benfey reviews selection of art books; drawings (M)
