lead_paragraph: FOR CHILDREN
abstract: FOR CHILDREN    Theater     ''AESOP'S FABLES,'' presented by the Vital Children's Theater Company. The young actresses and the director Bruce Merrill, who collaborated on the script, have filled it with references to current pop figures as well as with characters accessible to 3- to 10-year-olds. Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. Vital Children's Theater Company, 432 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 592-4508.     ''BUTTERFLY'S ADVENTURE: A LEPIDOPTERA OPERA,'' a musical theater piece by the Amazing Landfill Gardeners of Gondwanaland, featuring a caterpillar that changes into a butterfly, a talking tree, birds and a moth, Sunday at 2 p.m. at the Children's Museum of the Arts, 182 Lafayette Street, SoHo. Free with admission: $5. Information: (212) 274-0986.     ''CHARLOTTE'S WEBB,'' E. B. White's classic tale of Wilbur the pig and Charlotte the spider, adapted by Joseph Robinette. Presented by the Pied Piper Children's Theater, children ages 5 to 14 who are involved in all aspects of the production. Performances are tomorrow and Sunday (and May 13) at 3 at 7 p.m. at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, 20 Cumming Street, Inwood. Tickets: $16; $3 for children under 18. Information: (212) 567-2329.     ''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed in Spanish and English simultaneously), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the familiar story but with a twist. Little Red does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to question his identity. With Jose Lopez, puppeteer. Saturdays at 3:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. Through June 25. Los Kabayitos Theater, 107 Suffolk Street, second floor, Lower East Side. Tickets: $8; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 260-4080, extension 14.     ''KINGDOM OF THE SUN,'' directed by Zac Whinnem, is knights and courtiers, Monty Python style. Josh Cagan's play is also a feminist fairy tale in which the king's female page, Harold, saves him. Sundays through May 21 at 2 p.m. Manhattan Theater Source, 177 Macdougal Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $7. Reservations: (212) 501-4751.     ''PIRATES OF PENZANCE,'' the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta about a band of pirates and their adventures, performed by the West Side Y.M.C.A.'s Kids Company, youngsters trained in musical theater who perform for other children. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7; Sunday at 2 p.m. 5 West 63rd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 875-4277.    Events     CARIBBEAN CARNIVAL, tomorrow and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the New York Aquarium, West Eighth Street and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, Brooklyn. Children will view Caribbean wildlife like coral, dolphins and turtles while enjoying music, mask making, arts and crafts, and other activities with a Caribbean flavor. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $9.75; children 2 to 12 and the elderly, $6; under 2, free. Information: (718) 265-3474.     CELEBRATE MAY at the Staten Island Zoo, 614 Broadway, off Forest Avenue, West Brighton, Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., with activities, crafts and a Maypole. Free with zoo admission: $3; children 3 to 11, $2; under 3, free. Information: (718) 442-3101 or (718) 442-3174.     CENTRAL PARK CONSERVATORY Workshops, tomorrow from 1 to 4 p.m at the Henry Luce Nature Observatory at Belvedere Castle, midpark at 79th Street. ''Hawk Navigation and Migration,'' with educators from the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary, who will introduce youngsters to these birds, also known as raptors. ''Tiles That Bring Smiles'' gives youngsters 6 and older an opportunity to explore the history of the Minton tiles on the ceiling of the Bethesda Arcade, installed in the 1870's, and then design and put together their own tiles. Free, but reservations required: (212) 772-0210.     ''THE CINDERELLA MAGIC SHOW'' combines illusion with live animals and participation from the audience. The creator, Arnie Kolodner, has added comic touches to the familiar story, with Cinderella, played by Alice Bergmann, driving her own pumpkin. St. Jean Baptiste Church, 184 East 76th Street, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday at 11 a.m., 1:30 p.m. and 4 p.m. Tickets: $17.50. Information: (212) 279-4200.     ''CIRCUS TO GO,'' a workshop featuring clowns, presented by the Big Apple Circus tomorrow at two Queens sites: at 1 p.m. at the Flushing Library, 41-17 Main Street, (718) 661-1212; at 4:30 p.m., Kew Gardens Hills Branch, 72-33 Vleigh Place, (718) 261-6654. Free.     COLUMBIA GREENHOUSE SPRING FAIR, tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. (rain date is Sunday), will bring a minifarm to the sidewalks of Morningside Heights, on 116th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Morningside Drive. The Greenhouse is an 80-year-old nursery school affiliated with Columbia University. Free events include a petting zoo, a firetruck for climbing, a carousel, pony rides and face painting. Information: (212) 666-4796.     ''PEONY FESTIVAL'' coincides with the Chinese Peony Show in the Haupt Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Kazimiroff Boulevard, Fordham, the Bronx, in which the colorful blossoms of the Chinese tree peony are in bloom. Featured activities, today through May 14 include hands-on activities, storytellers telling Chinese folk tales and a Chinese lion dance. Garden hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Everett Children's Adventure Garden hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 1 p.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Parking: $5. A ''garden passport'' combination ticket grants admission to the entire grounds, with a tram tour: adults, $10; students and the elderly, $7.50; children 2 to 12, $4; under 2, free. Information: (718) 817-8700.     ''STUART DAVIS IN GLOUCESTER.'' A tour of the landscapes of the Cape Ann community of Gloucester by Stuart Davis at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 90th Street, will be the starting point of a family program for children and an accompanying adult tomorrow from 2 to 3 p.m. After viewing images of the picturesque harbors, shipyards, hillsides and street scenes, visitors will create postcards with the artist Hannah Frassinelli. They can also bring some from home to collage into their creations. Fee: $6 for children 5 to 12 and accompanying adults. Reservations: (212) 369-4880, extension 244.     ''SUBWAYS, SEA CREATURES, TOOLS AND TEA.'' At first it may be hard to see what these items have in common. The connection will be revealed tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. Tanishka Kachru, a decorative arts intern, will talk about the manufacture, decoration and use of silver objects over the last 300 years. Free with suggested museum admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672, extension 257.     ''UNIVERSAL HAIR PUPPET MAKING WORKSHOP.'' ''Hair in African Art and Culture,'' an exhibition through May 28 at the Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, in SoHo, is the inspiration for a workshop tomorrow at 1 p.m. for ages 5 and older. Free with museum admission: $5; $2.50 for students, children and the elderly; free on Sundays. Information: (212) 966-1313.     ''WELCOME,'' a new exhibition opening Sunday at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, presents work by 11 artists exploring ideas of home and the relationship between people and nature. The new exhibition (through Aug. 20) will be celebrated with activities, programs and tours from 1 to 4 p.m. Events include a performance by Skip LaPlante and his ensemble, who perform on instruments made from household items, and a chance to create a Chinese landscape painting. Free buses to and from midtown Manhattan; for bus reservations: (718) 549-3200, extension 248. Grounds hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200.     MEADOWFAIR at the Staten Island Children's Museum, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston, Sunday from noon to 5 p.m. The museum's annual spring celebration features crafts, workshops and entertainment. Admission: children, $8; adults, $5. Also tomorrow, from 1 to 4 p.m., youngsters can learn how to combine water, oil, food dye and their imaginations to create water sculptures. Fee: $2 plus museum admission: $4; free for children under 2 and members. Information: (718) 273-2060.     ''STORYTELLING IN THE GALLERIES: THE CHINESE BRUSH.'' Stories about a magic brush that makes anything it paints come to life will be the subject of stories told by the educator Angie Kim, tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the Chinese Galleries, second floor, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.     ''THREE OLD MEN WHO WANT TO LIVE FOREVER,'' an opera created for 5- to 12-year-olds, will be presented tomorrow at noon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Avenue, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. Created by Josee Hussaarts and Suzanne van Lohuizen and performed by three singing actors from the Netherlands, the fairy tale introduces the concept of aging and mortality. Although it begins with three old men who wake up one morning to learn they are going to die, the program includes jokes, singing, dancing and games as it goes about its message of acceptance and unexpected new beginnings. Tickets: $10.

snippet: William Grimes reviews Jack's Fifth, 8 West 58th Street, which serves new American cuisine; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: JACK'S FIFTH is the name of the place. It has a no-nonsense American sound to it. Turn the name around, and you get a fifth of Jack's. It feels right. If the laws were different, every table at Jack's Fifth would get a complimentary pack of Luckies, just for the visuals. It's that kind of restaurant -- a subterranean lair with a swanky bar, lots of circular booths and a retro sense of style that's part 1940's nightclub, part Rat Pack hangout.

lead_paragraph: THE Sologne is a vast, flat expanse lying south of the Loire just beyond Orleans. It stretches from the chateau of Chambord in the west to the hills of Sancerre in the east. A haunting landscape of forests and ponds, it is one of France's premier game regions and one of my favorites for downright good eating.

snippet: Richard Jay Scholem reviews Zen Palate restaurant in Westbury, Long Island (M)
lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN is what the sleek, stylish, new Zen Palate in Westbury says to all who enter, while its creative, complex Asian fusion fare says vegetarian as it's rarely been said before. Zen Palate, opposite the Source at 477 Old Country Road (516-333-8686), is the first out-of-Manhattan venture for this one-of-a-kind Chinese-Japanese-Italian-Indian-Mexican restaurant, which has three locations in New York City. Most adventurous eaters embrace Zen Palate's multinational dishes and call them exotic, while traditional, conservative eaters might well stamp them bizarre.

lead_paragraph: DAVID BOULEY does not do things in a small way. His ambitions are boundless, and his complex, ever-changing schemes to establish a personal culinary empire make him one of the more attention-getting and baffling figures on the restaurant scene. He is the Stanley Kubrick of New York chefs -- difficult to get a read on, by most accounts difficult to deal with, but always pointed in a direction that feels as though it will lead straight to the next big thing.

snippet: Zia pueblo near Albuquerque is fighting for control of Zia sun sign, traditional symbol consisting of circle with lines radiating in four directions, which has become ubiquitous image throughout New Mexico; pueblo has protested American Frontier M...
lead_paragraph: IN a strange coda to a decade obsessed with branding, controversy has broken out over a surprising symbol: the Zia sun sign. The symbol -- a circle with lines radiating in four directions -- is one of the best-known images in New Mexico. It is on the state flag and license plates. It appears in the Yellow Pages with about the same frequency as the oversize apple used to promote New York City. And it shows up on everything from dishes and linens to motorcycles and portable toilets.
abstract: Zia pueblo near Albuquerque is fighting for control of Zia sun sign, traditional symbol consisting of circle with lines radiating in four directions, which has become ubiquitous image throughout New Mexico; pueblo has protested American Frontier Motorcycle Tours receipt of trademark incorporating version of symbol; has also demanded $74 million from state for using symbol without permission; United States Patent and Trademark Office, partly in response to dispute, is investigating legal status of Native American tribal symbols; photos (M)

snippet: Profile of almond industry in California's Central Valley, which produces 70 percent of world's supply of almonds, nation's top horticultural export; vast groves are in midst of intensive harvest season as growers rush to get crop hulled and shell...
lead_paragraph: THEY are among the oldest cultivated foods on earth, the stuff of Greek myths, a prized ingredient of the pharaohs' breads, a staple of Biblical feasts. They are believed to have originated in China and Central Asia, and their pinkish white blossoms and graceful branches call to mind the cherry trees whose botanical family they share. Transported to the Mediterranean by the traders of the Silk Road, they have been an important commodity since the Middle Ages.

snippet: Bruce Wagner satiric comment on Power Groveling in Hollywood; photo (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)
lead_paragraph: At one time in Hollywood, a social faux pas or small betrayal elicited the aside: ''How may I grovel [to redeem myself]?'' It was a common, if not comical, refrain. When actors' salaries hit the $20 million mark, the query took a serious turn. Power Groveling (i.e., New Groveling) became an industry staple, and we would be hard put to imagine the Hollywood landscape without it. Falling to one's knees is now widely regarded as a necessary tool, the carabiners and rope, if you will, of one's ascent up the cold, steep, expensive incline of the Business. The following are three modern parables on the way we grovel (New New Groveling, hereafter referred to as New2Groveling) today.
abstract: Bruce Wagner satiric comment on Power Groveling in Hollywood; photo (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

lead_paragraph: RESTAURANTS are routinely compared to the theater, but sometimes film seems like a better analogy. There are major studios, like Restaurant Associates or the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, that combine class and mass. Drew Nieporent's Myriad Group, which includes TriBeCa Grill, Montrachet and Berkeley Bar and Grill, does a convincing impersonation of Miramax, a big-bucks company with the soul of an independent. There are star chefs like Jean-Georges Vongerichten who can green-light a restaurant merely by wiggling an eyebrow. And on the margins are hundreds of small restaurants that, like small independent films, express a highly personal vision.
abstract: RESTAURANTS are routinely compared to the theater, but sometimes film seems like a better analogy. There are major studios, like Restaurant Associates or the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, that combine class and mass. Drew Nieporent's Myriad Group, which includes TriBeCa Grill, Montrachet and Berkeley Bar and Grill, does a convincing impersonation of Miramax, a big-bucks company with the soul of an independent. There are star chefs like Jean-Georges Vongerichten who can green-light a restaurant merely by wiggling an eyebrow. And on the margins are hundreds of small restaurants that, like small independent films, express a highly personal vision.    Trois Marches is one of the independents -- the small-budget kind, shot with a handheld camera -- and it has the strengths and weaknesses that the term implies.

lead_paragraph: ON THE REZ
abstract: ON THE REZ  By Ian Frazier  311 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.      Ian Frazier's 1989 book, ''Great Plains,'' was one of those enchanting books that thoroughly captured the peculiar mood and magic of a place: not just the mythic dimensions of its history and not just the mundane facts relating to its highways and byways and towns, but the shimmering, miragelike overlap of the two. The Great Plains in Mr. Frazier's dreams were ''enormous, bountiful, unfenced,'' and in that book he filled in some of those blanks with names and stories, peopling that vast Western prairie with individuals he met in the course of his 25,000-mile journey.

snippet: David Margolick report on aesthetics of newly opened Oresund Fixed Link, bridge-tunnel-road linking Denmark and Sweden; discusses likely economic and social impact on two countries and its prospect for further unifying Europe; photos (The Sophisti...
lead_paragraph: One day, perhaps, the Oresund Fixed Link, the newly opened bridge, tunnel and road that has reunited Denmark with Sweden after a 7,000-year hiatus, will find its Hart Crane, who will rhapsodize about it in the way the American poet sang the praises of the Brooklyn Bridge. But probably not. While it is an engineering marvel, one bringing to fruition nearly 100 years of dreaming and planning and politicking, aesthetically speaking at least, the new span is not the stuff of verse. It is too long (10 miles) and too much of it -- nearly the first 4 miles heading east out of Copenhagen -- is under water. When it does surface from its tunnel, most of what's visible is an elevated causeway. Its middle section looks like a bridge, but its simple concrete towers, the tallest in Sweden, and the cables strung from them, are more elegant than mighty. And since the raised span is so far from shore, for all its size it seems small and slight, a few strokes from a finely pointed pen. If it inspires poetry, it will be less for its looks and more for what it portends: a Europe whose borders are slowly evaporating.
abstract: David Margolick report on aesthetics of newly opened Oresund Fixed Link, bridge-tunnel-road linking Denmark and Sweden; discusses likely economic and social impact on two countries and its prospect for further unifying Europe; photos (The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

snippet: Rob Nixon travel article on trip through Driftless region of southwest Wisconsin; photos; maps (M)
lead_paragraph: MOVING to Wisconsin after 15 years in Manhattan, my partner, Anne, and I were charmed by the idea of the new way of life Madison would offer. But beyond the state's capital, our knowledge of Wisconsin amounted to a few hours spent on I-90 and a grab bag of cliches about cheeseheads, badgers, blizzards and lakes, mostly frozen ones. We felt apprehensive about living in a landscape without vertical dimension: neither of us is fond of the legato drone of the flat Midwest. So ranking high among the many startling pleasures of our move has been our discovery of the Driftless, Wisconsin's hilly southwest quadrant.

lead_paragraph: William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, has no doubts about who is responsible for his company's antitrust woes. During a news conference last Wednesday, hours after a federal judge ordered that Microsoft be split in two, Mr. Gates spoke pointedly of the ''competitors that have been behind this lawsuit.''
abstract: William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, has no doubts about who is responsible for his company's antitrust woes. During a news conference last Wednesday, hours after a federal judge ordered that Microsoft be split in two, Mr. Gates spoke pointedly of the ''competitors that have been behind this lawsuit.''    What part did Microsoft's rivals play? The competitors, to be sure, played a crucial role throughout the investigation, litigation and sanctions phase of the suit by the Justice Department and 19 states. It was, in fact, a 222-page white paper written in the summer of 1996 by lawyers for Netscape Communications, Microsoft's main rival in the market for Internet browsing software, that caught the attention of Joel I. Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, and prompted him to order an investigation.

snippet: Kyle Gann article on dramatic changes in electronic music; it once took dozens of hours for pioneers to get just a single tone out of a synthesizer 40 years ago but now, by using music notation computer software, whole pages of music can be input ...
lead_paragraph: IT takes maybe 15 minutes to input the first page of Stravinsky's ''Sacre du Printemps'' into music notation software on my computer. I press the space bar, and it plays back instantly, with simulations of the original woodwind tones. Compare that process with the dozens of hours it took pioneers like Milton Babbitt to get just a single tone out of a synthesizer 40 years ago -- or even with the hundreds of IBM cards I tediously punched in a computer music class only 20 years ago, with three notes to show for it -- and it is clear that the very meaning of the term ''electronic music'' has changed. In fact, as the millennium turns over, it is appropriate to ask whether the term still means anything at all.

lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
abstract: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.    * AUTUMN BLUES FESTIVAL, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400. The three-night blues festival begins with a bill of blues and Southern soul by Bobby Rush, who sings a lot of good-natured, raunchy come-ons, and Otis Clay, born in Mississippi and living in Chicago, who holds on to the gospel-charged intensity of 1960's soul. Tonight at 8; tickets are $25. An acoustic blues night tomorrow brings together the guitarists and singers Joe Louis Walker and Matt  Murphy with the harmonica player Billy Branch, a rare chance to hear these bluesmen unplugged. Alvin Youngblood Hart, who applies the lessons of finger-picking country blues to his songs, opens with a solo set. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $25. And on Sunday, two rare visitors arrive from Mississippi's juke joints: the 74-year-old Delta bluesman Eddie Cusic and a younger juke joint regular, James Johnson. Sunday night at 7; tickets are $21 (Jon Pareles).

snippet: Sherry Marker travel article on historic neighborhood of Strawbery Banke in Portsmouth, NH, populated by costumed role players and interpreters; photos; map (L)
lead_paragraph: AT Strawbery Banke in Portsmouth, N.H., costumed role players and interpreters encourage visitors to eavesdrop on three centuries of daily life, from the first settlement here in 1630 to the museum's foundation in 1958. The 1630 settlement took its name from the wild berries that grew along the banks of the Piscataqua River, but the settlers were less interested in the site's sylvan pleasures than in its economic possibilities. In 1653 Strawbery Banke changed its name to Portsmouth, trumpeting that ''We are at the river's mouth and our port is as good as any in the land.'' Today's Strawbery Banke, which calls itself an outdoor history museum, preserves the original spelling of the first settlement's name.
abstract: Sherry Marker travel article on historic neighborhood of Strawbery Banke in Portsmouth, NH, populated by costumed role players and interpreters; photos; map (L)

abstract: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.    Museums    * JEAN-SIMEON CHARDIN, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 3). This retrospective doesn't tell us much that wasn't already known about Chardin, but there's nothing wrong with being reminded occasionally of what great painting is. The art, by contrast with so much Rococo art, is about love, not sex. Quiet and deliberation were Chardin's essential ingredients, combined with a perfect mastery of abstract form. He was the best still-life painter ever because he made the most of the least, his work focusing on the same humble cups and pans in one painting after another, one decade after another. The result was a compilation of precise little observations that together make as true a record of the value of seeing as exists in the history of art. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).

snippet: Mac Griswold article on visiting new National Botanic Garden of Wales, with its futuristic Great Glass House by Sir Norman Foster; describes environmentally-friendly features that conserve energy; also recommends visits to restored gardens at Aber...
lead_paragraph: THERE is now another pressing reason to visit Wales this summer, besides Welsh Black beef, cut from the only cattle in Britain that have never been fed anything but good green Welsh grass, or so the Welsh say. After dining royally on one of those filets cooked by Rod Peterson, the acclaimed chef at the Cawdor Arms Hotel in Llandeilo, I headed for the new National Botanic Garden of Wales in nearby Llanarthne, which was scheduled to open this week. There I was delighted to find the same natural-systems approach to the world, but transformed into the most advanced -- and good-looking -- sustainable machinery for keeping plants, people and interior climates in sync.

Museums     ''THE CHANGING FACE OF LIBERTY: FEMALE ALLEGORIES OF AMERICA,'' New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through Sept. 3). Uncle Sam, the allegorical male personification of the United States, has always had a female counterpart, the damsel dressed in flowing robes who came to symbolize Liberty. As a sequel to its ''Uncle Sam'' show, the historical society mounted this very lively display of his iconic sister in her many guises, from ''L'Amerique,'' an Indian princess with feathers in her hair who represented the New World in early maps, to the matronly Lady Liberty portrayed in the Bartholdi statue in New York Harbor. The fascinating story of Liberty's evolution is told in posters, cartoons, illustrations and photographs. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3 for students over 12 and the elderly (Grace Glueck).

lead_paragraph: HAVING a party? Pin the tail on the donkey and background music from the CD player don't cut it anymore. Whether it's a wedding, bar mitzvah, anniversary, corporate or school event, the entertainment choices are limitless. And the wackier the better. Magicians, prancing drummers, impersonators, belly dancers, face painters, ventriloquists, sword swallowers, male strippers, puppeteers and multi-talented performers who walk on stilts, ride unicycles and play with yo-yos are only a fee away. Here are some of the possibilities.

snippet: Barry Singer article on lyricist who are continuing the classic tradition of American song, among them Craig Carnelia, Susan Birkenhead, Lynn Ahrens, Mark Waldrop and David Zippel; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: NAME the most important lyric writers of the past half-century. Stephen Sondheim, without question; the lyricist who single-handedly deepened the American song tradition with penetrating verbal invention and an enlivening dose of psychological complexity. But also Bob Dylan, Paul Simon and Joni Mitchell, folk balladeers who infused lyric writing with the imagery and confessional aspect of modernist poetry. Their innovations created an entirely new tradition, or perhaps antitradition -- that of the self-absorbed singer-songwriter for whom, in the name of personal expression, all lyric-writing rules could be broken.
abstract: Barry Singer article on lyricist who are continuing the classic tradition of American song, among them Craig Carnelia, Susan Birkenhead, Lynn Ahrens, Mark Waldrop and David Zippel; photo (M)

snippet: Director Cameron Crowe tribute to work of Polish-born cinematographer Janusz Kaminski; Kaminski comments on his close partnership with wife, actress Holly Hunter; fashion photos of Hunter (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part ...
lead_paragraph: The year was 1987, and flickering on the big screen of the Fine Arts Theater in Chicago was a film called ''Raising Arizona.'' Sitting in the audience was Janusz Kaminski, a 28-year-old film student, and there was something in the vivid performance of the movie's star, Holly Hunter, that resonated with him deeply, far beyond words. ''I was crazy about her,'' he remembers. ''This girl with this wonderful voice, this beautiful face, who made me cry in her determination to have some kind of romance in her life. She was a very determined character.''
abstract: Director Cameron Crowe tribute to work of Polish-born cinematographer Janusz Kaminski; Kaminski comments on his close partnership with wife, actress Holly Hunter; fashion photos of Hunter (special section, Fashions of The Times) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

snippet: Weekend Excursion article by Sara Rimer on North Shore of Massachusetts, with stops for bird-watching on Plum Island, walking in Newburyport, ice cream in Ipswich and seafood in Essex (Woodman's and Farnham's) and Gloucester; photos; map; list (M)
lead_paragraph: By 6:15 a.m. my friend Lou and I were stumbling out of the Clark Currier Inn and driving the few miles to Plum Island on the North Shore of Massachusetts. Our headlights cut through the fog as we followed the road along the Merrimack River toward the sea. Plum Island is a natural barrier beach, a nine-mile-long spit of sand, dune grasses, trees and tidal marsh -- and beach plums, hence its name -- that attracts huge numbers of migrating birds in the spring and fall.

AISLER SET, Thompson Center, New York University, 238 Thompson Street, near Washington Square South, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-4999. The pop-savvy home-crafters swelling the ranks of indie rock auteurism are mostly male, with women sometimes providing winsome vocals. But Amy Linton, a singer and a producer, fits right in with the boys in bands like Apples in Stereo and the Pastels. Her rough-hewn but smooth-minded arrangements make her songs, which expand on the fantasies of a well-educated young woman, more than just another round of confession. Tonight at 8:30; admission is $3; $2 for N.Y.U. students (Ann Powers).     GERI ALLEN TRIO, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. Since the 1980's, Ms. Allen, the articulate, sometimes brilliant pianist, has done some of her best work in trios; the space around her energizes the music. She's had this one, with the bassist Billy Johnson and the drummer Marc Johnson, for more than a year now. Sets through Sunday are at 9:30 and 11:30 p.m., with a 1 a.m. set tomorrow; cover charge is $20, or $15 on Sunday (Ben Ratliff).

Theaterworks/USA presents Robert Louis Stevenson's gothic thriller, transformed into a one-hour contemporary musical about a teenager who can't say no to drugs. The play is suitable for ages 8 to 12. Book and lyrics are by David Crane and Marta Kauffman; music is by Michael Skloff. Auditorium at Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 52nd Street, tomorrow and Sunday at 12:30 p.m. (also Feb. 19-20). Tickets $19. Reservations: (212) 627-7373.     ''MAMET FOR KIDS.'' You wouldn't expect David Mamet to write fairy tales or other works for children, yet he has written two that have the playwright's stamp without his famously colorful language. ''The Poet and the Rent'' (10 a.m.) and ''The Frog Prince'' (11:30 p.m.) will be presented tomorrow by Atlantic Theater Company, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea. Tickets: $10; $5 for children under 10. Reservations: (212) 633-2643.

lead_paragraph: THE best restaurants in Budapest are Italian and French.'' Thus spake Laszlo Alkonyi, the editor of Borbarat, Hungary's leading wine review. Indeed, Fausto, his favorite, and Lou-Lou, Italian and French respectively, are very good restaurants in which you'll meet ''le tout Budapest.'' But they weren't my favorites. A week of dedicated dining in Budapest's Hungarian restaurants was as delectable as it was illuminating. I didn't find the Magyar Alain Ducasse, but I did eat really good local food and felt very much part of the life of the city.

lead_paragraph: Just over a century ago, a struggling actress -- the more artistic of two women sharing a New York town house -- read ''The Decoration of Houses'' by Edith Wharton and the architect Ogden Codman Jr. This subversive volume recommended a return to European ideals of purity and elegance -- Vanderbiltian baroque was labeled out; Versailles or 18th-century English country style was going to be in. The actress took a long look at her dark rooms decorated in gloomy, overstuffed 1890's style and made some very radical changes.

snippet: Thomas Powers article on CIA Dir John Deutch and investigation of his downloading of classified files on home computer; explains that computer technology has made security much more challenging for agency for which it is crucial; traces Deutch's c...
lead_paragraph: One of these days -- perhaps this year, perhaps next -- John M. Deutch is going to get a call from his lawyer. If he is lucky, he will learn that his ''case'' has been resolved. Of course, it may not be a ''case'' in the formal sense; he has not been charged with any criminal offense nor has he been informed by the Justice Department that he is the target of a criminal investigation. But ''case'' is probably still the best word to describe the slowly unwinding chain of events that began with the discovery in late 1996 that Deutch -- then the outgoing director of central intelligence, as the C.I.A.'s chief is formally known -- had placed classified files on an unclassified Apple computer provided to him by the agency for his use at home.
abstract: Thomas Powers article on CIA Dir John Deutch and investigation of his downloading of classified files on home computer; explains that computer technology has made security much more challenging for agency for which it is crucial; traces Deutch's career and tenure, noting that his dream was always to head Pentagon, not CIA, where he got into trouble by not having respect for agency's classified, clandestine culture; drawings (L)

lead_paragraph: Which turn-of-the-year movie horse race do you follow? The one at the box office? Or the stampede of critical 10-best lists that nudge prestigious films toward Academy Award consideration?
abstract: Which turn-of-the-year movie horse race do you follow? The one at the box office? Or the stampede of critical 10-best lists that nudge prestigious films toward Academy Award consideration?    A year ago when ''Saving Private Ryan'' won many critics' polls and did slam-dunk business, it looked as if Hollywood was gearing up to steal back some of the critical thunder that has increasingly accrued to independent films. But this year the tables have turned again. On Sunday evening when the New York Film Critics Circle distributes its annual awards at Windows on the World, mainstream Hollywood will be given a mostly frigid shoulder.

abstract: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.    * AC/DC, SLASH'S SNAKEPIT, Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741. Going nowhere and proud of it, AC/DC turns arrested development into a vocation, insisting that men will be boys. Angus Young, dressed in his schoolboy knickers though he is in his mid-40's, runs around the stage as he peals out primal hard-rock guitar riffs; Brian Scott screeches about girls, booze and sin; and sooner or later there's a shower of sparks. Slash, the lead guitarist for Guns 'n' Roses, has had plenty of time between albums to start his own hard-rock band, Snakepit. Tonight at 8; tickets are $38 and $48 (Jon Pareles).

lead_paragraph: FOR weeks, I avoided using Priceline's new online grocery service because I was sure I would hate it.
abstract: FOR weeks, I avoided using Priceline's new online grocery service because I was sure I would hate it.    Let's leave aside for the moment Priceline's reputation in the name-your-price airline ticket business (too many stopovers, crazy departure times) and the annoying television ads for the new grocery service featuring the ''Star Trek'' actor William Shatner (as if Captain Kirk ever set foot inside a Waldbaum's, much less knew the first thing about how to keep a low profile with extra items in the express line). More important, Priceline's online grocery service, called the Priceline WebHouse Club, would force me to confront one of life's worst weekly horrors -- grocery shopping -- not once, but twice.

abstract: The managers of the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company's Chicago office know how to butter up the corporate V.I.P.'s. The quartet sang for the board of directors, of course. lead_paragraph: John Lasseter pulled close a yellow chair and turned it so its egg-yolk surface met the sunlight. ''Look at this,'' he said. ''In the real world, this is about as close as you can get to a perfect, simple object.'' The chair's wooden back and seat are bright yellow, no other color. ''But look closer,'' Mr. Lasseter said. ''See, there's a little black mark here. And look, here's some kind of a blemish. And if you look really close, you can see the grain of the wood through the paint.''

abstract: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.    Now Playing    * ''AMERICAN BEAUTY,'' starring Kevin Spacey (winner of best actor Oscar), Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes; winner of best picture, director, cinematography and original-screenplay Oscars). With heavenly finesse Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Janet Maslin).

snippet: Focus on major shifts occurring in Japanese economy; changes in employer-employee relationship, liberalization of financial markets and explosion of new business models in freewheeling arenas of Internet and information technology have spawned new...
lead_paragraph: Starting this week, music fans across Japan will be stepping up to a gadget that resembles a souped up, stand-alone automated teller, plugging in a blank minidisk, dropping in some coins and, 30 to 40 seconds later, walking away with their favorite recordings. And they will not be limited to just a few selections; thanks to a super-fast, high-capacity digital connection to a central computer, thousands upon thousands of popular songs will be potentially available at the touch of a few buttons.
abstract: Focus on major shifts occurring in Japanese economy; changes in employer-employee relationship, liberalization of financial markets and explosion of new business models in freewheeling arenas of Internet and information technology have spawned new breed of entrepreneurs who care little for conventions that have dominated country for decades; many big companies are slowly realizing benefits of competitive procurement practices and cost of providing life support to many small partners; are struggling to pare work forces, largely by drastically cutting hiring of new employees; many that still dominate economy are adopting compensation programs based on performance and abolishing remuneration determined by seniority, fast diluting attractions of lifetime employment; evolution of financial markets is helping entrepreneurs, as new stock markets emerge designed to foster young businesses and flood of venture capital provides money that was once parceled out almost exclusively by big banks largely interested in corporate customers and real estate developers; at same time, barriers to taking young companies public have eased, making private capital less crucial in nursing them; previously, economic structure that evolved after World War II with its heavy emphasis on government-directed bank lending, its punitive tax structure, its ban on stock options and its lack of pension portability, had stifled entrepreneural spirit; photo; graph; chart (M)

snippet: Bryan Miller Choice Tables column suggests restaurants in Phoenix, Ariz: Los Dos Molinos, Gregory's Grill, Hapa, Mary Elaine's and Richardson's; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: TEN years ago, fine dining in Phoenix was largely confined to chain restaurants, most of them in frosty air-conditioned malls. Aside from a batch of scorching Tex-Mex chili parlors, the food in this shimmering city in the sand was as flat as a bus ride to Yuma. Or as one local culinary writer put it, ''Back then, people here thought free-range chicken was something you didn't have to pay for.''

lead_paragraph: IN beat-up pickup trucks and station wagons, in sedans and four-by-four's and sports cars, the correction officers are coming to work at the Westchester County Jail. The heat is already oppressive as the line stretches along the Grasslands Reservation here at 6:45 a.m. The officers drive through an opening in a 15-foot-high, double-chain-link fence, past Officer John West, who has been waving his colleagues through this point of freedom for the last nine years.

snippet: Michael Frank article on tranquil Sauvie Island, wildlife preserve and farmland just ten miles from downtown Portland, Oregon; photos; map; advice for day trip and picnic (M)
lead_paragraph: IN the landscape, in the very atmosphere of islands, there is often a visceral feeling of apartness. It may have its roots in certain obvious isolating factors of geography and history, but there is a further dimension, less easily pinpointed, a kind of island sensibility, an individuality. A sense that things are done differently on island turf; an attention to old customs and legacies; a respect for nature and a husbanding of natural resources. You feel it in Sardinia and in Sicily and on Patmos. Imagine, though, feeling it on a river island, one connected to a major highway by a bridge not much longer than a freeway overpass.
abstract: Michael Frank article on tranquil Sauvie Island, wildlife preserve and farmland just ten miles from downtown Portland, Oregon; photos; map; advice for day trip and picnic (M)

snippet: Susan Allen Toth article on Malvern Hills; describes villages, gardens, castles and countryside that create perhaps most beautiful pastoral landscape in England; photos; map (M)
lead_paragraph: I WANTED to walk the Malvern Hills. For years I'd looked longingly at pictures of the broad paths along this high, undulating ridge, a dramatic nine-mile upheaval in the otherwise placid and gently rolling landscape of Hereford and Worcester in central England. The views from this ridge looked wonderful, the paths challenging but not arduous. So when my husband, James, and I planned five nights in the Malverns last spring, I promised James we would walk miles every day.
abstract: Susan Allen Toth article on Malvern Hills; describes villages, gardens, castles and countryside that create perhaps most beautiful pastoral landscape in England; photos; map (M)

lead_paragraph: AS the weather warms up, who doesn't yearn to grab the blanket that's been tossed beside the fireplace and spread it out under a tree? Yet most of us automatically head back indoors when hunger strikes. But if you pack a picnic along with your book, you can savor more than just your trusty apple. And with so many portable possibilities in Westchester, the journey to the park could be as liberating as the picnic itself.

snippet: Kyle Gann reviews art exhibit I Am Sitting in a Room: Sound Works by American Artists 1950-2000, part of Whitney Museum's American Century exhibition; photo (M)0
lead_paragraph: WHEN the performance art genre appeared in the 1970's, the playwright and novelist William Hogeland commented cynically, ''We already have a performance art: it's called 'theater.' '' One could similarly dismiss the term ''sound art'' as just a vaguely glorified name for weird music. And yet ''sound art'' has served as a useful historical euphemism, a safe harbor for works too outre for the ever-conservative classical music world.

lead_paragraph: Like many movie lovers, Victor Rosa has run through most of the titles available at the local video store.
abstract: Like many movie lovers, Victor Rosa has run through most of the titles available at the local video store.     But not long ago, Mr. Rosa, the assistant manager of a fast-food chain restaurant in midtown Manhattan, found himself at a Blockbuster outlet near Times Square renting  ''Enemy of the State,'' a 1998 thriller he had watched on his VCR before. Now, thanks to a Christmas gift from his wife, he was eager to see the movie again.

snippet: Article on fencing instructions available at Metropolis Fencing in Manhattan; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Take your typical Big Apple fender bender, transpose it to Paris in, say, 1720, and odds are that swords and seconds would be summoned. From 1600 to 1780, 40,000 Frenchmen died in duels. That averages out to 222 a year, and the Hungarians and Italians were surely as passionate. (Though it was a Frenchman, Moliere, who summed up the essence of the duel: ''The entire secret of arms consists of only two things: to give, and not to receive.'')

lead_paragraph: IT looked like a huge tomb rising from the beach. A gray-brown monolith with a shadowy entrance, it had concrete slopes and a flat roof that had been weathered into smoothness. As my husband, James, and I walked along the peaceful four-mile stretch of sands on St. Ouen's Bay on the island of Jersey, we could not keep our eyes from this monumental bunker or the immense stone-and-concrete wall, curving for miles, to which it was connected.

snippet: west meets east**A
lead_paragraph: In China, Grace Zia Chu had been a gym teacher; in 1950's America, she became Madame Chu, a well-known Chinese-cooking expert whose Manhattan cooking classes and cookbooks initiated a whole generation of Americans in the mysteries of the stir-fry. Today, we are struck by the enormous gulf that Madame Chu sought to span and by the tone with which she spanned it: she opens her groundbreaking 1962 cookbook, ''The Pleasures of Chinese Cooking,'' with the tremendous poise of an ambassador. ''We Chinese,'' she begins, ''like to think of cooking as a distinctive art form.''

snippet: Ted Rose on touring Katmandu and Nepal's Langtang Valley; map; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: IT'S been almost 50 years since Nepal first invited Western visitors to trek its ancient trade routes, and 30 years since its capital, Katmandu, became a hippie mecca. More recently, in the wake of Jon Krakauer's best-selling book ''Into Thin Air,'' the image of the mysterious Shangri-La has suffered. Katmandu has been reduced to a polluted staging ground for mountain adventure, while the trails themselves sound as crowded as the Long Island Expressway on a summer weekend. One friend advised that I visit neighboring Bhutan instead. ''Nepal is finished,'' he told me.

headline.print_headline: MOVIE GUIDE

lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 13.
abstract: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 13.    Now Playing   * ''ALL ABOUT MY MOTHER,'' starring Cecilia Roth, Marisa Paredes, Antonia San Juan and Penelope Cruz. Directed by Pedro Almodovar (R, 101 minutes; winner of best foreign-language film Oscar). A whole new order of Almodovar extravaganza. The antic fizz and theatrical exaggeration of his earlier work have blossomed into a newly sophisticated style, one that is far more wise and deeply felt. Lovingly dedicated to actresses who have played actresses, this film weaves its own soap opera around ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' and tells of splendidly resilient women; Mr. Almodovar has aptly described his material as ''screwball drama.'' Rich and entertaining, this story celebrates the power of artifice and impersonation to transcend ordinary truth. The irrepressible Ms. San Juan, a Spanish nightclub performer, plays a transsexual named Agrado and is the film's biggest treat (Janet Maslin).     * ''AMERICAN BEAUTY,'' starring Kevin Spacey (winner of best-actor Oscar), Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes; winner of best picture, director, cinematography and original-screenplay Oscars). With heavenly finesse, Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Maslin).     * ''BEAU TRAVAIL,'' starring Denis Lavant and Gregoire Colin. Directed by Claire Denis (not rated, 90 minutes). A loose adaptation of ''Billy Budd,'' moved to the present and set in the East African enclave of Djibouti, Ms. Denis's finest film to date observes the day-to-day rituals of a troop of French Legionnaires training in a harshly beautiful wasteland. The  visually spellbinding movie depicts their rigorous drills and rituals as ecstatic rites of purification and the embodiment of an impenetrable masculine mystique. In this version of  the allegory, the Claggart figure, Sergeant Galoup (Mr. Lavant), is a disillusioned officer, and his prey (Mr. Colin) a soldier whose humanity offends the sergeant. Not to be missed (Stephen Holden).     * ''BOYS DON'T CRY,'' starring Hilary Swank (winner of best-actress Oscar) and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberly Peirce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of last year's best (Maslin).     * ''THE CIDER HOUSE RULES,'' starring Tobey Maguire, Charlize Theron, Delroy Lindo and Michael Caine (winner of best suporting actor Oscar). Directed by Lasse Hallstrom (PG-13, 125 minutes). Radically downsized in scope and its examination of the issue of abortion greatly softened, John Irving's sixth novel (with an Oscar-winning Dickensian screenplay by the author) has been turned into a lovely World War II-era fable about a young man venturing out into the world. Mr. Maguire is Homer Wells, a doleful innocent  brought up in an orphanage by Dr. Wilbur Larch (Mr. Caine), who performs abortions. Fleeing the institution with a golden young couple (Ms. Theron and Paul Rudd), he becomes an apple picker. Sentimental but smart, the movie has the sweetness and narrative drive of a 1940's ''David Copperfield'' (Holden).     * ''THE COLOR OF PARADISE,'' starring Mohsen Ramezani and Hossein Mahjur. Directed by Majid Majidi (PG, 90 minutes). This beautiful Iranian movie about a widowed father who is reluctant to care for his blind 8-year-old son is a heartbreaker done with such  conviction that it avoids mawkishness. When the special school the boy has been attending  won't keep him on, the father takes his son first to the family's woodland homestead, then  leaves him in the care of a blind carpenter. The movie evokes nature with an ecstatic sensuousness, and its heady soundtrack teems with the sounds of birds, insects, wind and rain (Holden).     ''ERIN BROCKOVICH,'' starring Julia Roberts and Albert Finney. Directed by Steven Soderbergh (R, 127 minutes). After a promising, effective beginning in which Ms. Roberts proves what a fine actress she can be and Mr. Soderbergh demonstrates yet again that he is one of the most thoughtful and original directors in Hollywood, ''Erin Brockovich'' becomes a doggedly conventional crusader-for-justice Hollywood melodrama, a smooth secondhand amalgam of ''Norma Rae'' and ''Silkwood,'' with vigorous nods to ''The Rainmaker'' and ''A Civil Action.'' Ms. Roberts, playing a working-class single mother who spearheads an effort to win justice for victims of corporate negligence, aggressively solicits an Oscar nomination. After acting for about 40 minutes, Ms. Roberts spends the next 90 content to be a movie star. As the movie drags on, her performance swells to bursting with moral vanity and phony populism. It's as if she had a clause in her contract strictly limiting anyone else's right to be attractive or appealing on screen. Who could have foreseen that Mr. Soderbergh, the most brilliantly unpredictable of filmmakers, could have made a movie so utterly hokey and conventional? (A. O. Scott).     ''GHOST DOG: THE WAY OF THE SAMURAI,'' starring Forest Whitaker. Directed by Jim Jarmusch (R, 116 minutes). In his new film Mr. Jarmusch does for the samurai epic and the gangster movie what he did for the western in ''Dead Man,'' his dreamy, elegiac deconstruction of cowboys-and-Indians mythology. Here he has composed a ruminative, bittersweet visual essay on brutality, honor and tribalism, which may frustrate audiences expecting more visceral thrills. ''Ghost Dog'' is worth seeing for Mr. Whitaker's witty, moving performance as a modern-day samurai caught up in a Mafia vendetta, for Mr. Jarmusch's offbeat sense of cinematic style and for the hip-hop artist the RZA's brilliant musical effects (Scott).     * ''HIGH FIDELITY,'' starring John Cusack,  Jill Peterson, Iben Hjejle and Joan Cusack. Directed by Stephen Frears (R, 107 minutes). Although its setting has been moved from London to Chicago, the screen adaptation of Nick Hornby's best-selling 1995 novel is wonderfully true to the spirit of the book. Mr. Cusack has one of his juiciest roles in Rob, a 30-something record store manager and vinyl  fanatic sorting through the ''Top 5'' breakups in his disastrous romantic history while trying to salvage his latest relationship. The movie hilariously captures the mind-set of not-so-young men for whom pop music is a  kind of religion and hip musical taste an ultimate measure of a person's worth (Holden).     ''MISSION TO MARS,'' starring Gary Sinise and Tim Robbins. Directed by Brian De Palma (PG, 113 minutes). This film's visual design is spectacular, and the scenes on the Martian surface look so real that the picture could have been made on location. But the movie is undermined by Mr. De Palma's uncharacteristic wet-eyed awe. All this addled sincerity comes from trying to create wonderment for adults out of a morose astronaut's rediscovery of his humanity on Mars. Mr. Sinise plays the depressed astronaut, and his thoughtful patience makes him appear to be a little sluggish, though not as sluggish as the movie: narratively it seems to be taking place in zero gravity, where each minute seems to last an additional 30 seconds. In space no one can hear you snore (Elvis Mitchell).     ''THE NINTH GATE,'' starring Johnny Depp and Frank Langella. Directed by Roman Polanski (R, 133 minutes). For those with an interest in seeing a dinner-theater version of ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' look no further. This film, with its wizened decadence and its tired stabs at comedy, is calling your name. Mr. Langella is Boris Balkan, a wealthy and therefore evil collector of Devil-inspired antiquities who hires Dean Corso (Mr. Depp), a weedy rogue book dealer, to locate a volume called ''The Nine Gates.'' Will Balkan get Satan's powers in his clutches through mastery of the book?  Mr. Polanski is out to cross ''Rosemary's Baby'' with his saucy spoof ''The Fearless Vampire Killers,'' but this movie is about as scary as a sock-puppet re-enactment of ''The Blair Witch Project,'' and not nearly as funny (Mitchell).     * ''NOT ONE LESS,'' starring Wei Minzhi and Zhang Huike. Directed by Zhang Yimou (not rated, 106 minutes). Zhang Yimou's new drama enlarges the possibilities of filmmaking even as it grounds itself in one of cinema's oldest, most basic principles: the camera's ability to document reality. At the center of the film is Wei (Wei Minzhi), a 13-year-old primary school graduate who has been pressed into service as a substitute teacher in the Shuiquan Primary School. When one of her students is sent to the city to work off his parents' debts, Wei, who has been promised a bonus if she can keep her class intact (this is the source of the film's title), sets out to bring him home. And the movie, which has so far been a slow, touching study of village life, becomes something else: a work of lyrical realism that has some of the shattering, redemptive power of Vittorio De Sica's ''Bicycle Thief'' (Scott).     ''THE ROAD TO EL DORADO,'' with the  voices of Kevin Kline, Kenneth Branagh and Rosie Perez. Directed by Eric Bibo Bergeron and Don Paul (PG, 89 minutes). This animated buddy movie aspires to the airiness of a Bob Hope-Bing Crosby ''road'' romp but it's  hopelessly bland even by those timid 1940's standards. Mr. Kline and Mr. Branagh provide the nearly interchangeable voices of two perky con men who foil Hernando Cortes's 1519 invasion of the mythical El Dorado. Though scenic and fast-paced, the main characters have no life, and the movie plays history false. Elton John and Tim Rice provided six clunky songs (Holden).     ''WAKING THE DEAD,'' starring Billy Crudup and Jennifer Connelly. Directed by Keith Gordon (R, 106 minutes). Mr. Gordon's earnest screen adaptation of Scott Spencer's popular novel about a love that transcends death aspires to be a kind of intellectualized ''Love Story,'' set in the 1970's counterculture. But the blend of history and heartbreak doesn't quite jell. Mr. Crudup, as a rising Chicago politician, and Ms. Connelly, as his radical activist girlfriend who dies in a car bombing, have good chemistry. But the movie is so busy jumping back and forth between the past and present that it is continually stumbling over itself and breaking its own spell (Holden).     * ''WINTER SLEEPERS,'' starring Ulrich Matthes, Marie-Lou Sellem, Floriane Daniel and Heino Ferch. Directed by Tom Tykwer (not rated, 124 minutes). Thrillingly virtuosic cinematic flourishes lend a steady charge of adrenaline to this drama about the tangled destinies of well-to-do German slackers in a picture-perfect skiing village. Made just before the jet-propelled pop fantasy ''Run Lola Run'' put Mr. Tykwer on the short list of major international filmmakers, ''Winter Sleepers'' conveys the spiritual malaise afflicting the generation in its late 20's and 30's. But like ''Run Lola Run,'' this movie is also about how human destiny has everything to do with split-second timing (Holden).    Film Series     ''FOR OPENERS: THE ART OF FILM TITLES.'' In the beginning are the titles. Blending image, sound, music and text, they enhance the experience of moviegoing by setting the mood and presenting the themes of a film. Today and tomorrow, the Film Society of Lincoln Center's Walter Reade Theater is presenting a tribute to movie title designers and their work in an event that includes two panels, two illustrated presentations and two programs of short films. At 6 tonight, predigital designers like Pablo Ferro (''Dr. Strangelove'') and Wayne Fitzgerald (''Bonnie and Clyde'') are to discuss their work, and at 8:15 the writer Ken Coupland and the designer David Peters are to show and discuss some 20 classic and rarely seen sequences from 1950 to 1980 by Saul Bass, Maurice Binder, Mr.  Ferro, Robert Greenberg and others for directors like Stanley Donen, Blake Edwards, Alfred Hitchcock, Stanley Kubrick and Otto Preminger. At 6:15 p.m. tomorrow, a new generation of motion picture graphic designers like Randy Balsmeyer (''Magnolia'') and Deborah Ross (''The Talented Mr. Ripley'') are to discuss and show their work and at 8:15 Mr. Coupland and Mr. Peters are to discuss and show film titles from 1980 to the present. The tribute continues through tomorrow at the Walter Reade, at Lincoln Center. Admission: $9; $5 for Film Society members. Information: (212) 875-5600 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

snippet: Grace Glueck reviews current and permanent exhibits in museums along Maine's art trail; describes collections at Farnsworth Art Museum, Ogunquit Museum, Bowdoin College Museum, Colby College Museum, Bates College Museum and University of Maine Mus...
lead_paragraph: ART museums are not what you think of first in connection with the natural glories of Maine, but there are no fewer than seven significant ones in this sparsely populated state. And why not? With its wealth of woods, water and mountains, Maine has always lured artists, among them Winslow Homer, Martin Johnson Heade, Marsden Hartley, Childe Hassam, John Marin, Alex Katz, Robert Indiana and Maurice Prendergast.

snippet: Most computer users are aware that reading text from computer screen does not offer same quality as it does from printer paper; while there have been number of efforts to improve monitors themselves, technical limitations of monitors is shifting t...
lead_paragraph: IF anyone should know how hard it is to read from a computer screen, it is Dr. James Sheedy. A clinical professor of optometry at the University of California at Berkeley and founder of its Computer Eye Clinic, Dr. Sheedy has treated patients with computer-related eye strain for nearly 15 years.
abstract: Most computer users are aware that reading text from computer screen does not offer same quality as it does from printer paper; while there have been number of efforts to improve monitors themselves, technical limitations of monitors is shifting the effort to improve text display to software changes; two leading software alternatives are ClearType from Microsoft and ClearView from Ductus; both software applications try in different ways to make screen type easier to read; ClearType will work only on LCD (liquid crystal display) screens; photos; graphic on how LCD screens handle pixels (M)

lead_paragraph: INFORMATION, as the saying goes, wants to be free. In this spirit, a growing number of Internet service providers have begun offering completely free Internet access: no monthly charges and no start-up fees.
abstract: Gerowing number of companies like NetZero, World Spy and Freei.net are now allowing anyone with perconal computer and modem to browse Web at no charge, and, through aggressive advertising campaigns, aim to lure Web users from fee-based services like America Online and Earthlink; evidence that trend is accelerating is evidenced by established Web names Alta Vista and Juno joining their ranks last January; free access has been slower to catch on in the United States compared to other countries, such as Britain; industry analyst predicts 13 percent of Net users will gain access via free providers by 2003--healthy amount, but not likely enough to scare AOL; brief description of some free Web providers and their site addresses (M)

lead_paragraph: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.
abstract: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 10.    Now Playing    * ''AMERICAN BEAUTY,'' starring Kevin Spacey, Annette Bening, Chris Cooper, Wes Bentley and Thora Birch. Written by Alan Ball. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 116 minutes). With heavenly finesse Mr. Spacey plays a buttoned-down 42-year-old suburbanite who flips his lid for a teenage cheerleader. And he never gets it back on. The midlife crisis motif is familiar, but the stage director Sam Mendes brings terrific visual flair and dry humor to this barbecuing of the bourgeoisie. All the actors display coolly expert timing, especially Ms. Bening as the antihero's grasping wife. Although the story spreads itself thin among many characters, the film coalesces for a devastating finale (Janet Maslin).    * ''BOILER ROOM,'' starring Giovanni Ribisi, Vin Diesel and Ben Affleck. Written and directed by Ben Younger (R, 110 minutes). Mr. Ribisi portrays a young stockbroker in training at a fly-by-night company called J. T. Marlin. Like Oliver Stone's ''Wall Street,'' ''Boiler Room'' tells the story of an ambitious young man's rise, fall and redemption. And like Charlie Sheen's Bud Fox, Mr. Ribisi's Seth carries some heavy Oedipal baggage -- a troubled relationship with his demanding, disapproving father -- onto the trading floor. But at its best, which is awfully good, ''Boiler Room'' avoids the thumping moralism that has made Mr. Stone the least misunderstood director in Hollywood. It's less about selling your soul than about feeling your oats (A. O. Scott).    * ''BOYS DON'T CRY,'' starring Hilary Swank and Chloe Sevigny. Directed by Kimberly Peirce (R, 114 minutes). This stunning debut feature tells the strange and resonant story of Brandon Teena, who despite being born Teena Brandon went on to create a charismatic identity as a young man. Brandon's ultimately wrenching tale may sound tabloid-ready, but on screen it turns into Theodore Dreiser's idea of American tragedy. The film makes it hauntingly real and even tenderly romantic, with the astonishing acting needed to make it work. One of last year's best (Maslin).    * ''THE CIDER HOUSE RULES,'' starring Tobey Maguire, Charlize Theron and Delroy Lindo. Directed by Lasse Hallstrom (PG-13, 125 minutes). Radically downsized in scope, and its examination of the issue of abortion greatly softened, John Irving's sixth novel (with a Dickensian screenplay by the author) has been turned into a lovely World War II-era fable about a young man venturing out into the world. Mr. Maguire is Homer Wells, a doleful innocent raised in an orphanage by Dr. Wilbur Larch (Michael Caine), who performs abortions. Fleeing the institution with a golden young couple (Ms. Theron and Paul Rudd), he becomes an apple picker. Sentimental but smart, the movie has the sweetness and narrative drive of a 1940's ''David Copperfield'' (Stephen Holden).    ''ERIN BROCKOVICH,'' starring Julia Roberts and Albert Finney. Directed by Steven Soderbergh (R, 127 minutes). After a promising, effective beginning, in which Ms. Roberts proves what a fine actress she can be, and Mr. Soderbergh demonstrates yet again that he is one of the most thoughtful and original directors in Hollywood, ''Erin Brockovich'' becomes a doggedly conventional crusader-for-justice Hollywood melodrama, a smooth secondhand amalgam of ''Norma Rae'' and ''Silkwood,'' with vigorous nods to ''The Rainmaker'' and ''A Civil Action.'' Ms. Roberts, playing a working-class single mother who spearheads an effort to win justice for victims of corporate negligence, aggressively solicits an Oscar nomination. After acting for about 40 minutes, Ms. Roberts spends the next 90 content to be a movie star. As the movie drags on, her performance swells to bursting with moral vanity and phony populism. It's as though she had a clause in her contract strictly limiting anyone else's right to be attractive or appealing on screen. Who could have foreseen that Mr. Soderbergh, the most brilliantly unpredictable of filmmakers, could have made a movie so utterly hokey and conventional? (Scott).    ''GHOST DOG: THE WAY OF THE SAMURAI,'' starring Forest Whitaker. Directed by Jim Jarmusch (R, 116 minutes). In his new film Mr. Jarmusch does for the samurai epic and the gangster movie what he did for the western in ''Dead Man,'' his dreamy, elegiac deconstruction of cowboys-and-Indians mythology. Here he has composed a ruminative, bittersweet visual essay on brutality, honor and tribalism, which may frustrate audiences expecting more visceral thrills. ''Ghost Dog'' is worth seeing for Mr. Whitaker's witty, moving performance as a modern-day samurai caught up in a Mafia vendetta, for Mr. Jarmusch's offbeat sense of cinematic style and for the hip-hop artist the RZA's brilliant musical effects (Scott).    * ''THE HURRICANE,'' starring Denzel Washington. Directed by Norman Jewison (R, 120 minutes). The life story of Hurricane Carter, a middleweight contender who spent nearly 20 years in prison for a triple murder he denied committing, is a big, schmaltzy ballad of a movie redeemed by Mr. Washington's moving, bone-deep portrayal of the boxer. But the movie plays fast and loose with the facts, giving far too much credit to the members of a Canadian commune who took up Mr. Carter's cause and all but eliminating his courageous co-defendant, John Artis, from the story. And the minor characters are either saints or monsters. Yet the story of a man heroically fighting his demons and winning his freedom is still inspiring (Holden).    ''MISSION TO MARS,'' starring Gary Sinise and Tim Robbins. Directed by Brian De Palma (PG, 113 minutes). This film's visual design is spectacular, and the scenes on the Martian surface look so real that the picture could have been made on location. But the movie is undermined by Mr. De Palma's uncharacteristic wet-eyed awe. All this addled sincerity comes from trying to create wonderment for adults out of a morose astronaut's rediscovery of his humanity on Mars. Mr. Sinise plays the depressed astronaut, and his thoughtful patience makes him appear to be a little sluggish, though not as sluggish as the movie: narratively it seems to be taking place in zero gravity, where each minute seems to last an additional 30 seconds. In space no one can hear you snore (Elvis Mitchell).    ''THE NEXT BEST THING,'' starring Rupert Everett and Madonna. Directed by John Schlesinger (PG-13, 107 minutes). A contemporary screwball comedy about a Los Angeles yoga teacher (Madonna) and her gay best friend (Mr. Everett) who have a baby together, ''The Next Best Thing'' intermittently fizzes in its early scenes. But once it gets serious, the movie turns into a stumbling, poor man's ''Kramer vs. Kramer.'' Madonna is a curt, cool cookie whose painfully flat performance is all but devoid of feeling. Mr. Everett has a few bright comic moments as a man who discovers the joys of fatherhood (Holden).    ''THE NINTH GATE,'' starring Johnny Depp and Frank Langella. Directed by Roman Polanski (R, 133 minutes). For those with an interest in seeing a dinner-theater version of ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' then look no further. This film, with its wizened decadence and its tired stabs at comedy, is calling your name. Mr. Langella is Boris Balkan, a wealthy and therefore evil collector of Devil-inspired antiquities, who hires Dean Corso (Mr. Depp), a weedy rogue book dealer, to locate a volume called ''The Nine Gates.'' Will Balkan get Satan's powers in his clutches through mastery of the book? Mr. Polanski is out to cross ''Rosemary's Baby'' with his saucy spoof ''The Fearless Vampire Killers,'' but this movie is about as scary as a sock-puppet re-enactment of ''The Blair Witch Project,'' and not nearly as funny (Mitchell).    * ''NOT ONE LESS,'' starring Wei Minzhi and Zhang Huike. Directed by Zhang Yimou (not rated, 106 minutes). Zhang Yimou's new drama enlarges the possibilities of filmmaking even as it grounds itself in one of cinema's oldest, most basic principles: the camera's ability to document reality. At the center of the film is Wei (Wei Minzhi), a 13-year-old primary school graduate who has been pressed into service as a substitute teacher in the Shuiquan Primary School. When one of her students is sent to the city to work off his parents' debts, Wei, who has been promised a bonus if she can keep her class intact (this is the source of the film's title), sets out to bring him home. And the movie, which has so far been a slow, touching study of village life, becomes something else: a work of lyrical realism that has some of the shattering, redemptive power of Vittorio De Sica's ''Bicycle Thief'' (Scott).    * ''REINDEER GAMES,'' starring Ben Affleck, Gary Sinise and Charlize Theron. Directed by John Frankenheimer (R, 99 minutes). This is a wheel-within-a-wheel thriller that's a lot of fun until, near the end, it becomes a Xerox copy of a blueprint of a hit. Mr. Affleck, who suggests one of the Kennedys playing Clark Kent -- he wants to keep his light under a bushel, but he's not quite up to it -- plays Rudy, an ex-con who gets dragged into a casino heist planned for the Christmas season. Ms. Theron is the girl who lures him into the job. The seamy kicks of one double cross after another keep the movie in motion, and Mr. Frankenheimer's ruthless precision keeps it on track (Mitchell).    * ''SCREAM 3,'' starring David Arquette, Neve Campbell and Courteney Cox Arquette. Directed by Wes Craven (R, 116 minutes). At this point it goes without saying that the ''Scream'' movies are like episodes of ''Scooby Doo.'' Like the others, ''Scream 3'' belongs on the Cartoon Network, but this time for a better reason: The film is funny and brisk, with enough good lines to make the comedy more satisfying than the somewhat routine but still unsettling jolts to the spine. Mr. Craven and his group recognize that the franchise's real competition is not the recent hit films ''The Blair Witch Project'' and ''The Sixth Sense'' but rather ''Scream'' itself. ''Scream 3'' doesn't skimp on jacked-up scares, but it's as much a personality show as it is a slasher film (Mitchell).    * ''TOPSY-TURVY,'' starring Allan Corduner and Jim Broadbent. Directed by Mike Leigh (R, 161 minutes). Mr. Leigh's grandly entertaining ''Topsy-Turvy'' is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting opportunities, much as ''Shakespeare in Love'' did. Instead of a love-struck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivan in the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway (Maslin).    ''THE WHOLE NINE YARDS,'' starring Matthew Perry and Bruce Willis. Directed by Jonathan Lynn (R, 100 minutes). Oz (Mr. Perry) is a nice-guy dentist beaten down by his bored wife. When the confident Jimmy (Mr. Willis) breezes into the house next door, Oz's anxieties are ratcheted up several points on the Richter scale. It turns out that Jimmy is a former Chicago organized-crime figure who ratted out his associates. The movie has an intricate plot, with hit men, love interests, large sums of money and allegiances constantly in motion. But it is missing the verve of someone who can take a simple idea to the extreme; it must have been directed by a sleepwalker. Despite Mr. Perry's plucky slapstick and the treacherous gunplay that account for the second half of the movie, ''Yards'' is underwhelming, amusing only in fits and starts (Mitchell).    * ''WINTER SLEEPERS,'' starring Ulrich Matthes, Marie-Lou Sellem, Floriane Daniel and Heino Ferch. Directed by Tom Tykwer (not rated, 124 minutes). Thrillingly virtuosic cinematic flourishes lend a steady charge of adrenaline to this drama about the tangled destinies of well-to-do German slackers in a picture-perfect skiing village. Made just before the jet-propelled pop fantasy ''Run Lola Run'' put Mr. Tykwer on the short list of major international filmmakers, ''Winter Sleepers'' conveys the spiritual malaise afflicting the generation now in its late 20's and 30's. But like ''Run Lola Run,'' the movie is also about how human destiny has everything to do with split-second timing (Holden).    ''WONDER BOYS,'' starring Michael Douglas, Frances McDormand and Tobey Maguire. Directed by Curtis Hanson (R, 112 minutes). This film boasts a first-rate cast, a credible literary source and a director whose last film, ''L.A. Confidential,'' showed a prodigious ability to capture the headlong rhythms of a complex plot and the particularities of a motley assortment of characters. But even with so much going for it, this adaptation of Michael Chabon's novel about a pot-smoking middle-aged novelist burdened by romantic and creative problems is flat and unconvincing. There's no shortage of screwball material: a dead dog, an errant tuba and a very tall drag queen, for starters. But Mr. Hanson, perhaps aiming for wry understatement, has smothered whatever antic rhythm the story might have had. Despite a brilliant supporting turn by Robert Downey Jr. as a gay book editor, ''Wonder Boys'' is like a George Cukor movie with a bad head cold: slow, muffled and vague (Scott).
